(f)  Whenever a building or structure, used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, because of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, decay, damage, faulty construction or arrangement inadequate light, air or sanitation facilities, or otherwise, is determined by the building official to be unsanitary, unfit for human habitation or in such a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease. 
(g)  Whenever any building or structure, because of obsolescence, dilapidated condition, deterioration, damage, inadequate exits, lack of sufficient fire-resistive construction, faulty electric wiring, gas connections or heating apparatus, or other causes, is determined by the building official to be a fire hazard. 
(h)  Whenever any portion of a building or structure remains on a site after the demolition or destruction of the building or structure or whenever any building or structure is abandoned for a period of three (3) months so as to constitute such building or portion thereof, a nuisance or hazard to the public. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 7-60. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Administration. The city manager or his or her authorized representative or building official is hereby authorized to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Right to inspect. In order to determine whether a building is dangerous or abandoned within the meaning of this code section, a building official may, with the consent of the owner, occupant, or agent, enter upon any property and make an inspection. Such inspection may include the taking of photographs, surveys, samples or other physical evidence. If an owner, occupant or agent refuses consent to the inspection, or if facts or circumstances exist reasonably justifying the failure to seek such consent, a building official may seek an administrative inspection warrant pursuant to the procedures provided for under applicable South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(c)  Commencement of proceedings. Whenever a building official has determined that a building is a dangerous building, he or she may commence proceedings to cause the repair, vacation or demolition of the building. 
(d)  Notice and order. The building official shall issue a notice and order directed to the record owner of the building. The notice and order shall contain: 
(1)  Address, description. The street address and legal description sufficient for identification of the premises upon which the building is located. 
(2)  Statement by building official. A statement that the building official has found the building to be dangerous, with a brief and concise description of the conditions found to render the building dangerous under the provisions of this article. 
(3)  Statement of action required. A statement advising that any person having any recorded title or legal interest in the building may appeal from the notice and order or any action of the building official to the city commission. The appeal must be made in writing as provided in this article, and filed with the building official within ten (10) days from the date of service of such notice and order. In addition the notice must advise that failure to appeal will constitute a waiver of all rights to a hearing on the matter. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77; Ord. No. 1008, 6-11-18) 
Sec. 7-61. - Action required. 
    The following action shall be taken as determined by the building official: 
(a)  If the building official has determined that the building must be repaired, the order shall require that all required permits be secured therefor and the work physically commenced within thirty (30) days from the date of the order, and to be completed within one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of the order. 
(b)  If the building official has determined that the building or structure must be vacated, the order shall require that the building or structure shall be vacated within forty-five (45) days from the date of the order. 
(c)  If the building official has determined that the building or structure must be demolished, the order shall require that the building be vacated (if necessary) and all permits secured within forty-five (45) days from the date of the order, and that the demolition be completed within sixty (60) days from the date of the order. Completed demolition shall include fencing or filling of open basements as soon as exposed. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
Sec. 7-62. - Service of notice and order. 
    The notice and order and any amended or supplemental notice and order shall be served upon the record owner of the building and/or property, and tenants. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
Sec. 7-63. - Method of service. 
    Service of the notice and order shall be made upon all persons entitled thereto either personally or by mailing a copy of such notice and order by certified mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, to the property owner. If no address of any such person so appears or is known to the building official, a copy of the notice and order shall be published two (2) consecutive times in the legal newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
Sec. 7-64. - Standards to be followed in repair, vacation and demolition. 
    Standards to be followed in repair, vacation and demolition shall be followed by the building official in ordering the repair, vacation or demolition of any dangerous building or structure: 
(a)  The conditions or defects causing a building to be declared dangerous under this article shall either be repaired in accordance with the current building code or shall be demolished at the option of the building owner. 
(b)  If the building or structure is in such condition as to make it immediately dangerous to the life, limb, property or safety of the public or its occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
Sec. 7-65. - Board of appeals. 
(a)  Established. In order to provide for final interpretation of the provisions of this article and to hear appeals provided for hereunder, there is hereby established a board of appeals, which shall be the board of city commissioners. 
(b)  Filing of appeal. Any person may appeal from any notice and order or any action of the building official under this article by filing at the office of the building official within ten (10) days from the date of the service of such order a written appeal containing: 
(1)  A brief statement of the specific order or action protested, together with any material facts claimed to support the contentions of the person appealing. 
(2)  A brief statement of the relief sought and reasons why it is claimed the protested order or action should be reversed, modified or otherwise set aside. 
(c)  Processing of appeal. Upon receipt of any appeal filed pursuant to this section, the building official shall present it at the next regular meeting of the city commission. 
(d)  Scheduling and noticing appeal for hearing. As soon as practicable after receiving the written appeal, the city commission shall fix a date, time and place for the hearing of the appeal. Written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing to each appellant. 
(e)  Failure to appeal. Failure of any person to file an appeal in accordance with the provisions of this section shall constitute a waiver of his right to an administrative hearing and adjudication of the notice and order, or any portion, thereof. 
(f)  Staying of order under appeal. Enforcement of any notice and order of the building official issued under this article shall be stayed during the pendency of an appeal therefrom which is properly and timely filed. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
Sec. 7-66. - Enforcement of the order of the building official or the city commission. 
(a)  Failure to commence work. Whenever the required repair or demolition is not commenced within thirty (30) days after a final notice and order issued under this article becomes effective: 
(1)  The building official shall declare the building described as dangerous and order it to be vacated by posting at each entrance thereto a notice stating the building is dangerous and unsafe for human occupancy. 
(2)  No person shall occupy any building which has been posted as specified in this section. No person shall remove or deface any such notice so posted until the repairs, demolition or removal ordered by the building official has been completed. 
(b)  Interference with repair or demolition work prohibited. No person shall obstruct, impede or interfere with any officer, employee, contractor or authorized representative of the city, or with any person who owns or holds any estate or interest in any building which has been ordered repaired, vacated or demolished under the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Failure to obey order. If, after any order of the building official or city commission made pursuant to this article has become final, the person to whom such order is directed shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey such order, the city commission may cause such person to be prosecuted for violation of this article. 
(d)  Violations. Each day a violation occurs may be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 450, 9-26-77) 
ARTICLE V. - SAFETY BARRIERS FOR PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 7-67. - Definitions as used in this article. 
    Private swimming pool. Any constructed or prefabricated pool used for swimming or bathing, over twenty-four (24) inches in depth and having a surface area of more than one hundred fifty (150) square feet. 
(Ord. No. 611, § 1, 3-13-89) 
Sec. 7-68. - Safety barrier required. 
(a)  Generally. No private swimming pool final inspection and approval shall be given by the building official unless there has been erected a safety barrier as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Types. The safety barrier shall take the form of a screened-in patio, a wooden fence, a wire fence, a concrete block wall, a pool cover, natural terrain or other materials so as to enable the owner to blend the same with the style of architecture planned or in existence on the property. 
(c)  Standards. The minimum height of the safety barrier shall be not less than four (4) feet. The safety barrier shall be erected either around the swimming pool or around the premises on which the swimming pool is located; in either event, it shall enclose the area entirely, prohibiting unrestrained admittance to the enclosed area. The main structure or any accessory structure on the site may form part of the enclosure. 
    The sides of above grade pools are acceptable as enclosures; provided that the sides extend not less than four (4) feet above the outside ground at all points; and provided, further, that access steps, ladders or decks are capable of being rendered inaccessible by being moved or raised more than four (4) feet above the outside grade. 
    Pool covers shall be acceptable as a safety barrier if the pool cover provides a secure barrier against water entry and if said cover is in compliance with the "Standard Performance Specifications for Safety Covers," as developed by the American Society for Testing Materials, which is hereby adopted by reference. 
    Natural terrain shall be acceptable if it is of sufficient height or roughness to limit access to the property by an adult of average strength and stamina. 
    Gates shall be of the self-closing and self-latching type so that they shall automatically be in a closed position at all times. The self-latching device shall be located a minimum of three (3) feet above grade. 
(d)  Building permit. Before any work is commenced, a building permit shall be secured for all swimming pools and for the safety barrier. Plans shall contain all details to show compliance with the terms and conditions of these regulations. If the premises are already enclosed, as hereinbefore provided, a permit for the safety barrier shall not be required if, upon inspection of the premises, the existing barrier is proven to be satisfactory. 
(e)  Fences; walls. The wooden-type fence shall have the boards, pickets, louvers or other such members spaced so as not to have openings greater than four (4) inches in width, constructed and erected so as to make the fence resistive to climbing. Walls, whether of the rock- or block-type, shall be so erected as to make them resistive to climbing. Wire fences shall be two-inch chain link or diamond-weave, resistive to climbing, or of an approved equal with top rail. They shall be of a minimum of 11 gauge galvanized material. 
(f)  Authority; appeal. The building inspector shall have the authority to refuse approval of any safety barrier which, in the opinion of the building inspector, does not meet the requirements of this section, i.e., that it is high enough and so constructed or aligned as to keep children of preschool age from getting over or through the safety barrier. The owner or a representative of the owner of the pool may appeal the decision of the building inspector to the board of city commissioners. Such appeal shall be filed within ten (10) days of notice of the action of the building inspector. The board of city commissioners shall give the owner ten (10) days' notice of a hearing on the appeal; at which time, the board of city commissioners shall consider the appeal, all pertinent information and render a decision. 
(g)  Violation; penalty. Failure to comply with the terms hereof shall be unlawful and shall be fined or punished as stipulated in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 611, § 1, 3-13-89) 
Sec. 7-69. - Retroactivity of requirements. 
    The lack of a safety barrier as herein described on any existing pool is hereby deemed to be a serious public safety hazard. The owner of the property upon which such a pool is located shall comply with the safety barrier requirements of section 7-68 of this article within thirty (30) days after the date of notification to comply. Failure to comply with the terms hereof shall be unlawful and shall be fined or punished as stipulated in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 611, § 1, 3-13-89) 
Chapter 71/2 - CEMETERIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 71/2-1-71/2-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - YANKTON MUNICIPAL CEMETERY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 357, adopted Dec. 27, 1971, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion herein as Ch. 71/2, Art. II, §§ 71/2-11-71/2-42, was at the discretion of the editors. The introduction to said ordinance provides: "The Board of City Commissioners has deemed it in the public interest for the City of Yankton to assume all assets and liabilities of the present Yankton Cemetery Association. With the effective date of this Ordinance the City of Yankton hereby accepts all assets and liabilities of the Yankton Cemetery Association. All rules and regulations of said Yankton Cemetery Association shall continue in effect until modified or changed by the Board of City Commissioners." Ord. No. 357 is included herein as enacted, however in several instances catchlines were altered to facilitate indexing and reference and "ordinance" was changed to "article" where appropriate. 

Sec. 71/2-11. - Location and designation. 
    The cemetery owned by the city and located on the northwest quarter of the southwest quarter except the east 873.5 feet of the north 592 feet, Section 6, Township 93, Range 55, Yankton County, South Dakota, shall be known and designated as Yankton Municipal Cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-12. - Control of cemetery vested in city commission; supervision by city manager. 
    The control of the Yankton Municipal Cemetery shall be vested in the city commission with supervision by the city manager who shall employ a sexton and other laborers. The city manager may delegate the day to day supervision of the Yankton Municipal Cemetery to the department of parks and recreation under the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-13. - Sale and regulation of use of lots. 
    Lots may be sold subject to the rules and regulations which now are or hereafter may be prescribed by the city commission and shall not be used for any purpose other than a place of burial for the dead. No interment of any body other than that of a human being shall be made therein. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-14. - Permit prerequisite to interment; contents and procedures. 
    No dead body of any human being shall be interred in said cemetery until a permit for the interment of such body shall be obtained from the finance officer. Said permit shall be given without charge upon the receipt of a certificate of death from the physician in attendance or other proper evidence of death of a human being. No sexton or undertaker shall assist in or about the interment of a body until a permit for the interment of such body shall have been obtained as aforesaid. Said permit shall give the name of the deceased, sex, nativity, date of birth, date of death, age, and cause of death, and shall be signed by the officer issuing the same. Said permit shall be delivered to the sexton at or before the interment and shall be returned by the sexton to the finance officer immediately after the interment with a memorandum thereon showing the lot and portion of the lot on which the grave is situated. The finance officer shall keep a record of said permit and memorandum thereon. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-15. - Funerals prohibited after 5:00 p.m.; exception. 
    No funeral will be allowed in the cemetery after 5:00 p.m., except by special permission of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-16. - Burials on Sunday or legal holiday. 
    Burials on Sundays and on any legal holiday declared by state law will not be permitted in the cemetery, except upon special permit therefor issued by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-17. - Lot plans and specifications of city engineer to govern sale. 
    The lots in such cemetery shall be sold according to the plans and specifications drawn by the city engineer and now on file in his office. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-18. - Monuments and markers to conform to master plan. 
    All monuments and markers in the Yankton Municipal Cemetery shall be erected to comply with the master layout plan on file with the finance officer. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-19. - Lot prices determined by city commission. 
    The price of such lots shall be as specified and designated in the plans and specifications of the city engineer now on file in his office and shall include an amount sufficient in the discretion of the city commissioners to permanently care for such lots. The selling price shall be fixed from time to time by such commission, by resolution, and filed with the finance officer. 
    Lots shall be sold at the prices so specified. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-20. - Moneys received for grave work deposited in cemetery maintenance fund. 
    The city manager shall have control of the digging of all graves in said cemetery as well as for the opening of any grave for exhuming any casket or body buried in said cemetery. The funds for such work shall be paid into the city treasury and credited to the cemetery maintenance fund. No grave opening shall take place until all fees for said lot and/or opening have been paid. The charge for such services shall be fixed by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-21. - Records to be maintained by sexton and finance officer. 
    The sexton shall keep a book to be furnished and owned by the city in which he shall record the decedent's age and the cause of his death and the number of the lot and block of his burial and he shall report quarterly to the city commission the names and other facts so required to be recorded by him. The finance officer shall transcribe such names and other facts in a book to be furnished and owned by the city and kept in the finance office. Said book shall be known as the burial record. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-22. - Burial restricted to one body per grave; exception of mother and child. 
    One (1) body will be allowed in a grave except in case of a mother and infant, in which case special permission must be obtained from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-23. - Burials restricted to lot owner's family; exception by permission of city manager; permission of city manager for disposition of lot. 
    No burial of other than known members of the family of the lot owner, except on lots owned by Yankton County, will be allowed, except on written permission of the city manager. Such permission shall be filed in the office of finance officer and no lot owner will be allowed to dispose of any lot or portion thereof for a remuneration or consideration without the approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-24. - Grave requirements and preparation; notice; supervision of sexton. 
    The digging of all graves shall be done by the sexton or under his supervision. All graves shall be of a depth of at least five (5) feet. 
    Twenty-four (24) hours' notice for the digging of graves must be given either to the sexton or at the office of the finance officer and in all cases the box must be either sent at once to the ground or the exact size of the box must be left with the sexton. 
    Graves must be located at least six (6) inches within the boundaries of the lot. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-25. - Plat and requirements of grade of graves. 
    All graves shall be on a level with the grade established by the city engineer and a plat thereof filed by him in the office of the finance officer and all graves shall be raised or lowered to conform to such established grades. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-26. - Permit and conditions of disinterment. 
    No body shall be exhumed except by the permission of the county health officer or other proper public authority. 
    No disinterment in a lot or removal of a body will be allowed without the assent in writing of the surviving husband or wife or next of kin to the person whose body is to be disinterred or removed. Written permission from the owner of the lot or his lawful representative shall also be required. Such permission shall be on file with the finance officer. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-27. - Perpetual care; deposit; records and investments. 
    The city manager shall establish and maintain a perpetual care fund. The purpose of this fund shall be to provide for the future care and maintenance of the Yankton Municipal Cemetery. The fund shall contain the assets of the Yankton Cemetery Association's Perpetual Care Fund. When lots are purchased, thirty-three (33) per cent of the purchase price of said lot(s) shall be placed in the perpetual care fund. 
    The city manager shall invest the principal of said perpetual care fund in accordance with city commission investment policies and relevant state statutes. The interest received from said investments shall be used for the care and maintenance of the Yankton Municipal Cemetery and shall be credited to the cemetery maintenance fund. The principal of the perpetual care fund shall be maintained in accordance with relevant state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-28. - Cemetery maintenance fund; purpose, establishment. 
    The city manager shall establish the cemetery maintenance fund. The purpose of this fund shall be to provide for the operating and capital expenses of the cemetery. All funds, not credited to the perpetual care fund, or other funds, shall be credited to the cemetery maintenance fund. Budgeting, disbursements and other charges against this fund shall be handled in the same manner as other city funds. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-29. - Work in addition to general maintenance; extra charge. 
    Persons may have extra care or work done upon their lots as may be approved by the city manager, by giving written order to the sexton at the cemetery or at the finance office specifying the work to be done. All such orders must be approved by the city manager and he shall determine the charges. All orders shall be promptly executed and a reasonable charge shall be made. All such charges for work or special care are payable at the time of completion of the work at the finance office. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-30. - Requirements of workmen and erection of monuments, vaults or other structures; removal of stone work or other materials from lots. 
    When stone work or other material is to be removed from any lot, application must be made in writing by the lot owner to the sexton of the cemetery. 
    Persons engaged in erecting vaults, monuments or other structures shall not attach ropes to trees, shrubs, or other objects without the permission of the sexton. 
    All workmen within the confines of the cemetery shall be subject to the direction and supervision of the sexton. Workmen in violation of the regulations and properties of the cemetery shall not be admitted to work therein. 
    The foundations of all monuments erected in the cemetery shall extend below the frost line and such foundations shall be solidly constructed of stone or cement. The city commission may, by resolution, establish rates for the foundation and location of monuments. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-31. - City removal and disposition of articles left on graves; immunity. 
    The city or its officers shall not be held responsible for articles which may be placed on lots and may remove the same without notice. All articles removed from graves and lots shall not be accounted for in any way after ten (10) days from removal. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-32. - Water supply and apparatus for exclusive use of sexton. 
    The hydrants and hose of the water supply are for the exclusive use of the sexton in the care of said cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-33. - Unlawful to injure or damage any property within the cemetery. 
    No person shall break, pluck or otherwise injure any wild or cultivated plant, or break or otherwise injure any tree or shrub or deface or mar any monument or make any mark thereon by writing or otherwise, or injure any landmark or deface or injure any part of the fence around or upon said cemetery, or paint or otherwise put up any sign upon any part of any fence around or upon said cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-34. - Unlawful to erect coping or walls, grade lots or plant trees or shrubs without permission. 
    No fence or coping or walls shall be erected on or around any tree or shrub planted in said cemetery without the consent of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-35. - Unlawful to disturb the quiet and good order of the cemetery. 
    No person shall disturb the quiet and good order of the cemetery. All persons violating this section shall immediately leave the cemetery upon request of the person in charge of same. No person shall enter the cemetery except through the gates when opened by the sexton. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-36. - Unlawful to exceed speed of ten miles per hour or drive other than on the streets and driveways of the cemetery; funeral processions. 
    No driving shall be permitted in the cemetery except upon the streets and driveways thereof. 
    The speed limit in the cemetery shall be ten (10) miles per hour. All funeral processions while within the grounds shall be subject to the directions of the sexton. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-37. - Unlawful for contractors to damage cemetery property; repairs. 
    All contractors shall be held responsible for any damage or injury done to the grass, lots, trees and property of the cemetery and on order must be given to the sexton to repair the same at the expense of the lot owner or contractor. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-38. - Dogs and firearms prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall be permitted to enter the cemetery with firearms except those persons attending funerals involving military honors. 
    No person shall be permitted to enter the cemetery with dogs. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-39. - Unlawful to solicit in cemetery. 
    Soliciting work in the cemetery or placing business cards upon lots is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-40. - Unlawful to set or cause fires in or about cemetery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to set fire or cause to be set any fire in or about the grounds of Yankton Municipal Cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-41. - Additional cemeteries prohibited; purpose. 
    For the purpose of exercising the power delegated to it by the laws of the State of South Dakota, the city commission of the City of Yankton, South Dakota, has determined and does hereby determine that good cause and reason exists for regulating and prohibiting the establishment of additional cemeteries within the corporate limits of the City of Yankton, South Dakota and within one mile of the city limits of the city of Yankton, South Dakota. 
Cemeteries prohibited within city and within one mile thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to establish and/or maintain a cemetery or cemeteries within the limits of the City of Yankton, South Dakota, or within one mile of the corporate limits of the City of Yankton, South Dakota. 
Prohibition not applicable to existing cemeteries. The prohibition herein contained shall not apply to any person that has heretofore established and is maintaining a cemetery within the limits of or within one mile of the corporate limits of the City of Yankton, South Dakota, nor shall said prohibition be applicable to the existing cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Sec. 71/2-42. - Rules and regulations of city manager. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to establish rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this article, governing the operation and maintenance of the cemetery and the conduct of persons therein. Such rules and regulations shall be approved by resolution of the city commission. When so approved, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate any such rule or regulation. Such rules and regulations shall be published in booklet form and shall be considered to be part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 357, 12-27-71) 
Chapter 8 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire zones established, § 7-1; fire hydrants usage, § 26-50. 
State Law reference- Municipal fire protection and safety regulations, SDCL 1967, § 9-33-1, et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Interference with fire department. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully hinder or interfere with any city officer or firefighter in the performance of his duty at, going to, or returning from any fire, or while attending to his duty as a member of the fire department. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 4.0108; Ord. No. 884, 2-27-06) 
Sec. 8-2. - Damaging of fire apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully break, deface, destroy, cut, or in any manner injure or damage, tamper or interfere with any fire engine or other fire apparatus or equipment. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 4.0109) 
Sec. 8-3. - False alarm of fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to give, knowingly, a false alarm or false report of a fire in any manner. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 4.0110) 
Sec. 8-4. - Duties of police department at fire scene; police authority of firefighters. 
    In the vicinity of a fire it shall be the duty of the police department to preserve order, protect property, and give any other assistance needed. All firefighters, at fires, shall have full power as a police officer. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 4.0111; Ord. No. 884, 2-27-06) 
Sec. 8-5. - Fire code adopted; bureau of fire prevention; amendments. 
(a)  That certain documents, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the fire marshal, being marked and designated as the "International Fire Code" 2015 edition, and the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) documents, currently adopted editions as listed in this section are hereby adopted as the code of the city for prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire, hazardous materials or explosion providing for the issuance of permits for hazardous uses or operations; reestablishing a bureau of fire prevention and providing officers therefore; and defining their powers and duties all of which are on file in the office of the finance officer are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section. 
(b)  (1)  The currently adopted fire code shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city which is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(2)  The fire marshal in charge of the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department shall be appointed by the city manager. The fire marshal shall be a subordinate of the fire chief. His primary duty shall be to enforce the currently adopted fire code and assume the duties and responsibilities of fire marshal as contained in said code. In addition, the fire marshal shall be the second ranking command officer, after the fire chief, in the Yankton Fire Department and shall assume the duties of the office of fire chief in the absence or disability of the fire chief. He shall devote full time to his duties. 
(c)  (1)  Wherever the word "jurisdiction" is used in the currently adopted fire code, it shall mean the City of Yankton, South Dakota. 
(2)  Wherever the words "chief of the bureau of fire prevention" are used they shall be held to mean "fire marshal." 
(d)  Modifications and amendments. That the following National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) documents referenced in the 2015 International Fire Code shall be adopted by the City of Yankton, South Dakota. 
(1)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 10, "Portable Fire Extinguishers," 2013 edition. 
(2)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 72, "National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code," 2016 edition, is the standard to be used. 
(3)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 407, "Aircraft Fuel Servicing," 2017 edition, is the standard to be used. 
(4)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 52, Vehicular Gaseous Fuel Systems Code," 2016 edition. 
(5)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 86, "Standard for Ovens and Furnaces," 2015 edition. 
(6)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 17, "Standard for Dry Chemical Extinguishing Systems," 2017 edition. 
(7)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 11, "Standard for Low, Medium and Expansion Foam," 2016 edition. 
(8)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 15, "Standard for Water Spray-Fixed Systems for Fire Protection" 2017 edition. 
(9)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 704, "Identification of the Hazards of Materials for Emergency Response," 2017 edition. 
(10)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 385, "Standard for Tank Vehicles for Flammable and Combustible Liquids," 2017 edition. 
(11)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 17A, "Standard for Wet Chemical Extinguishing Systems," 2017 edition. 
(12)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 30, "Flammable and Combustible Liquids Code," 2015 edition. 
(13)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 318, "Standard for Protection of Semiconductor Fabrication Facilities," 2015 edition. 
(14)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 25, "Standard for Inspection, Testing and Maintenance of Water Based Fire Protection Systems," 2017 edition. 
(15)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 12, "Standard for Carbon Dioxide Extinguishing Systems," 2015 edition. 
(16)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 30, "Flammable and Combustible Liquids Code," 2015 edition. 
(17)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 58, "Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code," 2017 edition, is the standard to be used. 
(18)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 13, "Installation of Sprinkler Systems," 2016 edition. 
(19)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 14, "Installation of Standpipe and Hose Systems," 2016 edition. 
(20)  National Fire Protection Association Standard 13R, "Sprinkler Systems in Residential Occupancies Up To and Including Four (4) Stories in Height," 2016 edition. 
(21)  The following sections of 105.6 are adopted as described: 
Sec. 105.6 Permit Required. A permit shall be obtained from the bureau of fire prevention prior to engaging in the following activities, operations, practices or functions: 
105.6.3 Aviation Facilities. (as defined by same title in Section 105. 
105.6.10 Covered and open mall buildings (as defined by same title in Section 105. 
105.6.14 Exhibits and Trades Shows 
105.6.15 Explosives. (as defined by same title in Section 105.) 
105.6.17 Flammable and Combustible Liquids. (as defined by same title in Section 105.) 
105.6.32 Open Burning. (as defined by same title in Section 105.) 
105.6.34 Open Flames and Candles. (as defined by same title in Section 105.) 
(22)  Section 603.8.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Sec. 603.8.1 General. Residential incinerators are not allowed. 
(23)  Section 307.4.1 is amended as follows: A bonfire shall not be conducted within 50 feet of a structure or combustible material unless the fire is contained in a barbecue pit. Conditions which could cause a fire to spread within 50 feet of a structure shall be eliminated prior to ignition. Bonfires shall not be conducted within the city limits except by permit in commercial areas. 
(24)  SECTION 307.4.2 is amended as follows: Recreational Fires- shall not be conducted within 15 feet of a structure or combustible material when conducted in an approved container or approved fire pit not to exceed 3 feet in diameter. Conditions which could cause a fire to spread within 15 of a structure shall be eliminated prior to ignition. 
(25)  SECTION 903.2.8 is amended as follows: An automatic fire sprinkler system shall not be required in residential one and two family dwellings. 
(26)  SECTION 903.2.8 is amended as follows: An automatic fire sprinkler shall be installed throughout any new hotel, motel, and multi-family housing six or more families as specified in Section 903 of the International Building Code 2015 edition and the South Dakota Administrative Rules 61:15:01:19 Automatic Sprinkler System Requirements. 
(27)  The fire code official is authorized to require a registered KNOX brand key box to be installed in an accessible location where immediate access is necessary to verify the existence of a fire or other emergency in all existing and new commercial, multifamily and educational buildings equipped with or required to be equipped with fire protection systems or where security restricts lifesaving or firefighting operations. Fire protection systems shall include fire sprinklers and/or fire alarm systems. 
(a)  Required new construction shall have a lock box installed prior to issuance of an occupancy permit. 
(b)  Key box placement shall be pre-arranged with the fire department as to location on the building. 
(c)  Property owners shall be required to contact the fire department anytime a key change is made on the property affecting fire and life safety operations including but not limited to egress doors, mechanical rooms, alarm pulls and panels, elevators and elevator equipment rooms. 
(d)  The following appendices of the 2015 International Fire Code are adopted and amended: 
From the 2015 International Fire Code: 
Appendix II-H-Site assessments for determining potential fire and explosion risks from underground flammable or combustible liquid tank leaks. 
Appendix B-Fire flow requirements for buildings. 
Appendix C-Fire hydrant locations and distribution. 
Appendix D-Fire Apparatus Access Roads. 
Appendix I--Fire Protection Systems-Non Compliant Conditions. 
(Ord. No. 682, §§ 1-4, 6-28-93; Ord. No. 799, §§ 1-5, 3-13-00; Ord. No. 959, 8-12-13; Ord. No. 1000, 8-28-17) 
Editor's note- Pursuant to the city's direction, §§ 1-4 of Ord. No. 682, adopted June 28, 1993, have been codified herein as § 8-5 at the editor's discretion. Formerly, § 8-5 pertained to ordinances adopting fire prevention code saved from repeal and derived from the 1971 Code. 
Sec. 8-6. - Conflicts between fire prevention code and other laws. 
    In case of conflict between the provisions of the fire prevention code and any other express provision of this Code or other city ordinances in or any state laws, the express provisions of this Code or other city ordinances or state laws shall prevail. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 4.0330) 
Sec. 8-7. - Design, location and use of incinerators. 
    Incinerators may be used in Fire Zone Number One, established in section 7-1, if the incinerators are constructed, located and used as follows: 
(a)  If the incinerator is mounted on the ground, it must be attached by a chain, hook or snap, to a noncombustible post or pipe, or it may be placed on a concrete slab two and one-half (21/2) inches thick, which will insure the burner being used in the specified location. 
(b)  Portable incinerators shall not be larger than twenty-four (24) square inches on the bottom, and not more than thirty-six (36) inches high, so that it will not be too large to empty. The top shall be hinged and self closing, and shall have openings not larger than one (1) inch by one (1) inch; this will insure the lid being in place while burning, and will keep out dogs. Two (2) handles of sufficient size shall be attached to the sides of the incinerator. Holes for draft shall be near the bottom, and not larger than one (1) inch square. 
(c)  Nonportable or fixed types of incinerators may be constructed of noncombustible material, with the base not larger than sixteen (16) square feet in area, and not more than four (4) feet in height. If constructed of brick or tile, the walls shall be eight (8) inches thick and the top shall be solid material without holes, and have a four (4) foot section of six (6) inch smoke pipe to discharge the smoke and fumes, or it may have the same top construction as required in subsection (b). The top of the six (6) inch smoke pipe shall have a wire cover with one (1) inch openings. 
(d)  Portable types of incinerators shall be located at least three (3) feet from a noncombustible building, or ten (10) feet from a combustible building or materials. 
(e)  Nonportable incinerators made of brick or tile shall be at least two (2) feet from a noncombustible building, and five (5) feet from a combustible building or material. 
(f)  All incinerators shall be constructed, located and maintained so as not to endanger the property of others. 
(g)  Only such material as may be readily burned without any objectionable odor or fumes shall be placed in any incinerator. 
(h)  Garbage and similar refuse shall not be placed in any incinerator. 
(i)  Tar, rubber, grease, petroleum products or wastes shall not be placed or deposited in any incinerator. 
(j)  No fires shall be started in any incinerator in Fire Zone Number One between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time during a high wind which may result in property damage to others. 
(k)  All incinerators shall be cleaned out at regular intervals. 
(l)  A written permit to construct, locate and use an incinerator shall be obtained from the chief of the fire department for all incinerators in Fire Zone Number One. 
(m)  Upon a signed complaint, by the owners or occupants of adjacent property, the chief of the fire department shall cause the repair or removal of the offending incinerator. 
Cross reference- Restrictions on burning garbage and refuse, § 10-3. 
Sec. 8-8. - Fireworks regulated. 
(a)  No person shall possess, sell, offer for sale or discharge any pyrotechnics commonly known as fireworks within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of fireworks in a public display provided that any individual, group of individuals, association, organization, partnership or corporation, prior to making such public display of fireworks, shall first secure written permission to do so from the governing board of the city. 
(Ord. No. 526, § 1, 7-26-82) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 526, adopted July 26, 1982, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of § 1 as § 8-8 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Offenses generally, Ch. 16. 
Secs. 8-9-8-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 374, § 1, adopted March 26, 1973, amended this Code by repealing former Art. II, §§ 8-19-8-27. Former Art. II was derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 1.0214, 4.0101, 4.0102, 4.0104-4.0107. 

Sec. 8-19. - Created; composition; policy. 
    There is, hereby, created the Yankton Fire Department which shall consist of one (1) fire chief, one (1) deputy fire chief, one (1) volunteer first assistant fire chief, one (1) volunteer second assistant fire chief and volunteer fire captains and firefighters, the number of which shall be determined from time to time by resolution by the board of city commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00; Ord. No. 884, 2-27-06) 
Sec. 8-20. - Office of fire chief created; duties generally. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of fire chief, who shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(b)  The fire chief, under the supervision of the city manager, shall be responsible for all matters pertaining to the administration and operation of the Yankton Fire Department. He shall be responsible for the discipline, training, records and proper conduct of the fire department and fire personnel, the enforcement of all laws, ordinances, and regulations pertaining thereto, and for the care and maintenance of all property of the department; he shall devote his entire time and attention to the duties of his office and to the improvement of the fire department; he or his designee shall attend all fires and shall direct all firefighting activities at the fire scene; he shall prepare all reports on fire department activities and fire loss as required by the board of city commissioners and the city manager; at the fire scene, he shall have the full power of a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00; Ord. No. 884, 2-27-06) 
Sec. 8-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 682, adopted June 28, 1993, repealed § 8-21 in its entirety. Formerly, § 8-21 pertained to the fire marshal, duties, generally, and derived from § 1, of Ord. No. 374, adopted Mar. 26, 1973. 
Sec. 8-22. - Volunteer fire officers; duties generally; appointments. 
    Those volunteers appointed to the position of fire officers pursuant to section 8-19 shall be, after the fire chief and deputy fire chief, the department's command officers. In the absence or disability of the fire chief and deputy fire chief, the senior fire officer, by rank, shall be the department's ranking command officer and shall have the full authority of the office of fire chief until relieved by the fire chief or deputy fire chief. The fire chief shall appoint the volunteer fire officers for a term of three (3) years; individuals shall be eligible for reappointment. Said appointments shall be consistent with the standard operating guidelines of the Yankton Fire Department and shall be open to all volunteer firefighters. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00; Ord. No. 884, 2-27-06) 
Sec. 8-23. - Volunteer firefighters; duties generally, qualifications, appointment. 
    The volunteer firefighters shall perform, as directed by the department's ranking command officer, firefighting activities. All volunteer members shall have an annual physical examination, which shall be paid by the city. All applications for volunteer firefighters shall be made to the fire chief on forms subscribed by him. After investigation of said applicant, if found satisfactory and a vacancy is available, the fire chief shall appoint the applicant as a probationary firefighter. At the end of six (6) months of service said probationary firefighter shall become a volunteer firefighter if approved by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) majority vote of the total membership of the volunteer fire department. At the end of one (1) year of service the probationary firefighter shall be placed on the active firefighter roster if approved by fire chief and fire marshal. 
    The fire chief shall develop and implement standards of attendance and performance for volunteer firefighters. Failure to maintain said standards shall be cause for termination. Any volunteer firefighter who is terminated may appeal to the membership of the Yankton Volunteer Firefighters in accordance with the by-laws of that organization. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00) 
Sec. 8-24. - Compensation. 
    The fire chief and the fire marshal shall be compensated under the city's pay plan and shall not receive the compensation detailed in this section. All volunteer members shall receive compensation as established from time to time by resolution by the city commission in accordance with the current adopted fiscal year budget. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00) 
Sec. 8-25. - Volunteer firefighter's association; creation, constitution and bylaws. 
    There shall be a volunteer firefighters' association. Membership in said association shall be restricted to present volunteer firefighters of the Yankton Fire Department. The constitution, bylaws and all other matters pertaining to the volunteer firefighter's association shall be determined by a majority vote of the members of said association. The association may, at their option, establish an auxiliary, create active and inactive membership classifications, collect dues, sponsor civic and social functions, promote public awareness of fire hazards and conduct programs and events germane to the fire service. It is the intent of the board of city commissioners that the membership of the volunteer firefighter's association shall manage and determine all association affairs and matters. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00; Ord. No. 884, 2-27-06) 
Sec. 8-26. - Extra territorial fire protection. 
    The Yankton Fire Department may provide fire protection services to the rural areas adjacent to the city. However, the board of city commissioners shall determine, by resolution, the extent of such coverage and may, by contract or other agreement, exercise joint powers with adjacent governmental units for fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00) 
Sec. 8-27. - Mutual aid agreements. 
    The board of city commissioners may, by contract or other agreement, enter into with other local governments or the state or federal governments, joint powers to provide mutual aid in case of major fire or other catastrophes. 
(Ord. No. 374, § 1, 3-26-73; Ord. No. 809, 10-9-00) 
Chapter 9 - FOOD AND FOOD HANDLERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for the inspection of foodstuffs, SDCL 1967, § 9-32-3; authority to provide for the inspection of persons employed in food handling establishments, SDCL 1967, § 9-32-4; authority to regulate the sale of foodstuffs, SDCL 1967, § 9-34-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Street vendors of food. 
(a)  Each person engaging in the business of selling or soliciting the sale of popcorn, peanuts, fruits, soft drinks, ice cream, candy or other edibles from stands, trays, machines, motor or other vehicles, upon the streets or public grounds of the city, shall first obtain a license therefor and pay a license fee of three dollars ($3.00) per day, or an annual license fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(b)  No person shall be granted a license required by subsection (a) unless he shall first have secured and filed with the city auditor the written permission of the occupant of the property abutting upon the street where his business is to be carried on, and the consent in writing of the chief of police. 
(c)  No person to whom a license required by subsection (a) shall be granted shall have an exclusive right to any location in a street or public ground, nor shall any such person be permitted a stationary location in a street or public ground, nor shall any such person be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this section, the judgment of the chief of police, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 6.1801-6.1803) 
Secs. 9-2-9-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESTAURANTS AND OTHER FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-16. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Itinerant restaurant shall mean a restaurant operating for a temporary period of time, not in excess of ninety (90) days, or in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition or similar gathering. 
    Restaurant shall mean restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and all other public eating and drinking establishments, as well as kitchens in which food and drinks are prepared for sale elsewhere to the public. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 5.0801; added by Ord. No. 190, 6-14-54) 
Secs. 9-17-9-23. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 9-24. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant or an itinerant restaurant in the city or within one (1) mile of the boundaries of the city, who does not possess an unrevoked permit issued pursuant to this division. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 5.0802; added by Ord. No. 190, 6-14-54) 
Sec. 9-25. - Persons eligible for permit. 
    Only persons who comply with the requirements of this division shall be entitled to receive and retain a permit required by this division. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 5.0802; added by Ord. No. 190, 6-14-54) 
Sec. 9-26. - State permit prerequisite to city permit. 
    No person shall be issued a permit required by this article unless he/she shall first have obtained a state permit to engage in business as a restaurant or be exempted by the state from the requirement to obtain said permit. 
(Ord. No. 587, § 1, 12-22-86) 
Sec. 9-27. - Application; inspection of premises. 
    An application for a temporary or permanent permit required by this division shall be filed with the finance officer who shall thereupon deliver same to the city manager. The city manager shall forthwith cause an inspection of the establishment of the applicant to be made by the state department of environmental protection and the city fire marshal for the purpose of determining whether or not the applicant has complied with the state health and restaurant regulations and standards and city fire code requirements. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 5.0805, 5.0806; added by Ord. No. 190, 6-14-54; Ord. No. 205, 10-10-55; Ord. No. 391, 12-10-73) 
Sec. 9-28. - Issuance; expiration. 
    If the premises are approved by the state department of environmental protection and the city fire marshal, the city manager shall direct the finance officer to issue the permit. The permit shall expire on the last day of June after the date of issuance and shall not be transferable to another owner or premises. If said permit shall be for an itinerant restaurant it shall be a temporary permit and shall expire on the date shown on the face of the permit and shall not exceed ninety (90) days from the date of issuance. Temporary permits shall not be renewable. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 5.0805, 5.0806; added by Ord. No. 190, 6-14-54; Ord. No. 205, 10-10-55; Ord. No. 391, 12-10-73) 
Sec. 9-29. - Suspension and revocation generally. 
    A permit issued pursuant to this division shall be issued on the condition that the permittee's state permit shall remain in good standing. In the event that the permittee's state permit is suspended or revoked, the permittee's city permit shall be automatically suspended or revoked, without further action by the city. 
Sec. 9-30. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for a permit required by this article shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year or three dollars ($3.00) per day for itinerant restaurants with a maximum fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year. 
(Ord. No. 587, § 2, 12-22-86) 
Secs. 9-31-9-40. - Reserved. 
Chapter 10 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 708, adopted Feb. 27, 1995, repealed §§ 10-1-10-39 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to garbage and trash and derived from §§ 5.0402(b), 5.0302(f), 9.0311, 5.0601, 5.0402, 5.0401(b), (d), (g), (h), 5.0303(b) of Rev. Ords. 1949; Ord. No. 192, adopted Sep. 27, 1954; Ord. No. 214, adopted 8-27-56; § 1 of Ord. No. 324, adopted Nov. 18, 1968; Ord. No. 325, adopted Nov. 12, 1968; § 2 of Ord. No. 639, adopted May 28, 1991; § 5 of Ord. No. 682, adopted June 28, 1993; and § 1 of Ord. No. 689, adopted Feb 14, 1994. Section 1 of said ordinance reenacted §§ 10-1-10-34 as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Solid waste advisory committee, § 2-121 et seq.; requirements for the design, location and use of incinerators, § 8-7. 
State Law reference- Municipal garbage disposal systems, SDCL 1967, § 9-32-11; refuse in public places and streams, SDCL 1967, § 9-32-10. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings indicated, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Commercial collector or contract hauler means any person who hauls or transports for other persons or another person any garbage or receivable solid waste through or upon the streets or alleys of this city for a consideration of a fee. 
    Commercial solid waste means solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, apartments, printing shops, service stations, and other nonmanufacturing, nonhousehold sources. 
    Composting means the biological process by which microorganisms decompose the organic fraction of waste. 
    Garbage means solid and semisolid putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparing, cooking, storing, serving, and consuming of food or of material intended for use as food, and all offal, excluding useful industrial byproducts, from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
    Hazardous waste means solid waste, regulated waste or toxic waste or combination of the foregoing, which because of quantity, concentration, physical, chemical, toxic or infectious characteristics may: 
(1)  Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or 
(2)  Pose as substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated stored, transported, spilled or disposed of or otherwise managed. 
The terms hazardous or toxic waste shall include but not be limited to be pesticide, herbicide and insecticide. Hazardous waste shall include, but not be limited to those wastes identified and listed by the Administrative Rules of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources of the State of South Dakota and the United States Government and 40 C.F.R. Section 261.12-261.33, inclusive, and appendices I, II, III, VII, VIII, IX and X and any amendments thereto prior to the adoption of this chapter. 
    Household waste means solid waste derived from households, including single and multiple residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, ranger stations, crew quarters, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas, but not waste from commercial activities that is generated, stored, or present in a household. Household waste shall include, among other things, kitchen refuse, cans, bottles, paper and other waste material ordinarily originating on household premises and items may which be and are placed in regulation containers as provided in section 10-5. 
    Industrial waste means solid waste generated by manufacturing or industrial processes. 
    Infectious waste means medical waste generated at health care facilities, laboratories or mortuaries that contains any disposable equipment, instruments, utensils, or substances that carry pathogenic organisms from rooms of patients who have been diagnosed or are suspected of having a communicable disease; laboratory wastes such as tissues, blood specimens, excreta, and secretions from patients or laboratory animals; disposable substances that carry pathogenic organisms; and surgical operating room pathologic specimens, substances that carry pathogenic organisms, and other materials from outpatient areas and emergency rooms. 
    Large trees and limbs means and includes trees and limbs in excess of one-quarter (1/4) inch in diameter or in excess of two (2) inches in length. 
    Municipal solid waste landfill means the area provided by the city for the dumping or depositing of receivable solid waste. 
    Receivable solid waste means and includes rubble, yard waste, garbage, or commercial or industrial waste, as herein defined, which are nonhazardous in character and all household waste as herein defined, and large trees and limbs in excess of one-quarter (1/4) inch in diameter and which exceed two (2) inches in length. 
    Rubble means stone, brick, concrete, or similar inorganic material. 
    Tax-exempt user means any legal entity, including any public agency in possession or control of any lot, tract or parcel of real property which, by the laws of this state, is exempt from real property taxes levied by the city on real property on or from which receivable solid waste is collected or taken for deposit at the municipal landfill, whether directly by such tax-exempt user or indirectly by commercial collector or contract hauler. 
    Taxpayer user means any person or other legal entity in possession or control of any lot, tract or parcel of real property which is subject to real property taxes levied by the city against real property on or from which receivable solid waste is collected or taken for deposit at the municipal landfill, whether directly by such taxpayer user or indirectly by commercial garbage collector or contract garbage hauler. 
    Yard waste means leaves, grass clippings, chip brush, garden waste, and bush trimmings, and small tree trimmings not to exceed one-quarter (1/4) inch in diameter or two (2) inches in length which can be stored in a thirty-three-gallon plastic bag or container. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-2. - Containers required; specifications. 
    The occupant of every dwelling, house or apartment and of every place of business and building shall provide a suitable watertight metallic or plastic can or container which shall not exceed thirty-three (33) gallons in capacity, in which the occupants shall cause to be deposited receivable solid waste accumulating upon the premises, which containers shall be kept in a location accessible to the collector. If the premises is serviced by a commercial hauler with a mechanical lift, larger containers shall be permissible. Containers shall not be removed except when necessary. The vicinity of containers shall be kept free from garbage and other organic matter that attracts flies. 
    All yard waste as defined in section 10-1 presented for disposal or composting at the landfill site shall be presented separate from other recyclable solid waste and shall be placed in a container, can or bag, not to exceed thirty-three (33) gallons in capacity. The containers shall be kept at an area accessible to the collector and shall be stored in such manner as to allow the contents of each container to be emptied directly into the collector's truck or vehicle. 
    All large trees and limbs defined in section 10-1 shall be presented separate from other receivable solid waste for disposal at the landfill. All large trees and limbs shall be disposed of in a reasonable time after accumulation by hauling to landfill site, chipping and depositing as yard waste, or contracting with a commercial hauler. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-3. - Receivable solid waste on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit receivable solid waste or other kinds of waste as set forth and defined in section 10-1 on any private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not; except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection awaiting prompt disposal in such a manner that such receivable solid waste will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-4. - Owner to maintain premises free of commercial waste, household waste, garbage, infectious waste, industrial waste, rubble or yard waste. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of commercial waste, household waste, garbage, infectious waste, industrial waste, rubble or yard waste except that used for composting as defined in section 10-1; however, this section shall not prohibit the storage or receivable solid waste as defined in section 10-1 in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-5. - Receivable solid waste on vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit receivable solid waste as defined in section 10-1 on any open or vacant property within the city, whether owned by such person or not. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-6. - Removal of receivable solid waste. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall cause the receivable solid waste as defined in section 10-1 collected and stored in authorized receptacles to be removed from the property within seven (7) days and disposed of at the municipal landfill. All yard waste shall be stored in separate receptacles and shall contain no other receivable solid waste. If the owner or person in control of any private property shall fail to do so, the city manager or his designee shall notify the owner or person in control of the property to remove the material as defined in section 10-1 within three (3) days. Failure to do so will result in the imposition of the penalty set forth in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-7. - Vehicle loads causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any vehicle carrying any material as defined in section 10-1 within the city or to the municipal landfill unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any such load or portion of such load from being blown or deposited upon any street, highway or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-8. - Violation of article declared a public nuisance; penalty generally. 
    Each accumulation of garbage or rubbish which is deposited, kept, burned, or transported any place in the city in violation of the provision of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and any person who maintains or permits the maintenance of such nuisance shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-9. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COLLECTIONS 

Sec. 10-10. - City collection of solid waste. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city manager to employ a sufficient force of men, and vehicles to keep all private premises in the city free from garbage, rubbish, ashes, tin cans, or other refuse. 
(b)  The city shall provide the collection service for solid waste from all residential premises in the city. Commercial solid waste may be collected by a commercial collector or contract hauler. 
(c)  Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit any person from removing commercial solid waste from business establishments, as defined in this article, of the city to the city landfill or municipal solid waste transfer station, his own garbage, rubbish, ashes, tin cans, or other refuse, paper, wood, cardboard or other similar materials. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-11. - Garbage and rubbish not to be placed at any location except as provided in this article. 
    It shall be unlawful to place or leave any garbage, rubbish, ashes, tin cans or other refuse at any other place than that authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-12. - Preparation of garbage and refuse for collection. 
(a)  Each person accumulating garbage or refuse must place it in a suitable watertight container with a tightly fitting cover and with handles, which container shall not be in excess of thirty-three-gallon capacity. 
(b)  A person having placed garbage and refuse in a container shall place the garbage container on private property as near the line of the abutting alley as is possible; and if the private property does not abut on an alley, the container shall be placed where it is most convenient for the city garbage collector to empty it; however, if there is any dispute as to what place on the property is most convenient, the city manager has full power to settle such dispute and order the garbage container to be placed where he deems it most convenient for the garbage collector to empty the container. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to put any liquid of any kind in a garbage container or to place garbage herein unless the garbage is completely wrapped in paper or enclosed in paper sacks. 
(d)  Two (2) containers shall be allowed in the basic pickup service. Additional containers shall be collected at an additional charge. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place yard waste which includes grass clippings, small prunings and leaves in any garbage container. Yard waste will not be collected by the city garbage collector with the normal garbage collection service provided by the city. Yard waste must be kept separate and may be picked up by the city as a separate service under the rules and regulations provided by that service. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-13. - Collection charges generally. 
    The charges for collection by the city of garbage and refuse shall be as established from time to time by the board of commissioners by resolution and shall be on file in the office of the city auditor. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-14. - Billing, payment and delinquency of collection charges. 
(a)  The person residing on the premises served pursuant to this article shall be primarily liable for the payment of the collection charges established in this article, and the owner of the real estate shall be secondarily liable. 
(b)  To facilitate collection [of] the charges imposed by this article, the person in whose name the water service is charged shall be billed therefor and shall pay it with the water bill if a water bill is sent; otherwise, the charge shall be billed as a separate billing, and payment shall be made at the office of the city finance officer. 
(c)  Payment of charges imposed by this article shall become delinquent twenty (20) days after the end of the period in which the service was rendered and billed, and if an account is not paid before it becomes delinquent, the city may discontinue service rendered pursuant to this article until the account has been paid in full. If the account shall not be paid when delinquent, the city finance officer shall certify the amount of delinquency, together with a description of the property and the name of the owner as it appears from the records, in duplicate, to the county auditor in the same manner as provided by law for special assessments. 
(d)  This section shall apply to all garbage collection charges, whether incurred before or after the date of adoption of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Secs. 10-15-10-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL COLLECTION OF SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 10-20. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for contract haulers to use the city streets without a valid city license. 
    It shall be unlawful for contract or commercial haulers to use the streets for the collection, removal or disposal of any receivable solid waste and yard waste without first having obtained a license to perform such services from the finance officer. As a condition to the granting of any said license, all commercial haulers shall agree to abide by all city ordinances or landfill regulations involving the collection or depositing of any receivable solid waste and yard waste. In the event any commercial garbage hauler fails to abide by these said ordinances or regulations the City of Yankton reserves the right to terminate said license. 
    This requirement does not apply to building contractors removing and disposing of receivable solid waste incidental to a construction contract, nor to any firm or individual who, for a fee engages in the removal of receivable solid waste for disposal for fewer than two (2) days in any calendar year. 
    The fee for a license as a commercial hauler shall be as set by the city commission by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-21. - Same application; plate to be displayed. 
    Application for license shall be filed at the office of the finance officer five (5) days prior to any consideration and approval by the city commission. All licenses expire December 31 in the year they are issued. The license plate or placard issued shall be displayed on each such vehicle at all times. 
    Each license applicant shall, at the time of the submission of the license application, provide written verification to the finance officer that the applicant met the financial liability requirement of state law for liability insurance coverage for the vehicles used in the collector or haulers business. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-22. - Submission of rates and schedules with license applications. 
    Each applicant for a license required by this article shall submit with his application a schedule of charges, a schedule of collection time, and a list of manpower to be used in connection with his license. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-23. - Transferability of license. 
    A license issued pursuant to this article shall be nonrefundable and nontransferable from person to person; however, a license issued pursuant to this article may be transferred from one vehicle to another upon application, and inspection as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-24. - Vehicles for collection. 
    Licensed collectors of garbage and/or commercial solid waste and industrial waste shall provide themselves with suitable vehicles which shall be all metal, watertight as specified by manufacturer, and be of the packer type. Such vehicles shall be thoroughly washed at such times, not to exceed once each day, as may be directed by the supervising department or as may be necessary to keep vehicles in a proper sanitary condition when conveying and garbage shall be so loaded and unloaded that the contents shall not fall or spill upon the ground. No article or item shall be carried on such vehicles so as to drag upon the street. 
    Licensed haulers of yard waste and large trees and limbs shall provide themselves with suitable vehicles which, when transporting or loading, the contents shall not spill upon the ground. No articles or items shall be carried on such vehicles so as to drag upon the streets. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-25. - Vehicles and equipment; inspections. 
(a)  All equipment used for the collection and removal of garbage, rubbish, ashes, tin cans or other refuse, paper, wood, cardboard or other similar matter shall be so constructed and enclosed so as to prevent loss or droppage during loading and transporting of the refuse. 
(b)  Before a license to operate as a commercial collector shall be issued, the commercial collector shall procure liability and indemnity insurance covering his operations as a commercial collector. The policies of insurance shall be conditioned to pay any final judgment rendered against the commercial collector arising out of any action for death of or injury to any passenger, or loss or damage to property of a passenger in case of a carrier or passenger, and for loss or damage to property in case of a carrier of property, and shall be further conditioned to pay any final judgment rendered against the commercial collector arising out of any action for the death of or injury to any person other than a passenger, or loss or damage to any property not in transit. In the event of cancellation of such insurance policy, notice thereof shall be given by the insurer to the city finance officer. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of each commercial collector to maintain in good mechanical condition for safe operation each motor vehicle operated by it. The motor vehicles shall be subject to inspection by the police department of the city, and if any mechanical defect is found by the police department sufficient to endanger the safe operation of the vehicle, the commercial collector shall not operate the vehicle until the defect is remedied. 
(d)  Failure to maintain a vehicle subject to this section in the proper condition shall be cause for revoking the license by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-26. - Commercial collection of solid waste. 
    Commercial collectors shall be under no obligation to remove receivable solid waste unless the payments for the removal of such receivable solid waste, as provided by arrangement with the customer, shall have been made. 
    Every licensed commercial collector or hauler may, in addition to the regular collection, collect yard waste. Every licensed commercial collector must inspect each container of residential deposit of yard waste. This inspection shall be made prior to the collector or hauler emptying or debagging the container and depositing the yard waste in the collector's vehicles for transportation to the landfill; and except as otherwise provided by section 10-3. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 2-27-95) 
Sec. 10-27. - Duty of commercial collectors. 
    Licensed collectors or haulers shall obey all the ordinances and all the rules and regulations of the City of Yankton or its designated officer and report to the supervising department any violation of this chapter which may come to their notice. All licensed collectors or haulers may provide a subscription service for each customer. All charges for the collection of yard waste shall be made separate and distinct from any basic charges for all other collection services of receivable solid waste.
