When an inspection and test shall have been made by the electrical inspector and it shall be found that any equipment or apparatus coming within the terms of this section is being so operated or is so constructed that it interferes with radio reception, the person responsible for the operation of the equipment or apparatus shall be notified in writing by the electrical inspector to discontinue the use of the equipment or apparatus, or to make additions, repairs or modifications thereof, specifying the same, in order that the equipment or apparatus may be operated in a manner complying with the provisions of this section. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0701) 
State Law reference- Authority of the city to prevent interference with radio reception, SDCL 1967, § 9-29-15. 
Sec. 16-5. - Barbed wire fences. 
(a)  Barbed wire fences prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any fence upon any lot, part of lot, or parcel of ground in the city next to or along any street, alley, or adjoining lot, which fence is composed, in whole or in part, of barbed wire. 
(b)  Abatement of existing fences. It shall be the duty of the city manager to notify any person now having or maintaining any barbed wire fence prohibited by subsection (a) to remove the barbed wire therefrom within thirty (30) days after the notice. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0702) 
Sec. 16-6. - Entering or leaving Missouri River. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or leave the Missouri River from or on any property or structure owned or controlled by the City of Yankton for the purpose of wading or swimming. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 7-23-90; Ord. No. 904, 7-9-07) 
Sec. 16-7. - Fleeing from law enforcement officers prohibited; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully fail or refuse to stop or to otherwise flee when given a visual or audible signal to stop by a law enforcement officer. 
(b)  The signal given by the law enforcement officer may be by hand, voice, emergency light, loud speaker or siren. 
(c)  The law enforcement officer giving such signal shall either be clothed in such a manner as to identify said officer as a law enforcement officer, or by announcing themselves and displaying identification (such as a badge identifying themselves as a law enforcement officer) or shall be in a law enforcement vehicle identifiable as a law enforcement vehicle by it's markings or equipment customarily used in law enforcement. 
(d)  The penalty for a violation of this ordinance shall be the same as set forth in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 829, §§ 1-4, 4-22-02) 
Secs. 16-8-16-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit disorders and disturbances, SDCL 1967, § 9-29-3. 

Sec. 16-17. - Public intoxication. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be or remain in a state of intoxication, drunkenness, or under the influence of intoxicating liquor in any public place. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0408) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit public intoxication, SDCL 1967, § 9-29-3. 
Sec. 16-18. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall disturb the peace through oral communications which amount to fighting words or through conduct which creates unreasonable noise. "Fighting words" are oral communications which tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace. Examples of conduct creating unreasonable noise are loud stereos, cars or dogs. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0404; Ord. No. 748, § 1, 3-10-97) 
State Law reference- Disturbing the peace, SDCL 1967, § 22-13-1. 
Sec. 16-19. - Assault and battery. 
    No person shall attempt or offer with force or violence to do corporal hurt to the person of another, nor shall any person use force or violence upon the person of another except that it be a case of justifiable assault or battery as defined by the laws of the state. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0401) 
State Law reference- Assault and battery defined, SDCL 1967, § 22-18-1. 
Sec. 16-20. - Disturbing public meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously disturb or in any manner interfere with any lawful meeting or assemblage of persons in the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0403) 
State Law reference- Disturbing lawful assemblies, SDCL 1967, § 22-13-1. 
Sec. 16-21. - Carrying concealed weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry concealed upon his person any description of a firearm, being loaded or partly loaded, or slingshot, brass knuckles or any other weapon which when used is likely to produce death or great bodily harm except officers of the law in the execution of duty. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0402) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, SDCL 1967, §§ 22-14-1, 22-14-4. 
Sec. 16-22. - Drawing dangerous weapon on another. 
    No person except a law enforcement officer in the discharge of his duty shall draw any description of firearm, knife or other deadly or dangerous weapon upon another person. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0402) 
State Law reference- Assault with dangerous weapon without intent to kill, SDCL 1967, § 22-18-11. 
Sec. 16-23. - Discharge of weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or shoot off any description of firearm, or use for any purpose any slingshot or other device for throwing or forcing through the air missiles or projectiles of any character; however, this section shall not apply to any law enforcement officer in the discharge of his duty, or to any persons pre-authorized by the city manager for specific dates, times and places. 
    The discharge of arrows shall be permitted only at a temporary or conditional use archery range or an established archery range. An established archery range is defined as an archery range that: 
(a)  meets all the safety requirements of the National Field Archery Association of the United States, Inc. (NFAA); 
(b)  has been inspected by a certified NFAA archery range inspector; 
(c)  is a certified affiliate archery range of the NFAA; and 
(d)  is approved by the board of city commissioners. 
    The requirement that an established archery range be a certified affiliate archery range of the NFAA shall not apply to any archery range approved by the board of city commissioners prior to May 1, 2015. 
    A temporary or conditional use archery range is defined as an archery range that: 
(a)  meets all the safety requirements of the NFAA; 
(b)  is operated or overseen by NFAA staff or an NFAA certified archery coach; and 
(c)  is not open to the general public, or is in use for a limited period of no longer than seventy-two (72) hours. 
    The discharge of shotguns used on skeet shooting or shot gunning facilities shall also be permitted provided that said facility is permitted in the zoning district and has been approved by the board of city commissioners under the conditional uses and structures provision of the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0402; Ord. No. 597, § 1, 6-8-87; Ord. No. 900, 5-29-07; Ord. No. 910, 4-28-08; Ord. No. 972, 2-23-15) 
State Law reference- Discharge of weapon in public place, SDCL 1967, § 22-14-2. 
Sec. 16-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 750, adopted March 10, 1997, repealed § 16-24 in its entirety. Formerly, § 16-24 pertained to profanity and vulgar language and derived from § 7.0405 of the 1949 Revised Ordinances. 
Sec. 16-25. - Closing hours for Riverside Park and other city-owned property located on the Missouri River. 
    Riverside Park and all other city-owned property located adjacent to the Missouri River shall be closed to the public each day from 1:00 a.m. until 5:00 a.m., unless written permission is given to enter the area by the city manager. The closing hours contained in this section shall not apply to employees of the city who are engaged in active employment with the city, or to individuals who are launching or recovering a boat in the boat launching area of Riverside Park. 
(Ord. No. 648, § 1, 9-23-91) 
Sec. 16-26. - Discharge of noise by radio or stereo from a motor vehicle. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle in a public place or on any public street, highway or alley from which said motor vehicle a stereo, tape player, compact disc player, radio or any other sound amplification device can be heard a distance of fifty (50) feet or more. 
    The provisions of this section may be enforced following personal observance and/or hearing of any police officer or upon receipt of a complaint made or filed with the police department by the person disturbed by such noise disturbance. The city manager or his designee may grant a temporary variance to this section to facilitate special events. The police are specifically authorized to revoke the granted variance if the applicant shall fail to meet any of the limitations or conditions imposed when the variance was granted and/or other circumstances occurring subsequent to the granting of the variance requiring such revocation. 
(Ord. No. 805, 8-28-00) 
Secs. 16-27-16-36. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-51. - Lewdness. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any public place in the city in a state of nudity, or to indulge in any indecent, lewd or lascivious conduct or behavior, or to commit any indecent, wanton, or filthy act or behavior, or to expose the private parts of his person in any place where other persons may be offended by such act. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0406) 
Cross reference- Indecent exposure or simulation thereof prohibited on premises licensed for alcoholic beverages, § 3-8. 
State Law reference- Indecent exposure, SDCL 1967, § 22-24-1. 
Sec. 16-52. - Obscenity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, sell, offer for sale, or to distribute or dispose of in any manner in the city any obscene book, picture, print or other thing; or to exhibit any obscene or lewd play, show or other representation. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 7.0407) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit the sale or exhibition of obscene or immoral publications, prints, films, exhibitions or illustrations, SDCL 1967, § 9-29-9; state obscenity law not to affect power of municipalities, SDCL 1967, § 22-24-25.

Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND ZONING GENERALLY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 27. 
State Law reference- Municipal planning and zoning, SDCL 1967, § 11-4-1, et seq.; comprehensive city planning, SDCL 1967, § 11-6-1, et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Petition required to initiate rezone. 
(a)  Prior to the introduction of any ordinance proposing changes in the zoning ordinance, there shall first be filed with the city finance officer the written consent of forty (40) per cent of the owners of equity in the lots included in any proposed district and the lands within one hundred fifty (150) feet from any part of such proposed district measured by excluding streets and alleys. 
(b)  A corporation shall be construed to be a sole owner; and when parcels of land are in the name of more than one (1) person, ownership representation shall be in proportion to the number of signers who join in the petition in relation to the number of owners. 
(c)  Proposed changes introduced by the city, a municipal corporation and properties within one (1) year after annexation shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 446, 7-25-77) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 446, adopted July 25, 1977, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion as § 17-1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, SDCL 1967, § 11-4-9. 
Sec. 17-2. - Landscaping standards. 
(a)  It is hereby established that property owners within the city may landscape city right-of-way abutting their property with rocks or other similar materials as long as such materials are displayed in a safe and sanitary manner, and do not obstruct the free use of the right-of-way or the view of drivers of vehicles at any intersection. 
(b)  However, it shall be the property owner's responsibility to remove such landscaping in the event of any interference created by such landscaping due to city or utility excavations or work. The city shall be responsible for replacing excavated areas with grass only. 
(Ord. No. 483, 7-24-78) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 483, adopted July 24, 1978, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion as § 17-2 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 17-3-17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY PLAN COMMISSION 

Sec. 17-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a city plan commission. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 1.0501; Ord. No. 278, 12-14-64) 
Sec. 17-17. - Composition; appointment and qualifications of members. 
    The city plan commission shall consist of nine (9) members appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the board of commissioners. The members of the city plan commission shall be residents of the city, qualified by knowledge and experience to act in the matters pertaining to the development and administration of a civic plan, who shall not hold any elective office in the municipal government. 
(Ord. No. 243, § A, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- Composition and appointment of members of city planning commission, SDCL 1967, § 11-6-2. 
Sec. 17-18. - Terms of members; limit on consecutive terms. 
    The term of each member of the city plan commission appointed after July 1, 1995 shall be for three (3) years, except that the terms of members first appointed after July 1, 1995 and first appointed after July 1, 1997 shall be staggered so that, after July 1, 1997, three (3) members are to be appointed in each year. 
(Ord. No. 713, § 1, 6-26-95; Ord. No. 915, § 1, 10-13-08) 
State Law reference- Terms of planning commission members, SDCL 1967, § 11-6-4. 
Sec. 17-19. - Filling vacancies. 
    Any vacancy in the membership of the city plan commission may be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor in the same manner as for an initial appointment. 
(Ord. No. 243, § B, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-4. 
Sec. 17-20. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor, with confirmation of the board of commissioners, shall, after public hearing, have authority to remove any member for cause, when the cause shall be stated in writing and made a part of the record of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 243, § B, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-4. 
Sec. 17-21. - Compensation of members. 
    All members of the city plan commission shall serve as such without compensation, except for actual expenses which shall be subject to the approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 243, § C, 7-24-61) 
Sec. 17-22. - Organization. 
    Upon appointment, the city plan commission shall be called together by the mayor and shall organize by choosing from its members a chairman and a vice-chairman for a term of one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection, and may fill such other of its offices as it may create in a manner prescribed by its rules. Any qualified full-time city employee selected by the city manager shall act as secretary of the city plan commission, but shall not be a member thereof. Annually, in the month of June, the city plan commission shall choose its officers. 
(Ord. No. 243, § D, 7-24-61; Ord. No. 1004, § 1, 3-12-18) 
State Law reference- Organization of planning commission, SDCL 1967, § 11-6-5. 
Sec. 17-23. - Meetings. 
    The city plan commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting each month, and may hold such additional or special meetings as it, in its discretion, may deem necessary. However, the chairman of the plan commission may determine that any monthly meeting is not necessary if there are no requests for action to be considered. 
(Ord. No. 243, § E, 7-24-61; Ord. No. 1004, § 1, 3-12-18) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-6. 
Sec. 17-24. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
    The city plan commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business. 
(Ord. No. 243, § E, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-6. 
Sec. 17-25. - Record of proceedings. 
    The city plan commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record, and it shall cause its secretary to forward a copy of any of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations to the board of commissioners not later than the first meeting of the month following action by the city plan commission. 
(Ord. No. 243, § E, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-6. 
Sec. 17-26. - Utilization of professional services. 
    The city plan commission may utilize and have made available to it the advice and services of city engineers, architects or other consultants. 
(Ord. No. 243, § E, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-7. 
Sec. 17-27. - Annual report. 
    The city plan commission shall each year on or about the first of May make a report to the board of commissioners of its proceedings, which report shall include a statement of any receipts or disbursements made by the city plan commission during the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 243, § F, 7-24-61) 
Sec. 17-28. - Promulgation of master plan. 
    It shall be a duty and function of the city plan commission to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside of the boundary and within its planning jurisdiction, which, in the city plan commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the city. The master plan with accompanying maps, charts and directive or explanatory matter shall show the city plan commission's recommendations for the physical development, and it may include, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, bridges, parks, parkways, waterways, waterfront developments, playgrounds, airports, and other public grounds and, in order to effect a master plan, the city plan commission shall make careful and comprehensive studies of present conditions and future growth of the city, and with due regard to its relation to the neighboring territory. The master plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted, and harmonious development of the city which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity, and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(Ord. No. 243, § G, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-16-14. 
Sec. 17-29. - Adoption of master plan. 
(a)  The city plan commission may adopt a master plan as a whole by a single resolution, or, as the work of making the whole master plan progresses, may from time to time adopt a part or parts thereof, any such part to correspond generally with one (1) or more of the functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the plan. 
(b)  Before adoption of the master plan or part thereof, the city plan commission shall hold at least one (1) public hearing, notice of the time and place of which shall be given at least fifteen (15) days in advance of publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the community. 
(c)  The adoption of the master plan or any part, amendment or additions, shall be by resolution carried by the affirmative votes of not less than a majority of all the members of the city plan commission. The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps, descriptive matter and other matters intended by the city plan commission to form the whole or part of the master plan, and the action taken shall be recorded on the adopted master plan or part thereof by the identifying signature of the chairman and the secretary of the city plan commission, and a copy of the plan or part thereof shell be certified to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 243, § H, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, §§ 11-6-16-11-6-18. 
Sec. 17-30. - City plan commission approval required for improvements in areas covered by the master plan. 
    Upon the establishment of a master plan by the city plan commission, no street, park, or other public way, ground, place, or space; no public building or structure; no public utility, whether publicly or privately owned, if covered by the master plan or any adopted part thereof, shall be constructed or authorized in the city or within three (3) miles of its corporate limits until and unless the location and extent thereof shall have been submitted to and approved by the city plan commission; in case of disapproval, the city plan commission shall indicate its reasons of disapproval to the board of commissioners, which by a vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of its entire membership, shall have the power to overrule such disapproval. Upon the adoption of a master plan of the city, or any part thereof, the acceptance, widening, removal, extension, relocation, narrowing, vacation, abandonment, change of use, acquisition of land for any street or other public way, ground, place, property, or structure shall be subject to similar submission and approval by the city plan commission, and the failure to approve by the city plan commission may be similarly overruled. 
(Ord. No. 243, § M, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, §§ 11-6-19, 11-6-20. 
Sec. 17-31. - To act as zoning commission. 
    The plan commission shall have all powers of a zoning commission and shall be the zoning commission of the city and shall perform all the duties of the zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 243, § I, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- City plan commission acting as zoning commission, SDCL 1967, § 11-4-11. 
Sec. 17-32. - Recommendations as to public improvement programs. 
    The city plan commission may recommend to the board of commissioners or other officials of the city, programs for public improvement. 
(Ord. No. 243, § I, 7-24-61) 
Sec. 17-33. - Additional powers generally. 
    The city plan commission, its members and employees, in the performance of its functions, may enter upon any land, make examinations and surveys, and place and maintain necessary marks and monuments thereon. In general, the city plan commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to fulfill and perform its functions and, in general, to effect good city planning. 
(Ord. No. 243, § I, 7-24-61) 
Sec. 17-34. - Subdivisions generally; platting jurisdiction. 
    From and after the time the city plan commission shall have adopted a master plan, which includes at least a major street plan, or shall have progressed in its master planning to the stage of the making and adoption of a major street plan, and shall have filed a certified copy of the major street plan in the office of the register of deeds, no plat of a subdivision of land lying within the city or of land within three (3) miles of its corporate limits, shall be filed or recorded until it shall have been submitted to and a report and recommendations thereon made by the city plan commission to the board of commissioners, and the board of commissioners has approved the plat. 
(Ord. No. 243, § J, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-26. 
Sec. 17-35. - Approval of plats. 
(a)  All plans, or replats of subdivisions of resubdivisions of land embraced in the city, or adjacent thereto, laid out in lots or plats with the streets, alleys, or other portions of the same intended to be dedicated to the public in the city, shall first be submitted to the city plan commission and its recommendation obtained before approval by the board of commissioners, irrespective of whether a master plan shall have been perfected. After the establishment of any master plan, as required by law, any plat subject to this section embraced within the municipality, or of land within three (3) miles of its corporate limits and not located in any other municipality, shall be deemed subject to such approval. 
(b)  All plats should be approved or disapproved pursuant to subsection (a) within sixty (60) days after their submission; otherwise, such plats shall be deemed to have been approved and a certificate to that effect shall be issued by the board of commissioners on demand. However, the applicant for the approval may waive this requirement and consent to the extension of such period. The ground of the disapproval of any plat shall be stated upon the records of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 243, § K, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- Approval of subdivision plats, SDCL 1967, § 11-6-31, et seq. 
Sec. 17-36. - Approval of plat not to constitute acceptance. 
    The approval of a plat by the city plan commission or by the board of commissioners shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the city or public of the dedication of any street or other ground shown on the plat. 
(Ord. No. 243, § L, 7-24-61) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, see SDCL 1967, § 11-6-33. 
ARTICLE III. - SUBDIVISIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Subdivision signs, § 201/2-2(b); zoning, Ch. 27. 

Sec. 17-37. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as "The Land Subdivision Ordinance of the City of Yankton, South Dakota." 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-38. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the harmonious development of the city and its environs; for the coordination of streets within subdivisions with other existing or planned streets or with other features of the comprehensive plan of the municipality; for adequate open spaces for traffic, recreation, light and air; for adequate water and sanitation facilities, drainage and flood control; and for a distribution of population and traffic which will tend to create conditions favorable to health, safety, convenience or property. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-39. - General. 
(1)  All property not subdivided into lots, blocks and streets within the corporate limits or jurisdiction of the city shall hereinafter be laid out in accordance with these regulations; and no other subdivision will be recognized by the city. This shall also include any resubdivision of platted lands. 
(2)  The city hereby defines its policy to be that the city will withhold improvements of any nature whatsoever, including the maintenance of streets, and furnishing of sewage facilities and water service and building permits from all additions until the subdivision plat has been approved by the city commission. No improvements shall be initiated nor any contracts executed until this approval has been given. 
(3)  Land to be subdivided shall be of such character that it can be used safely for building purposes without danger to health or peril from fire, flood or other menace; and the land shall not be subdivided until public facilities and improvements exist or proper provision has been made for drainage, water, sewage and street improvements. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-40. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of interpreting this article, certain words used herein are defined as follows: 
(1)  Alley. The word "alley" shall mean a minor way used primarily for affording a secondary means of access to abutting properties. 
(2)  City. The word "city" shall mean the City of Yankton, South Dakota, together with all its governing and operating bodies. 
(3)  City commission. The term "commission" or "city commission" shall mean the duly elected governing body of the municipality. 
(4)  City engineer. Any office referred to in this article by title, e.g. "city engineer," shall mean the person so retained in the position by the city, or his duly authorized representative. 
(5)  Collector street. The term "collector street" shall mean a street which is continuous through several residential districts and is intended as a connecting street between residential districts and arteries, highways or business districts. 
(6)  County. The word "county" shall mean Yankton County, South Dakota, together with all its governing and operating bodies. 
(7)  Cul-de-sac. The "cul-de-sac" shall mean a short minor street having but one (1) vehicular access to another street and terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
(8)  Dead-end street. The term "dead-end street" shall mean a street, other than a cul-de-sac, with only one (1) outlet and no turnaround. 
(9)  Final plat. The term "final plat" shall mean any plat of any lot, tract or parcel of land which meets the requirements of these regulations and is in form to be recorded by the county register of deeds. 
(10)  Local street. The term "local street" shall mean a street which is intended primarily to serve traffic within a neighborhood or limited residential district, and which is used primarily for access to abutting properties. 
(11)  Lot. The word "lot" shall mean a parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development, whether immediate or future. 
(12)  Master plan. The term "master plan" shall mean the comprehensive plan or general plan of the city and adjoining areas as adopted by the city commission and the city planning and zoning commission, including all its revisions. This plan indicates the general location recommended for various land uses, transportation routes, public and private buildings, streets, parks and other public and private developments and improvements. 
(13)  Major street. The term "major street" shall mean principal traffic thoroughfares more or less continuous across the city which are intended to connect remote parts of the city, or areas adjacent thereto, and act as principal connecting streets with state and federal highways. 
(14)  Performance bond. A bond with such surety as may be required by the city commission made out to the city in an amount equal to the full cost of all or part of the improvements which are required by this regulation, said cost being estimated by the city engineer and said bond being legally sufficient to secure to the city that the improvements will be constructed in accordance with these regulations. 
(15)  Planning commission. The term "planning commission" or "zoning commission" shall mean the official city planning and zoning commission of the city, as appointed by the city commission. 
(16)  Preliminary plat. The term "preliminary plat" shall mean a tentative plan of a proposed division of land for review and study by the city. 
(17)  Resubdivision. The word "resubdivision" shall mean the resubdivision of any part of all or any block or blocks of a previously platted subdivision, addition, lot or tract. 
(18)  Street. The word "street" means a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place or however otherwise designated. 
(19)  Shall. The word "shall" will be interpreted in its mandatory sense. 
(20)  Street width. The word "shall" will be interpreted in its mandatory sense. 
(21)  Street width. The word "street width" shall mean the shortest distance between the lines which delineate the right-of-way of a street. 
(22)  Subdivision. The word "subdivision" or "addition" shall mean any division of any lot, tract or parcel of land into two (2) or more lots or sites for the purpose, whether immediate or future, for sale or of building development, or if a new street is involved any division of a parcel of land or replatting of land, lots or tracts, whether by metes and bounds or other recorded instrument. 
(23)  Subdivider. The word "subdivider" shall mean a person, firm or corporation undertaking the subdivision or resubdivision of a tract of land for the purpose of laying out a platted addition or subdivision of land. 
(24)  Subdivision owner. The term "subdivision owner" shall mean legal title or sufficient proprietary (equitable) interest in the land sought to be subdivided. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 17-41. - Application required. 
    Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed to be made, the owner of such subdivision shall apply in writing for approval of the proposed subdivision in accordance with the following procedures. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-42. - Procedures. 
(1)  Preapplication Conference. Prior to the filing of a plat, the subdivider shall consult with the city engineer or his authorized representative concerning the ultimate land use of the proposed development, the suitability of the location of the proposed subdivision, the most advantageous subdivision plan, the arrangement of streets, alleys, lots, the layout of utility lines, the availability of service from trunk mains for sewer and water, and compliance with the laws and regulations of the city. After this conference, the subdivider shall prepare the preliminary site plan. 
(2)  Preliminary Site Plan. Prior to preparing the final plat, the subdivider must present to the city engineer four (4) copies of a preliminary site plan of the proposed subdivision including a drawn-to-scale topographic map with a minimum of two-foot contour intervals covering the proposed area to be subdivided. Such preliminary site plan shall show the layout and dimensions of all proposed lots, and streets, alleys or grounds dedicated for public use. Copies of the preliminary site plan will be forwarded to all applicable utility companies by the engineer for their review of required easements prior to city approval of the preliminary site plan. 
(3)  In instances where developments are proposed in B-Y Water District's service area, the subdivider shall also consult with and obtain approval from B-Y Water District's Manager or authorized representatives concerning the design of, and method by which water service shall be provided to the subdivision. The design and specification of the distribution system shall meet B-Y Water District's and city specifications. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78; Ord. No. 976, § 1, 5-26-15) 
Sec. 17-43. - Optional preliminary plat approval. 
    An application may be made for the tentative approval of a preliminary plat by filing five (5) prints with the city engineering department at least seven (7) days prior to the meeting of the planning commission. This preliminary plat procedure is voluntary and shall not be required of any plat. Such plat shall contain: 
(1)  The proposed name of the subdivision and, if different, the title under which the subdivision is to be recorded. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner and the name and address of the engineer preparing the plan. 
(3)  The date, scale and north point. 
(4)  The legal description of the area being platted. 
(5)  The boundary line (accurate in scale), the dimensions and location of the property to be platted and the location of section lines. 
(6)  Locational sketch showing how the proposed subdivision is situated in relation to adjacent subdivisions and streets. 
(7)  The layout, numbers and approximate dimensions of proposed lots. 
(8)  The location, width and dimensions of all streets, alleys and grounds proposed to be dedicated for public use and easements. 
(9)  Proposed names for all streets in the area being platted. 
(10)  Any restrictions proposed to be included in the owner's declaration of plat. 
    The planning commission shall consider the preliminary plat, if requested, at its first regular meeting which falls at least seven (7) days following the filing of the preliminary plat with the office of the city engineer. 
    The planning commission shall approve, conditionally approve or disapprove the preliminary plat and set forth its reasons in writing for disapproval or conditional approval. 
    Upon approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation of the final plat as required in section 17-44. The approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission is revocable and does not constitute final approval or acceptance of the subdivision by the planning or city commission. Preliminary plat approval only constitutes approval of the layout and general plans. 
    If the planning commission disapproves or conditionally approves the preliminary plat, the reasons for disapproval shall be remedied prior to further consideration. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-44. - Final plat approval. 
(1)  Final plat approval is a two-step mandatory procedure required for all plats: 
(a)  The final plat must be reviewed and a recommendation obtained by the city planning commission; and 
(b)  The plat must be approved by the city commission by resolution. 
(2)  Before submitting the final plat to the planning and city commissions for approval: 
(a)  The subdivider shall furnish all plans and information listed in sections 17-45 and 17-46; and 
(b)  The city engineer shall examine the plat as to its compliance with the laws and regulations of the city, the existing street system, and sound engineering practices, and submit his finding to the planning and city commissions at said meetings. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-45. - Submittal of final plat. 
    The subdivider with the city's platting jurisdiction shall submit six (6) copies of the final plat to the city, of which one (1) copy shall be on suitable tracing cloth or reproducible original. In addition, the subdivider shall also submit a computer diskette compatible with the city's computer aided drafting system of any plat or replat of property containing five (5) acres or more, ten (10) lots or more, and any plats containing curvilinear property lines. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78; Ord. No. 656, § 1, 2-10-92) 
Sec. 17-46. - Contents of final plat. 
    The final plat shall show: 
(a)  The title under which the subdivision is to be recorded. 
(b)  The name or names of the owners and subdividers. 
(c)  The date, scale and north point. 
(d)  The legal description of the area being platted. 
(e)  Boundary lines (accurate in scale), the dimensions and location of the property to be platted, and the location of section, quarter and sixteenth lines. 
(f)  Center lines of all proposed and adjoining streets with their right-of-way width and names. 
(g)  Lines of all lots with a simple method of numbering to identify all lots and blocks. This includes the layout, numbers and all dimensions of lots. 
(h)  All building lines and all easements provided for public service, together with their dimensions and any limitations of the easements. 
(i)  Any and all dimensions necessary for accurate location of the boundaries of the site to be developed and of all streets, lots, easements and dedicated areas. These dimensions shall be expressed in feet and decimals of a foot. 
(j)  All radii, arcs, points of tangency, central angles and lengths of curves. 
(k)  A location plan showing how the proposed subdivision is situated in relation to adjacent subdivisions and streets. Streets names shall be as approved by the city. 
(l)  Certification by a registered land surveyor that the final plat as shown is a correct representation of the survey as made. 
(m)  Certification of ownership. 
(n)  All survey monuments and bench marks, together with their description. 
(o)  Private restrictive covenants and their period of existence. 
(p)  The accurate outline, dimensions and purposes of all property which is offered for dedication or is to be reserved for public use, or is to be reserved by deed covenant for the common use of the property owners in the subdivision. 
(q)  Any other information or certificates required by state statute. 
(r)  Written and signed statements explaining how and when the subdivider proposes to provide and install all required sidewalks, streets, sewer, water and drainage structures. 
(s)  An affidavit of ownership, showing fee simple title and encumbrances and liens, and certificates of dedication of all land intended for public use, signed by the owner or owners and all other parties who have a mortgage or lien interests in the property. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-47. - Official submission dates. 
    The planning commission shall consider the final plat at its first regular meeting which falls at least fourteen (14) days following the filing of the final plat with the office of the city engineer. The date of the regular meeting of the planning commission at which the final plat is introduced shall constitute the official submittal date of the plat from which the city must approve or disapprove within ninety (90) days thereof. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-48. - Final plat acceptance. 
(1)  Once the final plat has been acted upon by the city planning commission, it shall then be submitted to the city commission at their next regular meeting for approval. 
(2)  The city commission shall approve a plat by resolution or, if disapproved, set forth its reasons upon the records of the commission. All final plats must be approved by the city commission; and their action is final, regardless of the action taken by the city planning commission. 
(3)  The passage of the resolution accepting the plat shall constitute final plat approval of the platting of the area shown on the final plat, but the owner shall cause such plat to be recorded in the office of the county register of deeds and shall file satisfactory evidence of such recording in the city finance office before the city shall recognize the plat as being in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-49. - Improvements to be made by subdivider. 
    Before final plat approval, the subdivider shall provide one (1) of the following guarantees for the completion of improvements specified below, subject to approval by the city commission: 
(a)  Special assessments. The subdivider may petition to the city commission to have the necessary improvements constructed and assessments levied against the property. 
(b)  Privately constructed by subdivider. The subdivider may construct improvements privately provided all plans are designed by a registered engineer and approved by the city engineer. Performance, payments and insurance certificates shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-50. - Improvements required. 
    No building permits or municipal utility connections shall be permitted until all improvements fronting any lot to be built upon are satisfactorily provided for as specified in section 17-49. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-51. - Required improvements generally. 
    The subdivider is required to install or construct the improvements herein described. 
    All improvements required under these regulations shall be constructed in accordance with city specifications and under the inspection of the city engineer or his duly authorized representative. 
    All public and private water mains, sanitary sewers, laterals and storm sewers shall be installed as necessary to prevent the future cutting of pavement of any street, sidewalk or other required pavement. All utility lines shall be placed underground where determined feasible by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-52. - Streets and alleys. 
    All streets and alleys within the city shall be constructed in accordance with the city's specifications. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Sidewalk construction and repair, § 21-37 et seq.; excavations, § 21-56 et seq. 
Sec. 17-53. - Curbs and gutters. 
    Standard curbs and gutters shall be placed on both sides of all streets in the city limits in accordance with city specifications. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Curbing streets and alleys generally, § 21-18. 
Sec. 17-54. - Water mains. 
    The design and specifications of the distribution system shall meet city specifications. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Water, § 26-17 et seq. 
Sec. 17-55. - Sewers. 
    Sewers shall be installed in each subdivision located within the city in accordance with city specifications. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Sewers, § 26-71 et seq. 
Sec. 17-56. - Storm sewers and drainage. 
    Storm sewers and drainage structures shall be designed and installed as required by the city engineer in accordance with sound engineering practice. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-57. - Property markers. 
    The corners of all lots and the beginnings and endings of all curves on property lines shall be accurately marked on the ground with three-fourth-inch galvanized iron pipe or steel rod with distinctive survey marking caps, and shall be at least twenty-four (24) inches long. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-58. - Sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks shall be constructed on both sides of all streets within a subdivision and on any other locations deemed necessary by the city commission in accordance with city specifications. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Sidewalk construction and repair, § 21-37 et seq. 
Sec. 17-59. - Inspection. 
    Each facility installed shall be under inspection of the city engineer, and if the facility consists of water lines installed within B-Y Water District's territory, the facility installed shall also be under inspection of B-Y Water District's engineer. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78; Ord. No. 976, § 1, 5-26-15) 
Sec. 17-60. - Conformity to city development plan. 
(1)  All proposed subdivisions shall conform to the city development plan. 
(2)  The densities established by the zoning ordinance and the land use plan shall be observed by the subdivider and developer. 
(3)  Original and proposed final contours shall be made of the entire area proposed for development. Such plans shall show the proposed street and drainage pattern. 
(4)  The improvements the owner proposes to make off the premises, outside the boundaries of the proposed subdivision, pursuant to the development of the subdivision shall be clearly noted on site plan. These improvements shall relate to drainage, utilities and other improvements necessary to permit development in the subdivision. 
(5)  The improvements the owner proposes to request the city to make, if any, relative to off-premises improvements necessary to the development of the subdivision shall also be clearly noted on the preliminary site plan. These improvements shall relate to drainage improvements necessary to carry runoff, extension of water mains, sewers, and other improvements. 
(6)  Where a proposed park, playground, school or other public use shown in the comprehensive development plan is located in whole or in part in a subdivision, the city commission may require the reservation or option by the appropriate public agency of purchasing such an area within the subdivision in those cases in which the city commission deems such requirements to be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-61. - Street plan. 
(1)  Collector Streets. Collector streets shall be provided along one-sixteenth and quarter section lines. The arrangement, character, extent, location and grade of all streets shall be in accordance with sound engineering principles and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in appropriate relation to the proposed uses of land to be served by such streets. 
(2)  Congested Intersections. Any streets which would tend to promote congestion converging upon any one point shall be held to a minimum. Creation of a five-point intersection shall not be permitted. 
(3)  Pattern. The street pattern shall be in conformity with a plan for the most advantageous development of the entire neighboring area. Sufficient proposed streets shall be extended as far as the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided in order to ensure normal circulation of traffic within the vicinity. Land abutting a proposed subdivision shall not be left land-locked by such proposed subdivision. 
(4)  Relation of Residential Streets to Through Streets and Railroads. The street layout shall include residential collector and local residential streets of considerable continuity approximately parallel to and on both sides of each arterial street and railroad. Such a street pattern shall reduce the number of intersections of local residential streets with through streets and railroad tracks. 
(5)  Use of Residential Streets by Through Traffic. Local residential streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic in the subdivision will be discouraged. 
(6)  Subdivisions Abutting Highways, Arterial Streets. Subdivisions which abut, or include within the proposed area to be subdivided any highway or arterial street shall provide: 
(a)  A separate access street; or 
(b)  Reverse frontage with screen planting contained in a non-access reservation along the rear property line; or 
(c)  Deep lots with rear service drives; or 
(d)  Other treatment as may be necessary to adequately protect residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(7)  Intersection of Residential Streets With Arterial Streets. Intersections of local residential streets with arterial streets shall be held to a minimum. 
(8)  Half-Width Streets. Half-width streets shall be prohibited, except where necessary for the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformance with the other requirements of this article and where the city commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street has already been provided adjacent to an area to be subdivided, the other remaining half of the street shall be platted within such subdivision. 
(9)  Cul-de-sacs. Streets designed to have one (1) end permanently closed shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having a minimum right-of-way diameter of one hundred six (106) feet. A cul-de-sac shall not exceed four hundred (400) feet in length from the radius point. 
(10)  Street Jogs. Street jogs at intersections with center line offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet shall not be permitted. In no case shall a jog be permitted on an arterial street or highway. 
(11)  Minimum Street Right-of-Way Widths. The widths of highways, arterial streets, collector streets and residential streets shall be as indicated on the major street plan and where not shown therein shall be not less than as follows: 
Street Type Right-of-Way 
(feet) Pavement Widths 
Measured from 
Street Faces 
(feet) Per Cent

The amount of right-of-way deemed reasonable to be required by dedication shall not exceed one hundred (100) feet in width, except for cul-de-sac turnaround. 
(12)  Street Grades. Minimum grades of any roadway shall not be less than three-tenths of one (0.3) per cent unless otherwise approved by the city engineer. Vertical curves shall be such as to prevent abrupt change and shall be as approved by the city engineer. 
(13)  Alignment and Visibility. 
(a)  Minimum radii of horizontal curvature line shall be as designated by the American Association of State Transportation Official's Standard Design Policy. 
(b)  Tangents between reverse curves shall be as approved by the city engineer. 
(14)  Intersections. 
(a)  Grading plan. Submission of a grading plan showing existing conditions and a detailed design for intersections which are either unusual or are located on difficult terrains may be required by the city engineer. 
(b)  Acute angles. Acute angles at street intersections are to be avoided insofar as possible, but in no case will an angle of less than sixty (60) degrees be permitted. 
(c)  Minimum Turning Radii. Street intersections shall have a minimum turning radius of fifteen (15) feet. An increased radius shall be required when the angle of intersection is less than ninety (90) degrees or when the intersection involves an arterial street. 
(15)  Community unit plans. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the board of city commissioners may authorize variances from this section in any community unit plan proposed under section 10 of the zoning code of the city; provided that the board of city commissioners finds that the variances will not be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare. These variances shall be in addition to other variances or variance procedures authorized by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78; Ord. No. 636, § 1, 2-11-91) 
Sec. 17-62. - Alleys. 
(1)  Alleys shall be required in commercial and industrial districts, except where other definite and assured provision is made for service access, such as off-street loading, unloading and parking consistent with zoning ordinance requirements. 
(2)  Alleys shall be required in residential districts. Such alleys shall have a minimum right-of-way of twenty (20) feet. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-63. - Names. 
(1)  No street names shall be used which will duplicate by spelling or sound or will otherwise be confused with the names of existing streets. Street names are subject to the approval of the city commission and section 21-120 et seq. of the Code pertaining to numbering buildings. 
(2)  Subdivision names shall not duplicate or be similar to existing names and are subject to approval by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-64. - Blocks. 
(1)  The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(a)  Zoning ordinance requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions. 
(b)  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic. 
(c)  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(2)  Block lengths shall not exceed eight hundred (800) feet and shall normally be wide enough to allow two (2) tiers of lots of appropriate depth. 
(3)  Pedestrian crosswalks, not less than ten (10) feet wide, shall be required where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, bus stops and other community facilities. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-65. - Lots. 
(1)  The lot size, width, depth, shape and orientation, and the minimum building setback lines shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for commercial and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide off-street parking and loading for the use contemplated. 
(3)  Corner lots for residential use shall have a minimum width of sixty-five (65) feet. 
(4)  Each lot shall be provided with access to a public street. 
(5)  Double-frontage and reverse-frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. Along the line of lots abutting such traffic artery or any other such disadvantageous feature, the city commission may require that a planting screen or an earth berm be constructed by the subdivider. 
(6)  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles to streets except on curves, where they shall be radial. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-66. - Easements. 
(1)  Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities and drainage where necessary and shall not be less than fifteen (15) feet wide total unless otherwise approved by the city engineer. 
(2)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way or stream, there shall be provided a storm water drainage easement or right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such existing or planned drainage way. The width of such drainage easement or right-of-way shall conform substantially with the lines of such existing or planned drainage way and shall be sufficient to contain the ultimate channel and maintenance way for the tributary area upstream. 
(3)  Lots and easements shall be arranged in such a manner as to eliminate unnecessary jogs or offsets and to facilitate the use of easements for power distribution, telephone service, drainage, water and sewer services. 
(4)  Easements will be used above, below and on the ground surface for the uses declared on plats or otherwise stated. The city will coordinate the various entities work in and occupation of easements the same as public rights-of-way where an easement has been dedicated for multiple purposes. City issued excavation permits will be required of entities intending to use utility easements dedicated on plats or otherwise granted for multiple purposes. Ground covers including pavements will be restored to existing condition by entities conducting activities in easements. 
(5)  Construction work, ground surface, piping or other improvements within the easement area shall not be interfered with or disturbed. The construction or placement of any structure, trailer, building, fence or other above or below ground stationary object within the easement area is strictly prohibited without the prior written approval of the city. Additionally, the city shall have the right at its discretion to remove from the easement area, at its own cost any trees, plants, undergrowth, buildings, trailers, fences or other structures that may interfere with the construction, operation, inspection and/or maintenance of said pipeline utilities and other facilities as determined by the city with no obligation to replace. Easement shall be perpetual and include the rights of ingress and egress necessary for the full and complete use and occupation of the easement. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78; Ord. No. 767, § 1, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 17-67. - Drainage and inundation. 
(1)  A drainage plan shall be made for each subdivision by the subdivider's engineer. Adequate provisions shall be made within each subdivision to provide drainage facilities needed within the subdivision, taking into account the ultimate development of the tributary area. Drainage and flood control facilities shall be provided in conformance with city regulations. The storm and sanitary sewer plan shall be made prior to other utility plans. Engineering considerations in subdivisions and other development shall give preferential treatment to gravity flow improvements as opposed to other utilities and improvements. 
(2)  The subdivider shall obtain all off-premises drainage easements and improvements as may be required to handle the runoff of subdivisions into a natural drainage channel. 
(3)  Low areas subject to periodic inundation shall not be developed or subdivided unless they meet the city's flood control regulations. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Cross reference- Flood control, § 11-54 et seq. 
Sec. 17-68. - Variances-Generally. 
    Where the city commission finds that extraordinary hardships or practical difficulties may result from strict compliance with this article and/or the purposes of this article may be served to a greater extent by an alternative proposal, it may approve variances to this article so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that such variance shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this article; and further provided the city commission shall not approve variances unless it shall make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that: 
(a)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare or injurious to other property. 
(b)  The conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable generally to other property. 
(c)  Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographic conditions of the specific property involved, a particular hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of this article is carried out. 
(d)  The variances will not in any manner vary the provisions of the zoning ordinance, master plan, or official map. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-69. - Same-Conditions. 
    In approving variances, the city commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standard or requirements of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-70. - Same-Procedures. 
    A petition for any variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time the final plat is filed for the consideration of the planning commission. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all facts required. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Sec. 17-71. - Penalties. 
    Violation of any provision of this article by any subdivider shall constitute a misdemeanor, and upon conviction of such violation there shall be imposed a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each lot in such subdivision. Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 475, 3-27-78) 
Secs. 17-72-17-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN 

Sec. 17-91. - Adopted by reference. 
(a)  The city, pursuant to the provisions of South Dakota Codified Law (SDCL) 11-6, hereby adopts [by reference], a comprehensive plan including the adoption of current and future land use maps, transportation maps, comprehensive development plan, and other official maps and documents which measures are more fully shown in the document and exhibits on file in the city finance office and entitled: 
THE YANKTON PLAN 
A Comprehensive Plan for Yankton, South Dakota. 
(b)  Said document is an ordinance establishing a comprehensive plan for the city and shall provide for the administration thereof, in accordance with the provisions of SDCL Chapter 11 and for the repeal of all documents in conflict therewith. 
(c)  Pursuant to SDCL 9-19-7 upon completion of consideration and action, a notice and fact of adoption will be published in lieu of publishing the entire comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 850, § 1, 11-10-03) 
Chapter 18 - PLUMBING[1]
