Former Ch. 18 was derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 1.0501, 8.0101-8.0105, 8.0201-8.0204, 8.0301-8.0305, 8.0307, 8.0308, 8.0311, 8.0315, 8.0401, 8.0402, 8.0501-8.0503, 8.0505-8.0508, 8.0601, 8.0801; Ord. No. 148, §§ 1-3, adopted Oct. 10, 1949; Ord. No. 278, adopted Dec. 14, 1964; Ord. No. 323, §§ 1-3, adopted Oct. 14, 1968; Ord. No. 327, § 1, adopted June 9, 1969; and Ord. No. 329, § 1, adopted June 9, 1969. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax and regulate plumbers, SDCL 1967, § 9-34-12; authority to regulate building construction, SDCL 1967, § 9-33-4; state plumbing code, SDCL 1967, § 36-25-15; local regulations permitted, SDCL 1967, § 36-25-16. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
(a)  Plumbing: The practice of, and the furnishing and/or the use of materials and fixtures in the installation, extension, and alteration of all piping, fixtures, appliances and appurtenances in connection with sanitary drainage or storm drainage facilities, the venting system and the public water supply systems, within or adjacent to any building, structure, or conveyance; and including the installation, extension, or alterations of the stormwater, liquid waste, or sewage and water-supply systems of any premises to their connection with any point of public disposal, or other regulated terminal. 
(b)  Plumbing contractor: Any person qualified and skilled in the planning, superintending and the practical installation of plumbing, and otherwise qualified and registered to contract for plumbing installations and conduct the business of plumbing, and familiar with the laws, rules and regulations governing the same. 
(c)  Plumber: Any person other than a plumbing contractor who, as his principal occupation, is engaged as an employee of, or otherwise working under, the direction of a plumbing contractor in the installation of plumbing, and who is lawfully qualified and registered as a plumber pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(d)  Plumbers apprentice: Any person other than a plumber or plumbing contractor who is engaged in working as an employee of a plumbing contractor under the immediate and personal supervision of either a plumbing contractor or plumber in learning and assisting in the installation of plumbing. 
(e)  Fixtures: Shall mean and include water closets, urinals, bathtubs, kitchen and pantry sinks and dry tubs, lavatories and wash basins, floor drains and sinks for other purposes, openings for bar fixtures, laundries or shower baths when not placed over bathtubs. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 1, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 18-2. - Plumbing code adopted; amendments. 
    That certain documents, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the community and economic development, being marked and designated as: 
(a)  "Uniform Plumbing Code, 2015 Edition" as published by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials and amended by the South Dakota Sate Plumbing Commission as governed by South Dakota Codified Law 36-25; and 
(b)  Amendments by the City of Yankton to the 2015 Uniform Plumbing Code; 
    are hereby adopted as the plumbing code of the City of Yankton, South Dakota, for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, replacement and use of plumbing systems and for the issuance of permits and collection of fees. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 1, 1-26-87; Ord. No. 784, §§ 1, 2, 3-13-00; Ord. No 874, §§ 1, 2, 9-26-05; Ord. No. 922, § 1, 6-8-09; Ord. No. 998, § 1, 8-28-17) 
Sec. 18-3. - Chapter not to render the city liable. 
    The city shall not be held, by reason of this chapter, as assuming any liability for damages to persons or property by reason of inspections authorized in this chapter or any certificate of inspection issued pursuant to this chapter, or by reason of the approval or disapproval of any equipment authorized by this chapter or by virtue of any other requirement, rule or regulation set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Secs. 18-4-18-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - RESERVED 

Secs. 18-17-18-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLUMBING INSPECTOR 

Sec. 18-26. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-27. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The city manager shall appoint a plumbing inspector who shall have knowledge of plumbing, and who may be the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-28. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-29. - Conflict of interest. 
    The plumbing inspector shall not be interested, directly or indirectly, in any sewer or plumbing contract or work in the city. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-30. - Duties generally. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to see that the construction and maintenance of the plumbing, draining, and ventilating of all buildings shall conform to the provisions of this chapter, to pass upon all plans submitted, and to keep a record of his work, in his office, including all notices and applications received, permits granted, violations of regulations, and all other matters pertaining thereto. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall inspect all plumbing in course of construction in new or old buildings and shall see that all plumbing work complies with this chapter. 
(c)  The plumbing inspector shall pass upon plans within twenty-four (24) hours when reasonably practicable, and in any event within five (5) days. 
(d)  The plumbing inspector shall keep a record of all work done in new or old buildings and of all work that has been condemned. 
(e)  The plumbing inspector shall perform such duties as the city manager shall prescribe and shall be charged with the enforcement of all provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relating to plumbing, sewers, house drainage, ventilation, and the inspection, examination, and approval or rejection of all plans for plumbing in new or old buildings. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-31. - Supervision of plumbing work; authority to stop work. 
    All plumbing work in process of construction, alteration or repair shall be under the supervision of the plumbing inspector, who is empowered to stop such work when it is being done contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-32. - Access to buildings. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have access to all buildings during the progress of plumbing work for the purpose of examining and carrying into effect all the provisions relating to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Secs. 18-33-18-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 18-41. - When required. 
(a)  Required. No person shall begin work on the construction, alteration, repair, or reconstruction of any plumbing or house drainage system in any building without first obtaining a permit therefor from the plumbing inspector. 
(b)  Not required. A plumbing permit shall not be required for the removal of a stoppage in soil or waste pipes, or for replacing broken fixtures, if the fixtures conform to the provisions of this chapter, nor for replacing tanks or faucets, or repairing leaks in waste pipes, or the repair or construction of water supply pipes or tanks. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-42. - Additional permit required for changes after "roughing-in" inspection. 
    When a permit has been issued for plumbing work pursuant to this division, and after a "rough-in" inspection made pursuant to this article, in no case shall changed or additional work be put in or additional fixtures set without the approval of the plumbing inspector, and a new permit must be taken out for all such additional work or fixtures. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-43. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a permit required by this division shall file with the plumbing inspector an application in writing for the permit stating therein the street and house number, with the owner's name, the name of plumbing contractor and that the work is to be done in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-44. - Persons eligible for permit. 
    A permit required by this article shall not be issued to any person except to a plumbing contractor or to the owner of a residence who desires to do his own work in a dwelling which he will occupy as his domicile for a period of at least one year. All work done by such owner shall be subject to all requirements and inspections. 
    The fees for a permit required by this division shall be as prescribed from time to time by the board of commissioners by resolution, and shall be on file in the office of the city finance officer. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-45. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-46. - Issuance. 
    Upon the approval of the application for a permit required by this division, and the payment of the permit fees, the plumbing inspector shall issue a permit in duplicate to the person applying therefor, stating the name of the owner of the property, the name of the plumbing contractor, the street and house number, and specifically the work authorized to be done thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-47. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 588, adopted Jan. 26, 1987, repealed § 18-47. Said section pertained to notice to property owner of permit issuance and to withhold payment to plumber until issuance of certificate of inspection, and was derived from Ord. No. 382, adopted Aug. 13, 1973. 
Sec. 18-48. - Display. 
    A permit issued pursuant to this division shall, at all times during the progress of the work for which it was issued and until completion thereof, be posted in some accessible place in the building wherein the work is being done. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-49. - Permit to expire upon failure to commence or complete work. 
    When a permit has been issued pursuant to this division, the work for which it was issued must be started within thirty (30) days from the date of the permit, and the work must be carried on and complete within six (6) months after commencement of the work, otherwise, such permit shall become void and a new permit must be obtained. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-50. - Revocation. 
    The plumbing inspector may revoke a permit issued pursuant to this division at any time when the work is not being done in accordance with this chapter, and it shall be unlawful for any person to proceed further with such work. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Secs. 18-51-18-56. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 18-57. - Certificate of occupancy generally. 
    A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued for any plumbing work for which a permit is required by this article until the plumbing has been inspected by the plumbing inspector and found to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 383, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-58. - Notice to inspect. 
    Any person doing plumbing work, which work has been prepared for inspection, shall notify the plumbing inspector, by notice provided for that purpose, that an inspection is required, and the time the work will be ready for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-59. - Time for inspection. 
    The plumbing inspector shall inspect a plumbing installation within two (2) working days after having been notified pursuant to this division that the work is ready for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-60. - Notice of defective work. 
    If upon an inspection made pursuant to this section, the plumbing inspector finds the plumbing work not in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, he shall notify the master plumber doing the work and also the owner of the premises by written notice given to each of them, personally, of the defects in the work. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 588, adopted Jan. 26, 1987, repealed § 18-61, which section pertained to tests of plumbing work and was derived from Ord. No. 382, adopted Aug. 13, 1973. 
Secs. 18-62-18-72. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLUMBERS 
DIVISION 1. - RESERVED 

Secs. 18-73-18-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 18-81. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of plumbing contractor without first securing a license therefor from the city finance officer and paying the license fee as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 4, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 18-82. - Application. 
    Any person desiring a license required by this division shall first make application therefor to the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 4, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 18-83. - Qualifications of applicant. 
    No license to do plumbing work in this city shall be issued to any person who does not have a current license of the same category issued by the State of South Dakota. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Secs. 18-84-18-86. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 18-84, 18-85 and 18-86 were repealed by § 5 of Ord. No. 588, adopted Jan. 26, 1987. Prior to repeal, said sections pertained to examination for plumbers license, the fee therefor and reexaminations, and were derived from Ord. No. 382, adopted Aug. 13, 1973. 
Sec. 18-87. - Issuance of license; license fee. 
    Upon submission to the department of public works of a copy of a current and valid state of South Dakota plumbers permit, a bond as required by section 18-88 of this division, and payment of the annual license fee in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a plumbing contractor and ten dollars ($10.00) for a plumber, to the city finance officer, the finance officer shall issue a license upon the approval of the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 6, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 18-88. - Plumbing contractor's bond. 
    Before any license required by this article shall be issued to a plumbing contractor, he shall file with the city finance officer a bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in favor of the city, with sureties to be approved by the board of commissioners. The bond shall be conditioned for the faithful performance of all duties required by this Code or other city ordinance and to indemnify the city and/or any person for whom plumbing work has been done for all damages sustained by reason or neglect or incompetence on the part of the plumbing contractor in the performance of his work, or on account of careless guarding of excavations made, or failure to put streets or public places opened in as good condition as they were before the work was done; or by reason of any cause growing out of the negligence or carelessness of the plumbing contractor or the issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-89. - Renewal of licenses. 
(a)  The holder of a plumbing contractor's license issued pursuant to this division shall renew the license before or at its expiration. The license issued shall expire on December 31 of each year and may be renewed upon application not later than January 31 following. It shall be unlawful to engage in the work of a plumbing contractor without renewal of the license. 
(b)  The holder of a plumber's license issued pursuant to this division shall renew the license before or at its expiration. The license issued shall expire on December 31 of each year and may be renewed upon application not later than January 31 following. It shall be unlawful to engage in the work of a plumber without renewal of the license. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 7, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 18-90. - Transferability. 
    No license issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-91. - Posting. 
    A license issued pursuant to this division shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plumber's place of business. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-92. - Revocation. 
    In addition to other penalties imposed, the board of commissioners may revoke the license of any plumber issued pursuant to this division for violation of any provision of this chapter by the plumber or his employee. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Sec. 18-93. - Duties of licensed plumbers generally. 
    All plumbers licensed pursuant to this division shall be subject to the following: 
(a)  He shall be held responsible for the acts of his agents or employees done under and by virtue of his license. 
(b)  Any change in his business name or location shall be promptly reported to the plumbing inspector. 
(c)  Any defective plumbing work must be changed to conform to the ordinance pertaining thereof, and if on notice from the plumbing inspector, such change is not made, the plumbing inspector shall proceed to make or have the same made, at the cost of the plumber who performed such defective work and the surety on his bond. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73) 
Secs. 18-94-18-101. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SPECIAL LICENSES 

Secs. 18-102, 18-103. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 18-102, relating to appliance installers license, and § 18-103, relating to water conditioning and treatment license, both derived from Ord. No. 382, adopted Aug. 13, 1973, were repealed by Ord. No. 468, adopted Jan. 9, 1978. 
Sec. 18-104. - Sewer and water installers license. 
(a)  Special licenses shall be issued by the city under the South Dakota Sewer and Water Installers Rules and Regulations as set out herein, to persons engaged in the special trade or business of installing and repairing sewer and water installations as defined herein and who are qualified under such rules and regulations, provided, however, that such special license shall not be required of persons licensed as plumbing contractors, plumber, or plumber's apprentice. 
(b)  Definitions of terms under these rules and regulations: 
(1)  Sewer and water installation and repair shall mean and include the excavation and refilling for trenches and structures, and the furnishing and installing of materials for the following items: Water mains (water supply piping for public, private or community use); water services (piping from the water main or other source of water supply to the building served); water appurtenances (including, but not limited to valves, fittings, hydrants, pumps and their accessories, storage facility piping); water treatment plant piping and equipment (plant piping and equipment designed to purify water, including influent and effluent piping, and to purify water, including influent and effluent piping, and chemical treatment piping); public sewers (common sewer directly controlled by public authority); building sewers (sewer piping receiving discharge from the building drain and conveying it to a public sewer, private sewer, individual sewage-disposal system, or other point of disposal); sewer appurtenances (including, but not limited to manholes, valves, fittings, pumping equipment, lift stations and their accessories, septic tanks, mechanical treatment plants and their accessories, disposal fields); sewer treatment plant piping and equipment (plant piping and equipment designed to treat sewage, including influent and effluent piping, and chemical treatment piping, and process piping for same); storm sewers (sewers used for conveying rainwater, surface water, condensate, cooling water, or similar liquid wastes, located on public or private property); building storm sewer (extension from the building storm drain to the public storm sewer, combined sewer, or other point of disposal); connections to building services (actual connection to existing service lines at a point five (5) feet from the building being served, or connection to existing service lines at a point approved by the local authority). 
It does not include water, sewer and storm sewer connections within buildings on building side of connection point, connections to or piping for building water and sewer sanitary use. 
(2)  Sewer and water installation contractor. A sewer and water installation contractor is a person who engages in the trade or business of selling and installing sewer and water installations as defined in (a) above, and maintaining and servicing the same, including the option, adjustment, repair, removal and renovation of same. 
(3)  Sewer and water installer. A sewer and water installer is any person other than a sewer and water contractor who, as his principal occupation is engaged as an employee of, or otherwise working under the direction of a sewer and water contractor, in the installations, maintenance and repair of sewer and water installations. 
(4)  Sewer and water installer apprentice. A sewer and water installer apprentice is any person other than a water and sewer contractor or a water and sewer installer who is engaged in working as an employee of a sewer and water contractor under the immediate and personal supervision of either a sewer and water contractor or a sewer and water installer in learning and assisting in the installation of sewer and water installations. 
(c)  No license to do sewer and water installation in this city shall be issued to any person who does not have a current license of the same category issued by the State of South Dakota. Any person desiring a license required by this division shall first make application therefor to the department of public works. Upon submission to the department of a current and valid state license, a bond as required by section 18-105, and payment of the finance officer shall issue a license upon the approval of the department of public works. 
(d)  The annual license fee for a sewer and water installation contractor shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year and the annual license fee for a sewer and water installer shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year; such fees shall be paid to the city finance officer and his receipt therefor presented with the application for license. 
(e)  A sewer and water installer apprentice license shall be issued free of charge and will be renewed by the apprentice on the same dates as required by the contractor and installer. 
(f)  The annual license for a sewer and water installation contractor, sewer and water installer and sewer and water installer apprentice shall expire on December 31 of each year but may be renewed upon application not later than January 31 following; however, it shall be unlawful to engage in the work without renewal of the license. 
(Ord. No. 382, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 588, § 8, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 18-105. - Bond. 
    All sewer and water installation contractors shall furnish a bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in favor of the city with sureties to be approved by the board of commissioners. The bond shall be conditioned on the faithful performance of all duties required by this Code and other city ordinances and to indemnify the city and any person for whom the excavation has been done for all damages sustained by reason of neglect or incompetence on the part of the sewer and water installation contractor in the performance of work, or failure to put streets or public places opened in as good condition as they were before the work was done, or by reason of any cause growing out of negligence or carelessness of the sewer and water installation contractor of the issuance of the license required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 471, 1-9-78) 
Secs. 18-106-18-110. - Reserved. 
Chapter 19 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Resisting arrest. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist, or attempt to resist by any means, including physical resistance or flight, any lawful arrest by any police officer or peace officer. 
(Ord. No. 255, 7-23-62) 
Sec. 19-2. - Mistreating police dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously torture, tease, torment, beat, kick, strike, mutilate, injure, disable, or kill any dog used by the police department in the performance of its functions or duties, or to interfere with or meddle with any such dog while being used by the police department or any officer or member thereof. 
(Ord. No. 262, § 1, 1-14-63)

ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Duty to appoint chief of police and policemen, SDCL 1967, § 9-14-1; authority to regulate the police of the city, SDCL 1967, § 9-29-2; powers of policemen, SDCL, § 9-29-19. 

Sec. 19-16. - Established; composition. 
    There is hereby established a police department which shall consist of a chief of police and such number of police officers as the board of commissioners may prescribe. 
Sec. 19-17. - Duties of the chief of police generally. 
    The duties of the chief of police shall be such as are prescribed by the laws of the state, and the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city for the preservation of the peace and order of the city, and such further duties as shall be required of him by the city manager. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 1.0207)

Sec. 19-18. - Duties of police officers generally. 
    The duties of each police officer shall be the same as those prescribed for the chief of police, except that police officers shall be at all times under the direction and supervision of the chief of police. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 1.0207) 
State Law reference- Powers of policemen, SDCL 1967, § 9-29-19. 
Chapter 20 - RAILROADS 

Sec. 20-1. - Obstructing crossings. 
    No railroad company, railroad engineer, train conductor or other person shall cause or allow any locomotive engine, car or cars to stop at or remain upon any street or railroad crossing within the city for a period longer than five (5) minutes at any one time; however, in case any accident should take place at any railroad crossing, reasonable time shall be allowed to remove any obstruction that shall be caused thereby. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 11.0402) 
Sec. 20-2. - Whistle and bells. 
    No railroad company shall cause or allow the whistle of any engine to be sounded within the city, except necessary brake signals and signals as may be absolutely necessary to prevent injury to persons or to property. The bell of each engine shall be rung continually while said engine is running within the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 11.0403) 
Sec. 20-3. - Construction and maintenance of crossings. 
(a)  Any railroad company maintaining or operating any railroad over or across any street or alley in the city shall construct thereat such crossings as may be required by the board of commissioners, and shall keep and maintain the street or alley crossing in a state of proper repair. 
(b)  Whenever the board of commissioners shall direct the construction, reconstruction or repair of any street or alley crossing by a railroad company pursuant to subsection (a), a copy of the resolution ordering the work shall be served upon the railroad company, and thereafter, within twenty (20) days, the railroad company shall do and perform all acts required by the resolution upon penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day's failure to comply therewith, together with the cost of the work at the crossing, if done by the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0901) 
State Law reference- Authority to require the construction and maintenance of crossings, SDCL 1967, § 9-35-8. 
Sec. 20-4. - Authority of the city to require the installation of automatic warning signals. 
(a)  Whenever the board of commissioners shall by resolution so order and direct, any railroad company maintaining or operating a line through or into any part of the city shall place, keep, or maintain automatic danger signals at any street designated. The automatic danger signal shall be of a type approved by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Whenever the board of commissioners shall direct a railroad company to place, keep or maintain an automatic danger signal at any street or streets pursuant to subsection (a) a copy of the resolution ordering the installation shall be served upon the railroad company, and within thirty (30) days, the railroad company shall do and perform all the acts required by the resolution, upon penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day's failure to comply with the directions and orders in said resolution contained, together with the cost of the work, if done by the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 11.0404) 
State Law reference- Authority to require warning devices at crossings, SDCL 1967, § 9-35-9.

for provisions regulating signs.

Chapter 21 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Riding bicycles on sidewalks within the business district, § 6-5; storage of building materials on public ways, § 7-2; encroachment of public ways by buildings, § 7-3; moving buildings, § 7-19 et seq.; railroads obstructing crossings, § 20-1; railroad construction and maintenance of crossings, § 20-3; street banners, § 201/2-2; trees overhanging public ways, § 24-1; mowing grass on premises abutting public ways, § 24-2; sight obstructions at intersections, § 24-3. 
State Law reference- Regulation of streets and public places, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Removal of snow and ice. 
(a)  Declared a nuisance. Any accumulation of snow or ice upon any of the public sidewalks in the city which obstructs, impedes or in any manner interferes with the free and unobstructed use thereof by pedestrians is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(b)  Duty of owner or occupant to remove snow and ice. It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any premises abutting any sidewalk to keep the sidewalk free from snow or ice. He shall cause to be removed, within twenty-four (24) hours after any fall of snow, the snow from so much thereof as adjoins the premises owned or occupied by him. When it is impossible to take the snow or ice from the sidewalk by reason of its being frozen thereto, he shall sprinkle or spread some suitable material upon the sidewalk to prevent it from becoming slippery and dangerous to travel. 
(c)  Removal by the city. If the owner or occupant of a premises abutting a sidewalk fails or refuses to remove the snow or ice therefrom within the time limit prescribed in subsection (b), it shall be the duty of the city manager to have the snow or ice removed and to charge against the abutting property for each time the snow is removed, the actual expense incurred by the city on account of the removal of the snow or ice. 
(d)  Record of costs. The city manager shall cause an account to be kept against each lot for the snow or ice removed from the sidewalk each year, by the city pursuant to subsection (c) and the record shall be certified to the city auditor on or before the fifteenth day of April of each year. 
(e)  Assessment of costs. The finance officer shall prepare an estimate of the assessment against each lot for the removal of snow or ice by the city pursuant to this section for the preceding period and submit the estimate to the board of commissioners for its approval on or before the first day of May each year, and shall publish in the official newspaper a notice to property owners of the time and place when the board of commissioners will meet for the purpose of approving the estimate. Upon the day so named, the board of commissioners shall meet, and if it shall find the estimate correct, it shall approve it or if not correct, it shall correct or modify the estimate and approve it as modified and correct, and file assessment with the city treasurer. From the date of the approval and filing, the assessment shall be a special lien against the various pieces of property described in the assessment and shall be collected in like manner as special assessments are now collected for public improvements. 
(f)  Liability of property owner. Any owner of real property who shall fail to remove the snow or ice from the sidewalks in front of or along the property if he resides thereon, or if he does not reside thereon, to move the snow and ice forthwith when notified, shall be held liable to the city for any damage caused by his failure or neglect. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0310) 
State Law reference- Authority to require snow and ice removal and to make a special assessment for the cost thereof, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-5. 
Sec. 21-2. - Manner of providing for installment payments for special assessments. 
    Whenever the board of commissioners of the city shall cause to be improved any street, alley, public way or ground, the cost of which improvement is to be paid by special assessment against the abutting property, the board of commissioners may divide the special assessment into any number of equal annual installments, not exceeding ten (10). Interest on deferred installments shall be at the rate of six (6) per cent per annum. If the board of commissioners shall determine to divide the special assessment into installments, the resolution declaring the necessity for the improvement shall state that the special assessment therefor will be payable in equal annual installments and the number thereof, not exceeding ten (10). 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.1001) 
State Law reference- Installment payments of special assessments, SDCL 1967, § 9-43-13. 
Sec. 21-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 21-3, pertaining to driveway construction requirements, was repealed by § 1 of Ord. No. 617, adopted Aug. 28, 1989; said former section originated from Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0607; and Ord. No. 328, § II, adopted Apr. 14, 1969. 
Sec. 21-4. - Interference with barricades and lanterns. 
    No person shall move, interfere with, break, destroy, carry away, or in any manner molest any barricade, warning sign, lantern, torch or flare used by any person in guarding any unsafe or dangerous place. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0704) 
Sec. 21-5. - Marring new concrete. 
    No person shall mar, injure or deface in any way newly laid concrete of any public way. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0705) 
Sec. 21-6. - Violations of provisions of this Code regulating the use of streets declared a nuisance; remedies. 
    The violation of any provision of this Code, or any other city ordinance which provision prohibits or regulates the use of any street, alley, parking or other public place for any purposes, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and, to avoid a multiplicity of actions and to more effectively enforce such provisions of this Code or other city ordinances, the city is authorized to commence and complete actions in any proper court to restrain such violation and nuisance and to do such things and procure such relief as may reach such results, including temporary injunctions which actions may be commenced by the city attorney, and shall be commenced if the city manager or the board of commissioners shall so request. 
(Ord. No. 181, § 2, 9-28-53) 
Secs. 21-7-21-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Construction of local improvements, SDCL 1967, § 9-42-1; financing of improvements, SDCL 1967, § 9-43-21, et seq.; municipal improvement bonds, SDCL 1967, § 9-44-1, et seq.; street and alley improvements, SDCL 1967, § 9-45-21, et seq. 

Sec. 21-18. - Grading, paving and curbing streets and alleys generally. 
    The paving, grading and curbing of the streets and alleys shall be done under the direction of the city manager and the city engineer, and shall be done in accordance with the plans and specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0701) 
Cross reference- Curbs and gutters in subdivisions, § 17-53. 
State Law reference- Street and alley improvements, SDCL 1967, § 9-45-1, et seq. 
Sec. 21-19. - Street grades generally. 
    The grades of the streets in the city, as shown on the street profiles on file in the office of the city engineer, are hereby established and designated as the official grades of the streets of the city, and the profiles on file in the office of the city engineer are incorporated herein by reference and adopted as the official record of grades of streets in the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0102) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish street grades, SDCL 1967, §§ 9-45-1, 9-45-14.

    The grades of the alleys in the city, as shown on the alley profiles on file in the office of the city engineer, are hereby established and designated as the official grades of the alleys of the city, and the profiles on file in the office of the city engineer are incorporated herein by reference and adopted as the official record of grades of alleys in the city.
