Cross reference- Alleys in subdivisions, § 17-62. 
Sec. 21-21. - Roadway widths generally. 
    The width of the roadways between curblines for vehicular traffic on the various streets and avenues in the city are hereby fixed and established in accordance with the official record of the width of roadways in the city on file in the office of the city engineer and are hereby adopted as the official record of the width of roadways in the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0104) 
Sec. 21-22. - Interference with contractors. 
    No person shall interfere with or obstruct any person in carrying out in a lawful manner any contract entered into with the city for any improvement or public works. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0703) 
Sec. 21-23. - Inspections; fee. 
    An inspection fee of two and one-half (21/2) per cent of the cost of any public improvement shall be charged by the city as a fee for inspecting the engineering, design and general suitability of all public improvements within the city, and the inspections shall be made at such time and at such intervals as may be reasonably necessary in view of the conditions and nature of the construction requiring such inspection services. 
(Ord. No. 340, § 2, 7-13-70) 
Sec. 21-24. - City employees not to perform engineering or design work. 
    No city employee, and particularly any member of the city engineering staff, while on duty and being paid by the city, shall design or perform any engineering services for the benefit of private contractors or developers, notwithstanding any fee proposal tendered or offered by any such contractors or developers, and all engineering and design work shall be done by qualified persons who are not employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 340, § 1, 7-13-70) 
Sec. 21-25. - Duties of the city engineer generally. 
    The duties of the city engineer with respect to public improvements shall include the preparing of all plans and specifications for and supervision over all contract work undertaken by the city and such other duties as may be assigned to him by the board of commissioners or the city manager. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0702) 
Secs. 21-26-21-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK AND DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 617, adopted Aug. 28, 1989, repealed former Art. III, §§ 21-37-21-43, and added new provisions as herein set out in Art. III, §§ 21-37-21-50; former Art. III pertained to related subject matter and originated from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 9.0601-9.0606; and Ord. No. 328, §§ I, II, adopted Apr. 14, 1969. 
Cross reference- Streets and alleys in subdivisions, § 17-52; sidewalk construction in subdivisions, § 17-58. 
State Law reference- Sidewalk improvements, SDCL 1967, § 9-46-1 et seq. 

Sec. 21-37. - New buildings. 
(a)  General rule. The owners of all new or relocated residential, business and industrial buildings, except those listed in subsection (b), shall construct permanent sidewalks fronting or abutting all streets, highways and avenues. 
(b)  Exception. The owners of new or relocated residential, business and industrial buildings may be waived by the city commission if: 
(1)  The industrial building is beyond any residentially zoned property by more than one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet; or 
(2)  Those exceptions listed in subsection 21-38(e)(1 through 4). 
(c)  Commission action. When a new or relocated residential business and industrial building is required to have a permanent sidewalk in subsection (a), 
(1)  the city commission may order the permanent sidewalk be installed, or 
(2)  after fifty (50) per cent of the lots on that side of the block have installed sidewalks and when five (5) years has elapsed since the installation of curb and gutter fronting or abutting the property. 
(d)  Definition. A new or relocated residential, business and industrial buildings is in a subdivision platted after May 1, 1990, and has at least fifty (50) per cent of the curb and gutter installed in the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 679, 5-4-93) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 679, adopted May 4, 1993, repealed §§ 21-37-21-40. Formerly, these sections pertained to sidewalk installation and construction requirements and derived from § 2 of Ord. No. 617, adopted Aug. 28, 1989. Ordinance No. 679 provided further for the addition of new §§ 21-37-21-40 as herein set out. 
Sec. 21-38. - Previously built buildings. 
(a)  General rule. All residential, business and industrial buildings which are not new or relocated residential, business or industrial building are not required to have permanent sidewalks unless that procedure in subsections (b) through (e) are met. 
(b)  Petition. Two (2) owners of residential, business or industrial buildings on the same block may petition the city commission for a proposal concerning the construction of permanent sidewalks fronting or abutting all streets, highways and avenues on their own block. 
(c)  Notice and public hearing. Upon receipt of the petition from the owners, the city commission shall give notice of time and date of the hearing described in subsection (d) to all homeowners on the same block on which the petitioners shall reside. Notice shall be given at least ten (10) days before the hearing and comply with due process. 
(d)  Hearing requirements. When a petition is submitted under subsection (b) the city commission shall conduct a public hearing at which it shall permit owners to present testimony and submit evidence. After all testimony and evidence are presented, the city commission shall submit the petition to a vote of those owners on that block present at that meeting. If those owners favoring placement of permanent sidewalks receive greater than fifty (50) per cent of the those owners attending the meeting to approve the addition of sidewalks, then the city commission shall order permanent sidewalks to be placed on that block. Each landowner shall have a number of votes equal to the number of lots they own. 
(e)  Waiver. The city commission shall not waive the hearing and notice procedure provided in sections (a) through (d). However, the city commission may waive a sidewalk requirement which has been submitted to a vote of owners in subsection (d) and has received greater than fifty (50) per cent of the vote under the following conditions: 
(1)  Where it can be determined that exceptional topographic changes make it impractical to build a sidewalk on the site. 
(2)  Where an insufficient right-of-way exists that would preclude the location of a sidewalk. 
(3)  Where an existing sidewalk on the opposite side of the street extends at least seventy-five (75) per cent of the block in which the waiver is required. 
(4)  Where it is proposed by a developer and approved by the department of public works that alternate sidewalk locations will be equally or more physically feasible or desirable while serving the same sidewalk access function. 
(Ord. No. 679, 5-4-93) 
Note- See editor's note following § 21-37 herein. 
Sec. 21-39. - Failure to comply with sidewalk requirements. 
(a)  Failure to comply. The failure of a property owner to construct a permanent sidewalk fronting or abutting his property in the manner and time specified upon the order of the city commission under section 21-37 or section 21-38(d) shall be cause for the city to have the sidewalk installed and assess the cost against the respective property owner. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 679, 5-4-93) 
Note- See editor's note following § 21-37 herein. 
Sec. 21-40. - Supervision and deferral. 
(a)  Supervision and deferral. Construction under section 21-37 and 21-38 shall be completed, approved and supervised by the department of public works prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy required by the building code of the city. 
    This requirement may [be] deferred by the department of public works for up to six (6) months under the following conditions: 
(1)  Weather conditions are such that it is not economically or physically feasible to construct a sidewalk before occupancy; or 
(2)  It is evident that additional work requiring the use of heavy equipment must be completed before occupancy; or 
(3)  The director of public works has agreed that other arrangements have been made. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 679, 5-4-93) 
Note- See editor's note following § 21-37 herein. 
Sec. 21-41. - Driveways required. 
    The construction of a permanent driveway fronting or abutting all streets, highways and avenues shall be accomplished by the owner of all new residential, business and industrial buildings or when any structural change to any garage, whether attached or unattached, within the city. Structural changes shall include additions to existing garage structures. Driveways shall be constructed in accordance with the provisions of section 21-47. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
Sec. 21-42. - Supervision of work. 
    The building, construction, repair or reconstruction of all sidewalks and driveways within the city shall be done under the direct supervision of the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
Sec. 21-43. - Permit required. 
    Before any sidewalk, driveway or any part thereof is constructed within the city by any contractor or person acting for the owner of the abutting property, the contractor or person must first make application to and secure a permit therefor from the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
Sec. 21-44. - Bond required of contractors and other persons. 
    Before any person shall receive a permit for the construction or installation of any sidewalk or driveway, they must first file with the finance officer a bond, in an amount equal to the total amount of the work to be performed by him, with sufficient surety to be approved by the department of public work; or, in the alternative, he shall first file a bond with like surety in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) covering all work to be done by him within one (1) year of the date of filing the bond. The bond shall provide that person obtaining the permit shall replace any sidewalk constructed by him at any time within three (3) years from the time of completion thereof which, in the opinion of the board of city commissioners or the director of public works, was not laid in accordance with the specifications therefor. 
    Exception: The bond required above shall not be required of property owners who own and occupy properties and perform the work themselves. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89; Ord. No. 631, § 1, 9-18-90) 
Sec. 21-45. - Specifications generally. 
    The construction of all sidewalks and driveways, whether done by direct contract with the city or by contract with the abutting property owner, shall be done in accordance with specifications for sidewalks and driveways adopted by the board of city commissioners and on file in the department of public works. The director of public works shall have full power to reject work or material not in accordance with the requirements of the specifications. Should the sidewalk be rejected after its construction, the director of public works shall notify the property owners immediately and order the work to be replaced at the owner's expense. If the owner fails to replace rejected work, the city shall cause the work to be replaced and assess the cost as prescribed in SDCL 9-46. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
State Law reference- Authority to prescribe sidewalk specifications, SDCL 1967, § 9-46-1. 
Sec. 21-46. - Lines and grades. 
    The construction of all sidewalks and driveways shall be according to lines and grades furnished by the department of public works. The contractor shall take necessary steps to protect and care for all grade stakes set; and if any of the stakes are disturbed, the grade is to be reset at the contractor's expense. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
Sec. 21-47. - Location and width of sidewalks and driveways. 
(a)  Sidewalks. All sidewalks required by this article: 
(1)  Shall be located on public property or a dedicated sidewalk easement and shall be located as specified by the director of public works. 
(2)  Shall be of the same width as sidewalks immediately adjacent thereto but of not less than five (5) feet; or, in cases where a sidewalk abuts the curb, the sidewalk shall be not less than six (6) feet in width. Where sidewalks adjacent thereto are of different widths, then the director of public works shall determine the width thereof. 
(3)  All sidewalks constructed on Third Street between Mulberry Street and Linn Street, on Broadway Avenue between Third Street and Fourth Street, on Walnut Street between Third Street and Fourth Street and on Douglas Avenue between Second Street and Fourth Street shall extend in width from the lot line to the curbline. 
(4)  Shall be a minimum thickness of four (4) inches except at residential driveways and ADA ramps, including the turning space, where the thickness shall be a minimum of six (6) inches, and commercial driveways shall be as prescribed by the director of public works. 
(5)  Shall be constructed with Portland cement concrete or equivalent as determined by the director of public works. 
(b)  Driveways. All driveways and driveway approaches required by this article: 
(1)  Shall be limited to one (1) access point. A second access point may be allowed for residential properties if the property is located on a corner lot: one (1) access point to each street frontage may be permitted. Multiple access points may be allowed for residential, business and industrial properties where, in the opinion of the director of public works, the driveway design will not interfere with traffic safety. In all cases where a second or multiple-driveway access is requested, it must be approved by the director of public works. 
(2)  Shall have a minimum width of ten (10) feet for residential properties and sixteen (16) feet for business and industrial properties. The curb opening shall be not greater than the buildable area width, plus three (3) feet extended from the driveway edge for residential properties and forty (40) feet for business and industrial properties. In no case shall the driveway opening extend beyond the property line. 
(3)  Shall not be located closer than twenty-five (25) feet from the projected curbline of the intersecting street. 
(4)  Shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete from the curbline to the property line; and, from the property line to the structure or parking lot, may be of Portland cement concrete, asphalt concrete or an equivalent material approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89; Ord. No. 1007, 4-23-18) 
State Law reference- Authority to prescribe sidewalk width, SDCL 1967, § 9-46-1. 
Sec. 21-48. - Maintenance. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain all sidewalks adjacent to his property in a safe, unobstructed and passable condition as determined by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
Sec. 21-49. - Requirements for barrier-free curbs and sidewalks. 
    Whenever any person, firm or corporation makes new installations of sidewalks, curbs or gutters or improves or replaces existing sidewalks, curbs or gutters in both business and residential areas, it shall be required that they install ramps at crosswalks so as to make the transition from street to sidewalk easily negotiable for disabled persons in wheelchairs. All such ramps shall be constructed or installed in accordance with design specifications according to the most current American National Standards specifications published by the American National Standards Institute. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89; Ord. No. 979, § 2, 7-27-15) 
Sec. 21-50. - Retroactivity of requirements. 
    The lack of a public sidewalk in developing subdivisions is hereby deemed to be a serious public safety hazard. The owner of any property in a developing subdivision shall be required to comply with the sidewalk requirements of subsection 21-37(b) of this article as of the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 617, § 2, 8-28-89) 
Secs. 21-51-21-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and alleys in subdivisions, § 17-52. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate excavations in public ways, SDCL 1967, §§ 9-30-1, 9-45-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-56. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  The person making an excavation in a public way shall carry liability insurance which shall save harmless the city and protect the public and any person from injury or damage sustained by the reason of the prosecution of the work or the handling or storing of materials therefor. 
(b)  Prior to the beginning of any excavation work in city right-of-way, the person making the excavation shall furnish the finance officer with a proper affidavit, executed by the representatives of a duly qualified insurance company, evidencing that the insurance company has issued a liability insurance policy effective during the year of construction. The affidavit shall specifically evidence bodily injury and property damage liability insurance covering all operations performed by the person making the excavation or his employees. The minimum protection shall be as follows: 
(1)  Bodily injury, general liability insurance: 
Each person\$100,000.00 
Each accident\300,000.00 
(2)  Property damage, general liability insurance: 
Each accident\$50,000.00 
Aggregate\100,000.00 
(Ord. No. 335, § 3, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-57. - Supervision. 
    The city engineer or his authorized representative shall supervise all excavations made for any purpose in street parkings, sidewalks, alleys, or other public property, and he shall require all excavations to be backfilled in a good and workmanlike manner and as specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 5, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-58. - Cutting concrete pavements. 
    All existing concrete that is to be broken out to make an excavation shall be sawed where indicated by the city engineer or his authorized representative so as to form a smooth, straight joint at the junction of the new and old concrete. The sawed joint shall be at least one and one-half (11/2) inches deep. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 8, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-59. - Protection of excavations. 
    Any person receiving a permit issued pursuant to this article shall erect and maintain around the excavation, both by day and night, during the continuance of the work and until the city engineer permits traffic over the excavation, suitable and adequate guards, fences, flares, and signals so as to prevent injury to persons or property because of the excavation. The protection shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 6, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-60. - Backfilling. 
(a)  All native material or sand used for backfill shall be free from frozen materials, rocks, foreign material that may decompose, and other materials that may affect the stability of the backfill. 
(b)  All trenches and structure excavations shall be backfilled as soon as the jointing compound, mortar, concrete, or other material has attained a suitable degree of hardness, and this work shall be prosecuted expeditiously until completed. 
(c)  In the case of excavations for any kind of pipe or conduit, the space between the pipe and conduit and the bottom and sides of the trench shall be packed and compacted as fast as placed, up to the level of the top of the pipe or conduit. The material shall be deposited carefully in the trench to avoid injuring the pipe or conduit and shall be placed in layers not more than six (6) inches in thickness, and each layer shall be solidly and carefully tamped with appropriate tools. The filling shall be carried up evenly on both sides. The above method shall be used to cover the pipe or conduit to at least two (2) feet above its top. All tamping above an elevation of two (2) feet above the crown of the pipe or conduit shall be done by hand or with pneumatically operated tampers or other tampers approved by the city engineer. Tamping with the side or bottom of an excavating bucket shall not be acceptable. 
(d)  All backfill shall be placed and tamped in layers not more than six (6) inches in thickness. Flushing shall not be allowed unless specifically authorized by the city engineer. When the trench is filled, the person making the excavation shall remove all surplus material, leaving the street clean and in good order. If so directed by the city engineer, the surplus material shall be spread over the street; the person making the excavation shall not dispose of it until this matter is determined. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 7, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-61. - Replacement of pavement. 
(a)  All Portland cement concrete that is to be replaced shall be constructed and conform with the specifications of the city engineer. All concrete replaced shall be a minimum of six (6) inches in thickness and be high-early strength concrete. 
(b)  All asphalt streets shall be restored to a minimum of three (3) inches and shall be replaced according to the city engineer's specifications. The subbase shall have a minimum of twelve (12) inches of gravel. The asphalt used must be a hot mix and must be approved by the city engineer's office. All asphalt streets must be sawcut just prior to placing new asphalt. All concrete streets with asphalt overlays shall be cut, excavated and patched according to the city engineer's specifications. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 8, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-62. - Restoration of parkings. 
    A person making an excavation who performs work in a parking shall seed or sod the parking, and he shall restore the area back to original condition, as determined by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 8, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-63. - Restoration of roadway. 
    The person making an excavation shall be responsible for the roadway that the backhoe pads set on. Any damage done to the existing roadway will be repaired by the excavator to the city engineer's specifications. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 8, 3-9-70) 
Sec. 21-64. - Unsatisfactory work; notice. 
    If at any time within three (3) years after the issuance of a permit required by this article, the city engineer shall find that the work has not been satisfactorily done, or has not been properly backfilled, he shall notify the person who obtained the permit, in writing, that the work must be put in satisfactory condition in one (1) week, or the bonding company will be notified. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 4, 3-9-70) 
Secs. 21-65-21-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 21-76. - Required. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in or under any street, parking, sidewalk, alley, or other public property or remove any earth, soil, paving, gravel, or other material therefrom without first having obtained a permit therefor from the director of public works office. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 1, 3-9-70; Ord. No. 589, § 1, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 21-77. - Application. 
    Before a permit required by this division is issued, an application therefor shall be made at the director of public works office, which shall state where the excavation is to be made; the extent thereof; adjacent to what property; the purpose of said excavation; and whether the applicant has a bond and proper insurance on file with the city finance officer for making the excavation. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 2, 3-9-70; Ord. No. 589, § 1, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 21-78. - Bond. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit required by this division shall, before receiving the permit, deposit a bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in the officer of the city finance officer, to be approved by the director of public works, covering all excavations for the year for which bond is given, and covering the excavations for three (3) years. 
(b)  The bond required by subsection (a) shall stand as a guarantee for the proper refilling and proper guarding of the proposed excavation and the maintaining of the excavation in good condition for three (3) years thereafter. 
(c)  A plumber licensed by the city who has deposited a plumber's bond which shall also cover the bonding of excavations for a period of three (3) years, shall not be required to file a bond otherwise required by subsection (a) as a condition to making the excavation. 
(Ord. No. 335, § 2, 3-9-70; Ord. No. 589, § 1, 1-26-87) 
Secs. 21-79-21-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESERVED[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Division 3, the substantive provisions of which were given in §§ 21-86-21-90, relating to excavation contractors, derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, § 10.0202, was repealed by Ord. No. 470, adopted Jan. 9, 1978. 

Secs. 21-86-21-101. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent and remove encroachments and obstructions on public ways, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-2. 

Sec. 21-102. - Generally. 
    No person hereafter shall place, leave or keep on any street, road, alley, sidewalk or other public ground, any article, substance or thing which may obstruct the free use thereof or obstruct the view of drivers of vehicles approaching within fifty (50) feet of any street intersection. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0315) 
Sec. 21-103. - Fuel on public ways. 
    No person shall deposit, pile or keep or cause to be deposited, piled or kept any firewood or other type of fuel on any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground in the city; however, it shall be lawful for any person, while in the act of receiving any firewood or other fuel, to deposit and keep it for a period not exceeding twenty-four (24) hours between the outer edge of the sidewalk and the curb of the street. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0301) 
Sec. 21-104. - Storage, display and sale of goods and merchandise. 
(a)  The use of any public street, road, alley, sidewalk, parking or other public ground for the deposit, storage, exhibition or sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, including vehicles, machinery and furniture, shall be unlawful except as provided for street vendors of food licensed by the city. 
(b)  No person shall suspend any personal property over any sidewalk for deposit, storage, exhibition or sale or place or keep any advertising sign thereon. 
(c)  No person shall place any barrel, case, box, bottle or other package upon any sidewalk, except as is incidental to loading or unloading, receiving or delivering, but in no instance shall any such articles be left upon the sidewalk at night, or in such a manner as to obstruct the free use of the sidewalk. 
(d)  The word "parking" as used in this section shall include all that part of any public street dedicated, or used as such, lying and being between the property lines, except the sidewalk and the street, if there is a sidewalk or street. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0304; Ord. No. 181, § 1, 9-28-53) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate sales on public ways, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-4. 
Sec. 21-105. - Signs, posts and awnings. 
(a)  No person shall place, hang or maintain on, or extend over, any sidewalk any sign which shall be less than ten (10) feet above the sidewalk. 
(b)  No person shall set any post or other obstruction in or upon any street, sidewalk or alley for the purpose of fastening thereto any awning, sign, lamp or other article. 
(c)  No person shall attach any awning to any building adjacent to any street or sidewalk which, when down, shall approach nearer to the surface of the street or sidewalk than seven (7) feet. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0305) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and prohibit signs and advertising in public places, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-3. 
Sec. 21-106. - Stairways and areaways. 
(a)  No person shall construct any stairway extending into any street, road, alley or sidewalk or other public place. 
(b)  An area appurtenant to any building may extend not to exceed twenty-four (24) inches into the adjoining street, road, alley or sidewalk or other public ground; however, any area authorized by this subsection shall be covered with a substantial iron grating or other noncombustible cover, the grates of which shall not be more than one (1) inch apart, which cover must be on the grade of the street, road, alley or sidewalk or other public ground in which constructed. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0307) 
Sec. 21-107. - Discharge of water across public ways. 
(a)  Eave pipes. No person shall place or maintain any pipe leading from the eaves of any building in such position that the water discharged therefrom flows upon or over any public sidewalk. 
(b)  Air conditioners. The discharge of water from air-conditioning, air cooling or other like equipment upon or into the streets, alleys or public places of the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance. The city manager shall notify, in writing, any person discharging, permitting or causing to be discharged, water which is, under the provisions of this subsection, declared to be a nuisance, to abate the nuisance within five (5) days after the service of the notice, exclusive of the day of service, upon a penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for each day's failure to comply with the notice, together with the cost of abating the discharge of water if the work is done by the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0314) 
Sec. 21-108. - Impoundment of property unlawfully on public ways. 
(a)  Any property found in violation of this article may be removed by any police officer or other person at his direction, as provided for the removal of unlawfully parked vehicles. 
(b)  The police officer removing property pursuant to subsection (a) shall give a written notice to such person as he shall believe to be the owner or last in possession of the property, if he can conveniently learn thereof, and by filing a copy of the notice in the office of the chief of police. 
(c)  The charges for towing, storage and care of property impounded pursuant to this section, and a service charge of two dollars ($2.00) for each day, or fraction thereof, for the care of the property shall be paid, and is hereby declared to be a lien on the property in favor of the city, which lien may be foreclosed as provided by the laws of the state. 
(d)  The payment of costs imposed by subsection (c) shall not be a bar to the enforcement of this article by a prosecution for a violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 181, § 3, 9-28-53) 
Sec. 21-109. - Deposit of snow and ice on public rights-of-way. 
    It shall be illegal for any person to deposit snow or ice at any location in such as manner as to interfere or restrict with the passage or visibility of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Snow and ice shall not be deposited from private property onto any public street, alley, sidewalk, trail, parking lot, or other paved right-of-way with the following exception: 
EXCEPTION: Snow and ice may be placed on the following street gutters in the downtown central business district from abutting sidewalks only within the first 24 hours after the snowfall has ended: Third Street from Linn Street to Picotte Street and the following streets for a distance from Second Street to Fourth Street: Broadway, Cedar, Walnut, Douglas, Capital, Mulberry, and Pine. 
    Snow and ice from that portion of a driveway approach in the public right-of-way and public sidewalk may be deposited on right of way areas that are unpaved provided they do not obstruct motorist or pedestrian visibility. 
(Ord. No. 885, 3-27-06) 
Secs. 21-110-21-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the numbering of houses and lots, SDCL 1967, § 9-45-2(2). 

Sec. 21-120. - Duty of owner or occupant to number building. 
    It is hereby made the duty of each person owning or occupying any house or other building now in existence or which may be hereafter constructed in the city, fronting or abutting upon any street or avenue, to place or affix upon the door or the front of the building in plain, painted, printed or metallic numerals of not less than three (3) inches in height, the proper number assigned to the house or other building, and to keep or maintain the number so placed or affixed so that it will at all times be visible and legible by persons in the street immediately in front of the house or building. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0201) 
Sec. 21-121. - Numbering plan generally. 
    It is the intention of the board of commissioners that the numbers designated for all buildings, vacant lots or parcels of ground fronting or abutting upon any street or avenue running north and south and located on the east side thereof, or fronting or abutting upon any street or avenue running east and west and located on the north side thereof, shall be even numbers; and that all numbers assigned to buildings, vacant lots or parcels of ground fronting or abutting upon any street or avenue running north and south located on the west side thereof, or fronting and abutting upon any street or avenue running east and west and located on the south side thereof shall be odd numbers. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0203) 
Sec. 21-122. - Numbering north and south streets. 
    On all streets and avenues running north and south, the numbering shall be commenced at the south line of the platted portion of the city. The number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting on the street or avenue, and located on the west side, shall be the number "101" and the number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting on the street or avenue, and located on the east side, shall be the number "102"; and proceeding thus north a number shall be assigned to each building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting on the street or avenue alternating from the west side to the east side, up to the intersection of the street or avenue by Second Street. The number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting upon the street or avenue, and located on the east side, north of Second Street, shall be "200" and the number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting upon the street or avenue, and located on the west side, and north of Second Street, shall be "201" and the numbering shall proceed thus north to the north line of the platted portion of the city, alternating from the east to the west side of the street or avenue, the first number in each block in all cases being the next higher multiple of one hundred (100) than the first number in the block immediately south thereof. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0202) 
Sec. 21-123. - Numbering east and west streets. 
(a)  On all streets and avenues running east and west, the numbering shall commence at the intersection of the streets and avenues by Douglas Avenue, and the number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting on the streets or avenues, and located on the north side, east of Douglas Avenue, shall be "100" and the number signed to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground so fronting or abutting on the streets and avenues and located on the south side, shall be "101"; and proceeding thus east, each building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting the streets or avenues shall be numbered as in the case of streets and avenues running north and south. The number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting on the streets or avenues and located on the north side, west of Douglas Avenue, shall be "100" and the number assigned to the first building, vacant lot or parcel of ground so fronting or abutting upon the streets or avenues, and located on the south side, shall be "101" and the numbering shall proceed thus west to the west line of the platted portion of the city. 
(b)  The word "east" or "west", as the case may be, shall be added to the number assigned to any building, vacant lot or parcel of ground fronting or abutting upon any street or avenue running east and west for the purpose of indicating whether the building or lot is east or west of Douglas Avenue. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0203) 
Sec. 21-124. - Correct number determined by city engineer. 
(a)  The correct number of any house or building shall be determined by the city engineer. In case any house or building is incorrectly numbered, the city engineer may order the owner or occupant thereof to correctly number it, and it shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant to refuse to comply with the order. 
(b)  The number of any structure, as determined by the city engineer, shall be indicated on the building permit therefor. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0204) 
ARTICLE VII. - SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTES 

Sec. 21-125. - Policy. 
    It is hereby declared to be in the best interest of the public policy and public safety of the city to regulate and restrict the parking of vehicles on public streets during snow emergencies. 
(Ord. No. 542, 11-28-83) 
Sec. 21-126. - Penalties. 
    Any vehicle in violation of this article is hereby declared to be an abandoned vehicle and may be removed as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 542, § 11-28-83) 
Sec. 21-127. - Designation of snow emergency routes. 
    The following streets and avenues or portions thereof within the City of Yankton are designated as snow emergency routes: 
(1)  Commercial districts: 
Third Street from Mulberry Street to Linn Street. 
Broadway Avenue from Second Street to Fifth Street. 
Capital Street from Second Street to Fourth Street. 
Douglas Avenue from Riverside Drive to Fourth Street. 
Walnut Street from Second Street to Fourth Street. 
(2)  Other streets and avenues: 
Second Street from Broadway Avenue to South Dakota Highway 50. 
Fourth Street (Highway 50) from Fifth Street to Ferdig Avenue. 
Eighth Street from West City Limits Road to South Dakota Highway 50. 
Ninth Street from West City Limits Road to Summit Street. 
Fifteenth Street from Summit Street to Ferdig Avenue. 
Nineteenth Street from Broadway Avenue to Ferdig Avenue. 
Twenty-first Street from west city limits to Peninah Street. 
Thirty-first Street from Broadway Avenue to Peninah Street. 
Broadway Avenue from Fifth Street to Thirty-first Street. 
Burleigh Street from Fourth Street to Twenty-fifth Street. 
Douglas Avenue from Fourth Street to Thirty-first Street. 
Mulberry Street from Fifteenth Street to Twenty-fifth Street. 
Peninah Street from Eighth Street to Twenty-fifth Street. 
Summit Street from Fifth Street to Twenty-first Street. 
Whiting Drive from Burleigh Street to east city limits. 
Kellen Gross Drive from Twenty-first to Twenty-third Street 
Twenty-third Street from Kellen Gross Drive to Mulberry Street 
Twenty-fifth Street from Broadway to Mulberry Street 
Mulberry Street from Twenty-fifth to Donohoe Boulevard 
Donohoe Boulevard from Mulberry Street to Regal Drive 
Burleigh Street from Fourth Street to Peninah Street 
Peninah Street from Twenty-fifth Street to Thirty-first Street 
West city limits road from 8th Street to 9th Street 
(Ord. No. 542, § 11-28-83; Ord. No. 703, § 1, 11-28-94; Ord. No. 719, § 1, 10-9-95) 
Sec. 21-128. - Parking of vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand, park or leave unattended any motor vehicle upon any emergency snow routes immediately after two (2) inches of snow has accumulated, and until the snow has been cleared to the curbline of the entire block. This provision shall not prohibit the parking of vehicles in commercial districts listed in subsection 21-127(1). However, the parking prohibition for commercial districts shall be as established in section 14-159 of this Code. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to modify or change any regulations of the state highway department for state highways included as snow emergency routes or any provisions of chapter 14 regulating parking for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 542, § 11-28-83) 
Sec. 21-129. - Obstructions and encroachments. 
    Members of the police department or department of public works are hereby authorized to have a vehicle removed from a street to the nearest garage or other place of safety (including another place on a street), or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department, or otherwise maintained by this city, as provided in section 14-162 of this Code, when: 
(1)  The vehicle is parked on a part of a snow emergency route on which a parking prohibition is in effect. 
(2)  The vehicle is stalled on a part of a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice or on which there is a parking prohibition in effect and the person who was operating such vehicle does not appear to be removing it in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(3)  The vehicle is parked in violation of any parking ordinance or provision of law and is interfering or about to interfere with snow removal operations. 
(4)  Vehicles parked on non-snow emergency routes and in municipal parking lots in excess of twenty-four (24) hours after a snow emergency has been declared shall be ticketed for violation. Any such vehicle so ticketed remaining on a street forty-eight (48) hours after a snow emergency has been declared shall be subject to towing. 
(Ord. No. 542, 11-28-83; Ord. No. 885, 3-27-06) 
Sec. 21-130. - Notice to owner and recovery. 
    Whenever an officer of the city has a vehicle removed from a street as authorized in section 21-129, the officer shall send notice of removal by mail to the record title holder as provided for in section 15-17 of this Code. 
    The record title holder may recover a vehicle that has been removed pursuant to section 21-129 as established in section 15-18 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 542, 11-28-83) 
Sec. 21-131. - Record. 
    Is shall be the duty of the police department to keep a record of each vehicle removed in accordance with section 21-129. The record shall include a description of the vehicle, its license number, the date and time of its removal, where it was removed from, its location, the name and address of its owner and last operator, if known, its final disposition and the parking violation involved. 
(Ord. No. 542, 11-28-83) 
Sec. 21-132. - Signs. 
    The director of public works shall cause all snow emergency routes to be clearly signposted to give notice that this article is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 542, 11-28-83) 
Secs. 21-133, 21-134. - Reserved. 
Sec. 21-135. - Saving clause. 
    Should any section, clause or provision of this article be declared by the courts to be invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part so declared to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 542, 11-28-83) 
Chapter 221/2 - TAXATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 221/2-1-221/2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SALES AND SERVICE, USE TAX[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 490, adopted Mar. 26, 1979, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-7 as Ch. 221/2, Art. II, §§ 221/2-16-221/2-22, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 221/2-16. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide additional needed revenue for the city by imposing a municipal retail sales and use tax pursuant to the powers granted to the municipality by SDCL 10-52 entitled "Uniform Municipal Non-Ad Valorem Tax Law," and acts amendatory thereto. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 1, 3-26-79) 
Sec. 221/2-17. - Effective date; enactment of tax. 
(a)  From and after the first day of January, 2005, there is hereby imposed as a municipal retail occupation sales and service tax upon the privilege of engaging in business a tax measured by two (2) per cent on the gross receipts of all persons engaged in business within the jurisdiction of the City of Yankton, Yankton County, South Dakota, who are subject to the South Dakota Retail Occupational Sales and Service Tax, SDCL 10-45 and acts amendatory thereto. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 2, 3-26-79; Ord. No. 670, § 1, 11-9-92; Ord. No. 845, 8-11-03; Ord. No. 857, 8-23-04; Ord. No. 881, 9-12-05) 
Sec. 221/2-18. - Collection. 
    The tax provided for by this article is levied pursuant to authorization granted by SDCL 10-52 and acts amendatory thereto, and shall be collected by the South Dakota Department of Revenue and regulation in accordance with the same rules and regulations applicable to the state sales tax and under such additional rules and regulations as the Secretary of Revenue and Regulation of the State of South Dakota shall lawfully prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 3, 3-26-79; Ord. No. 845, 8-11-03) 
Sec. 221/2-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 881, adopted Sept. 12, 2005, repealed § 221/2-19, which pertained to exemptions from taxation and derived from Ord. No. 490, § 4, adopted March 26, 1979; Ord. No. 562, § 1, adopted Aug. 12, 1985; Ord. No. 623, § 1, adopted Dec. 11, 1989; Ord. No. 845, adopted Aug. 11, 2003. 
Sec. 221/2-20. - Use tax. 
    In addition there is hereby imposed an excise tax on the privilege of use, storage and consumption within the jurisdiction of the city of tangible personal property or services purchased from and after the first day of January, 2005, at the same rate as the municipal sales and service tax upon all transactions or use, storage and consumption which are subject to the South Dakota Use Tax Act, SDCL 10-46, and acts amendatory thereto. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 5, 3-26-79; Ord. No. 845, 8-11-03; Ord. No. 857, 8-23-04) 
Sec. 221/2-21. - Interpretation. 
    It is declared to be the intention of this article and the taxes levied hereunder that the same shall be interpreted and construed in the same manner as all sections of the South Dakota Retail Occupational Sales and Service Act, SDCL 10-45, and acts amendatory thereto, and the South Dakota Use Tax, SDCL 10-46, and acts amendatory thereto; and that this shall be considered a similar tax, except for the rate thereof, to that tax. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 6, 3-26-79) 
Sec. 221/2-22. - Penalty. 
    Any person failing or refusing to make reports or payments prescribed by this article and the rules and regulations relating to the ascertainment and collection of the tax herein levied shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. In addition, all such collection remedies authorized by SDCL 10-45, and acts amendatory thereto, and SDCL 10-46, and acts amendatory thereto are hereby authorized for the collection of these excise taxes by the department of revenue and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 7, 3-26-79; Ord. No. 639, § 5, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 845, 8-11-03) 
Sec. 221/2-23. - Use of revenue from rate over one per cent up to one and eighty-six hundredths per cent. 
    Any revenues received under sections 221/2-17 and 221/2-20 in excess of one (1) per cent up to one and eighty-six hundredths (1.86) per cent, may be used only for the purpose of capital improvements, land acquisition, street maintenance and operations, and debt retirement for a joint building project with the city school district (Summit Activities Center) including parking, street improvements, and utility improvements attendant thereto and for street construction and storm sewer improvements. Any revenues up to one (1) per cent and in excess of the one and eighty-six hundredths (1.86) per cent will have no restrictions on use. 
(Ord. No. 670, § 2, 11-9-92; Ord. No. 857, 8-23-04; Ord. No. 1009, 6-25-18) 
Sec. 221/2-24. - Reserved. 
Sec. 221/2-25. - Special tax rate on lodgings. 
    Notwithstanding the rate of tax established in section 221/2-16, there is hereby imposed an additional municipal tax at a rate of one (1) per cent upon the gross receipts of all leases or rentals of hotel, motel, campsites or other lodging establishments within the city for periods of less than twenty-eight (28) days. A lodging establishment shall mean any building, structure, property or premises kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the public to a be a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished to transient guests. A transient guest is any person who resides in a lodging establishment less than twenty-eight (28) consecutive days. There is also imposed an additional municipal tax at a rate of one (1) per cent upon the gross receipts of all sales of alcoholic beverages as defined in SDCL 35-1-1, or establishments where the public is invited to eat, dine, or purchase and carry out prepared food for immediate consumption, or ticket sales or admissions to places of amusement, athletic, and cultural events, or any combination thereof. This tax is imposed pursuant to the powers granted to the City of Yankton by the State of South Dakota, by SDCL 10-52A, and acts amendatory thereto. The tax applies to the gross receipts of all persons engaged in business within the jurisdiction of the City of Yankton, Yankton County, South Dakota, who are subject to the South Dakota Retail Occupational Sales and Service Tax, SDCL 10-45 and acts amendatory thereto. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 1, 9-9-91; Ord. No. 857, 8-23-04; Ord. No. 872, 5-9-05; Ord. No. 881, 9-12-05) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 645, adopted Sept. 9, 1991, provided for the inclusion of a new § 221/2-23. Inasmuch as other provisions have been included as § 221/2-23, new § 221/2-23 has been redesignated as § 221/2-25 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 221/2-26. - Use of funds generated by additional tax on lodgings, alcoholic beverages, prepared foods and entertainment. 
    All revenue received from this additional tax shall be utilized for the purpose of land acquisition, architectural fees, construction costs, payments for civic center, auditorium, or athletic facility buildings, including the maintenance, staffing, and operations of such facilities and the promotion and advertising of the city, its facilities, attractions, and activities, including economic development. The board of city commissioners shall have the authority to appropriate such funds as are generated by this additional tax for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 645, § 2, 9-23-91; Ord. No. 872, 5-9-05) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 645, adopted Sept. 9, 1991, provided for the inclusion of a new § 221/2-24. Inasmuch as other provisions have been included as § 221/2-24, new § 221/2-24 has been redesignated as § 221/2-26 at the editor's discretion. 
Chapter 23 - TRAILERS AND TRAILER PARKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate house trailers and trailer coaches, SDCL 1967, § 9-31-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 23-1-23-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 385, adopted Oct. 23, 1973, repealed former Art. II, relative to trailer coach parks, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Art. II as set out in §§ 23-16-23-27. Former Art. II was derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 6.2001-6.2016, and Ord. No. 178, adopted June 15, 1953. 
Cross reference- Flood control for mobile homes, § 11-90(c). 

Sec. 23-16. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
(a)  Mobile home park shall mean any area, tract, site or plot of land whereupon a minimum of twenty (20) mobile homes as herein defined are placed, located or maintained or intended to be placed, located or maintained, for dwelling purposes on a permanent or semipermanent basis. 
(b)  Licensee shall mean any person, firm, trust, partnership or corporation licensed to operate and maintain a mobile home park under the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Manager or operator shall mean any person named in the license who is in charge of the daily operation and maintenance of the mobile home park. 
(d)  Independent mobile home shall mean a mobile home which has a flush toilet and a bath or shower. 
(e)  Dependent mobile home shall mean a mobile home which does not have a flush toilet and a bath or shower. 
(f)  Mobile home is a detached residential dwelling unit designed for transportation, after fabrication, on streets or highways on its own wheels, on a flatbed, on another trailer or in another manner, and arriving at the site where it is to be occupied as a dwelling complete and ready for occupancy except for minor and incidental unpacking and assembly operations, location of jacks or other temporary or permanent foundations, connection to utilities, and the like. A travel trailer is not to be considered as a mobile home. 
(g)  Double-wide mobile home shall mean all mobile homes with a width greater than fourteen (14) feet. 
(h)  Travel trailer shall mean a mobile home not exceeding eight (8) feet in width and not more than thirty-three (33) feet in length, designed and furnished for nonpermanent occupancy and transportation, on wheels, by a standard automobile. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 23-17. - Location. 
    Mobile home parks shall be considered a conditional use as that term is defined and applicable under the provisions of the 1956 Zoning Ordinance, as amended. Said mobile home parks may be located in any zoning district in the city, provided, that the board of city commissioners shall approve same in the manner required by the 1956 Zoning Ordinance, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Cross reference- See also, § 23-22. 
Sec. 23-18. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the limits of the City of Yankton, any mobile home park without a license therefor. All mobile home parks in existence upon the effective date of this article shall within thirty (30) days thereafter obtain such a license. The license period shall be January 1 to December 31 annually and all licenses shall expire on December 31 annually. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-19. - License fee. 
    The basic annual license fee for each mobile home park shall be ten dollars ($10.00) plus a space fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each mobile home space, occupied or unoccupied. The fee for transfer of this license as provided in this article shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-20. - Application for license. 
(a)  Application for license for a mobile home park shall be filed with the finance officer, reviewed by the plan commission, and issued by the board of city commissioners. All applications, plans, maps, designs, specifications and drawings must be submitted in triplicate, however, license renewals shall not require resubmission of said plans unless changes have occurred after the initial filing as required by subsection 23-20(d). 
(b)  The application for an initial mobile home park license shall be in writing, signed by the owner, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant and or the manager or operator, if different than the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the mobile home park. 
(3)  A complete plan of the mobile home park in conformity with all of the requirements for such as contained in this article. 
(4)  Plans and specifications of all buildings, improvements and other facilities such as electrical wiring, water service pipes, sanitary sewer pipes, storm sewer drainage, gas service pipes, roads and sidewalks constructed or to be constructed within the mobile home park. 
(5)  Such further information as may be required or requested by the city manager to enable him to determine if a proposed mobile home park plan will comply with all requirements of this article. 
(c)  Before any application required by this section may be approved for a mobile home park, the city manager shall investigate and inspect the applications, the proposed plan and the specifications. If the plans and specifications for the proposed mobile home park are in compliance with all provisions of this article and all applicable ordinances and statutes, the application shall be referred to the plan commission for review. Following review, the plan commission shall recommend to the board of city commissioners approval or denial and the reasons therefor. The board of city commissioners may issue the license, at its discretion. 
(d)  No changes may be made in a mobile home park without filing for an adjustment to the original plan, in the same manner required of the original plan. 
(e)  Upon application for a transfer of the license, the board of city commissioners may authorize a transfer to any mobile home park in compliance with all provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-21. - Design requirements. 
    A mobile home park shall conform to the following requirements: 
(a)  A park shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to ensure rapid drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water. The park may not be built on a flood plain of up to a fifty-year frequency. 
(b)  Mobile home spaces shall be provided consisting of a minimum of two thousand two hundred (2,200) square feet for each space, except for those mobile home parks constructed prior to operative date of this article, which may have a minimum of one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet per space. 
All spaces must be clearly defined and marked. Mobile home spaces for double-wide mobile homes shall have a minimum size of three thousand (3,000) square feet, and must be clearly defined and marked. 
(c)  Mobile homes shall be placed on each space so that there shall be at least a fifteen-foot clearance between mobile homes. No mobile home shall be located closer than ten (10) feet from any building or ten (10) feet from the end of another mobile home within the park, or four (4) feet from any property line bounding the park. 
(d)  All mobile homes shall abut upon a driveway of not less than thirty (30) feet in width which shall have unobstructed access to a public street or highway; all driveways shall be all-weather surfaced with asphalt, Portland cement, or concrete, well marked in the day-time and lighted at night as required by the director of municipal services. An alley may not serve as the principal driveway of a mobile home park. One (1) off-street parking space must be available at each mobile home space, or if contiguous to a fifty-foot street have parallel parking available. 
(e)  Walkways not less than two (2) feet wide shall be provided from the mobile home spaces to any service buildings. The walkway shall be of concrete construction, except for those walkways constructed prior to operative date of this article, which must be all-weather surfaced. All walkways must be well marked in day-time and lighted at night as directed by the director of municipal services. 
(f)  Underground utilities shall be required in all mobile home parks, except for those mobile home parks constructed prior to operative date of this article. 
(g)  An electrical outlet supplying at least two hundred twenty (220) volts and one hundred (100) amperes shall be provided for each mobile home space, except for those spaces constructed prior to July, 1973, which may have sixty (60) amperes. 
(h)  Each mobile home space shall be provided with an untrapped sewer at least three (3) inches in diameter, which shall be connected to receive waste from the shower, bath tub, flush toilet, lavatory and kitchen sink of the mobile home, each of which shall be trapped. The sewer in each space shall be connected to discharge the mobile home waste into a public sewer system in compliance with all applicable ordinances. 
(i)  Each mobile home space shall have municipal water and sanitary sewer services in compliance with the State of South Dakota Plumbing Code. 
(j)  It shall be the duty of the park owner, his agent, or caretaker, to ensure that all mobile homes parked after July 1, 1975, shall be tied down or anchored with tie-down anchors or hurricane straps and/or cables, in accordance with specifications required and provided by the city. 
Cross reference- Anchoring of mobile homes in areas of special flood hazard, § 11-89(a)(2). 
(k)  All mobile homes shall be skirted on all sides between the mobile home floor and ground level, within thirty (30) days of occupancy. Mobile homes shall be skirted with concrete or metal. Persons wanting to use prefabricated, factory-designed plastic or polystyrene mobile home skirting must obtain written approval from the chief building inspector before installing the material. 
(l)  No open fires will be permitted within the mobile home park. 
(m)  Tightly covered garbage cans shall be provided in quantities adequate to comply with city ordinances to permit disposal of all garbage and rubbish. Garbage cans shall be located not more than two hundred (200) feet from any mobile home space. The cans must be kept in sanitary condition at all times. One (1) or more central collection points may be used. 
(n)  Each mobile home park shall provide a separate grassed ground and equipped recreation area of not less than two hundred (200) square feet per mobile home space. This section may be waived if the mobile home park is within four hundred (400) feet of an existing park or playground. 
(o)  No owner or person in charge of any dog, cat or other pet shall be permitted to let it run at large or commit any nuisance within the limits of the mobile home park, if pets are allowed by the owner. 
(p)  All mobile home spaces must be within four hundred (400) feet of an existing fire hydrant, and all parks shall have adequate fire protection in full compliance with city ordinances and the National Fire Code. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73; Ord. No. 415, 6-23-75; Ord. No. 502, 2-11-80) 
Sec. 23-22. - Location and size. 
    Mobile home parks may be located in any zoning district as detailed in section 23-17. The minimum size for a mobile home park shall be twenty (20) mobile home spaces located on a minimum site of one acre, except for those mobile home parks constructed prior to the operative date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-23. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The city manager shall inspect each mobile home park at least once a year for the renewal of the license and to determine that it is in compliance with this article. 
(b)  The board of city commissioners may revoke any license to maintain and operate a park when the licensee has been found by it to have violated any provision of this article. Notification of listed violations must be given in writing to the licensee by the city manager. A period of ninety (90) days will be allowed from the date of notification for the licensee to make necessary corrections, after which the board of city commissioners may act to revoke the mobile home park license. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-24. - Supervision. 
    A responsible attendant or caretaker, owner or operator, shall be responsible at all times to keep the mobile home park, its facilities and grounds, in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-25. - Existing licensed parks. 
    Mobile home parks licensed as of October 31, 1973 shall not be required to meet the space, parking and recreation area requirements of this article but shall meet all other requirements by November 1, 1975, provided, however, that all parks that do not meet the requirements of this article in every detail shall not be permitted to expand to any degree, whatsoever, except that said expansion shall meet all requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-26. - Travel trailers. 
    Travel trailers may be parked as unoccupied units in a yard or garage within the City of Yankton. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-27. - All mobile homes in licensed parks, modular homes. 
    All mobile homes of every type and description shall be located in licensed mobile home parks. However, the board of city commissioners may, at its discretion, permit mobile homes that are, in the opinion of the board of city commissioners, sufficiently different in structural details to qualify as modular house or manufactured homes to be located outside of licensed mobile home parks provided, however, that said special exceptions shall be decided on a case by case basis only and in no case shall be used for commercial or industrial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 385, 10-23-73) 
Sec. 23-28. - Mobile home placement standards. 
(a)  The mobile home park owner shall submit a permit application to the building official before a mobile home is allowed to be brought into the city and placed in a new or vacated space in the owner's park, or before a mobile home is moved from one licensed park to another within the city. Mobile homes moved within the same licensed park are exempt from this requirement. Said permit shall include the mobile home owner's name, mobile home make/model/size, date and time of anticipated arrival, and the park lot location assigned. The fee for said permit shall be determined by city commission resolution. 
(b)  All mobile homes brought into the city or moved from one location to another within the city shall be manufactured after June 15, 1976 and meet or exceed federal HUD manufactured home construction and safety standards as adopted on June 15, 1976. 
(c)  Building permits for improvements that increase the size of a mobile home shall not be issued for units constructed prior to June 15, 1976. 
(Ord. No. 939, 2-14-11)

DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 401, adopted June 10, 1974, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-4 as Ch. 231/2, Art. II, Div. 2, §§ 231/2-21-231/2-24, was at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate electrical rates, SDCL 1982, § 9-35-1. 

Sec. 231/2-21. - Approval required for change of rates. 
    No public utility shall place in effect a change in rates and/or charges and/or terms and conditions for electric services subject to the jurisdiction of the city under SDCL 9-35-1 without having received the prior approval of the city's governing board. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1, 6-10-74) 
Sec. 231/2-22. - Required information for rate change. 
    The following material shall be submitted by a utility with any rate schedules proposing changes in rates and/or charges and/or terms and conditions for electric service: 
(1)  A cost of service study for the following cities: Aberdeen, Chamberlain, Huron, Mitchell, Redfield, Webster and Yankton (hereinafter referred to as "cities") considered as a group and showing the cost of service to each of the following customer classes within the group, based upon a test period which shall consist of a base period of twelve (12) consecutive months of most recently available actual experience, adjusted for changes in revenues and costs which are known and measurable with reasonable accuracy at the time of filing, and which will become effective within nine (9) months after the last month of available actual experience utilized in the filing; but in no event shall such test period, as adjusted, extend six (6) months beyond the date of filing: 
Farm 
Residential, nonfarm 
Commercial 
Industrial 
Street and highway lighting 
All other 
(2)  The cost of service study shall include the information listed below. Where it is necessary to allocate expenses or investment to the cities, the allocations should be supported by a clear, concise statement of the method used and copies of calculations. 
a.  For each of the cities, provide sales and revenue data by customer class. 
b.  i.  The actual unadjusted test year expenses and revenue deductions applicable to the total company and the allocated expenses and revenue deductions applicable to the cities. 
ii.  Indicate any necessary adjustments to the actual test year expenses and revenue deductions and indicate the effect on the expenses and revenue deductions allocated to the cities. 
c.  The investment in electric plant in service for the total company and the allocated investment applicable to the cities. Include the date used to determine the investment in electric plant. 
d.  The depreciation reserve for the total company and the allocated investment applicable to the cities. Include the data used to develop the depreciation reserve. 
e.  A statement of working capital requirements with supporting data. Also, furnish thirteen-month data and averages for the following electric department items:

4.  Date of issue.

1.  Dividend rate. 
2.  Face value.

6.  Amount of issue outstanding. 
7.  Annual cost.

(iii)  Common stock: 
1.  For each year of ten-year period ending with test year give: 
a.  Dividend rate. 
b.  Earnings per average number of shares. 
c.  Average shares outstanding-actual and adjusted for stock splits and stock dividends. 
2.  Number of shares paid for but not issued under dividend reinvestment program, if any. 
i.  A summary of short-term debt transactions for test year, including any conditions of interest rate. 
j.  A statement showing the claimed cost of service to the cities. 
k.  Energy and demand responsibility calculations. 
l.  System loss calculations with supporting theory. 
m.  Balance sheets in the form prescribed by the FPC Uniform System of Accounts for Public Utilities and Licensees as of the beginning and the end of the test period, and the most recently available balance sheet, including therein the footnotes, if any, applicable thereto. 
n.  Income statements in the form prescribed by the FPC Uniform System of Accounts for Public Utilities and Licensees for the test period, and the most recently available income statement, including therein footnotes, if any, applicable thereto. 
o.  For the test period, show income taxes computed on the basis of the rate of return claimed and separated as between federal and state taxes; the principal components of the tax adjustments shall be described and the amounts thereof shown separately. Amounts for deferred taxes debit and credit should be shown. There also should be shown the amounts and basis of assignment of income taxes attributed to other utility departments and nonutility operations, together with any tax savings affecting the total tax liability. If the filing public utility joins in a consolidated tax return, there shall be given the total estimated tax savings, expressed as a percentage, resulting from the filing of a consolidated return, as well as a full explanation of the method of computing the tax savings. Any abnormalities (such as nonrecurring income, gains, losses, deductions, etc.) affecting the income tax for the test period shall be explained and the tax effect thereon set forth. 
(3)  a.  For the test year, furnish the twelve (12) actual monthly maximum demands for each of the cities and the combined monthly maximum demand for the cities as a group. Include the date and time of occurrence of each of these demands. 
b.  For the test year, furnish the twelve (12) actual monthly coincident demands at the time of system peak for each of the cities and the combined monthly coincident demand at the time of system peak for the cities as a group. Include the date and time of occurrence of each of these demands. 
(4)  The public utility shall provide the following background information: 
a.  Copies of FPC Form 1 and 12 for the most recent two (2) calendar years. 
b.  The annual report to the stockholders for the most recent two (2) calendar years. 
c.  Copies of all quarterly reports to stockholders issued for the test year and the most recent calendar year. 
d.  Copies of the latest prospectuses issued for debt and equity securities for the test year and the most recent calendar year. 
e.  Copies of the internal monthly financial and operating reports for each month of the test year. 
(5)  The public utility shall submit all work papers supporting the cost of service. 
(6)  The written testimony and exhibits on which the public utility relies to support the proposed changes in rates and/or charges and/or terms and conditions of service. 
(7)  A detailed statement of the material changes in facts and circumstances since the filing of the last rate change on which the public utility relies to justify the necessity for a change in rates. 
(8)  The submission of the foregoing prescribed cost of service and other data and information shall not preclude or limit the utility from submitting any additional data and information which is material, relevant and competent. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 2, 6-10-74) 
Sec. 231/2-23. - Legislative basis for rate changes. 
    The cost of service and other required data and information shall be prepared in accordance with the principles set forth in Exhibit #1 incorporated in Ordinance No. 398 adopted by the city and in any subsequent electric utility rate regulation ordinances adopted by the cities. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 3, 6-10-74) 
Editor's note- As originally promulgated, this section contained the numbers of ordinances adopted by the other cities of the group. Ord. No. 398 of the City of Yankton is not set out in this Code. 
Sec. 231/2-24. - Further information. 
    The city may, by resolution, require additional information and data and establish necessary administrative schedules and procedures. A public utility shall grant free access to the consultants, experts and counsel for the city to all accounts, records, reports, memoranda, data and information of whatever nature for the purpose of the investigation herein instituted when requested to do so. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 4, 6-10-74) 
Chapter 24 - VEGETATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Trees overhanging public ways. 
    The occupant or owner of any premises abutting upon any street, road or alley shall keep all trees upon the premises or between the premises and the center of the adjoining streets so trimmed that no bough or branch thereof shall hang lower than eight (8) feet above the surface of the street, road, alley or sidewalk thereon. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0309) 
State Law reference- Regulation of streets and public places, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-1 et seq. 
Sec. 24-2. - Mowing grass on premises abutting public ways. 
    The occupant or owner of any premises abutting upon any street, road or alley shall keep mowed or cut down all weeds and grass that may grow between the boundary line of the premises and the center of the adjoining street, road or alley. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0309) 
State Law reference- Regulation of streets and public places, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-1 et seq. 
Sec. 24-3. - Sight obstruction of intersections. 
    No person shall plant, maintain or permit to grow upon any premises abutting upon any street, road or alley any tree, shrub, hedge, or vegetation in such way as to obstruct the view of the drivers of vehicles approaching within fifty (50) feet of any street intersection. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 9.0309) 
State Law reference- Regulation of streets and public places, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-1 et seq. 
Secs. 24-4-24-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOXIOUS VEGETATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 920, adopted Jan. 26, 2009, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 24-16-24-21, pertained to weeds, and derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 9.0401-9.0403, 9.0405; Ord. No. 275, adopted Jan. 13, 1964; Ord. No. 705, § 1, adopted Dec. 12, 1994. 
State Law reference- Authority with respect to noxious and unhealthful vegetation, SDCL 1967,§ 9-32-12; authority to require the removal of weeds from parkings, SDCL 1967, § 9-30-5. 

Sec. 24-16. - Weeds and vegetation deemed noxious, dangerous, and unhealthful are declared to be a nuisance. 
    The following named weeds and plants shall be deemed noxious, dangerous, and unhealthful vegetation and are hereby declared to be nuisances: ragweed; parsley; pigweed; nettle; thistle; sunflower; goldenrod; tumbleweed; burdock; cockle burrs; wild oats; sticktight; milkweed; mustard greens and all other non-woody grasses and plants growing in the city to a height greater than eight (8) inches. This does not apply to vegetation which is being grown as a crop, livestock pasture, garden, or property that has been designated by the director as a natural area or native planting. 
(Ord. No. 920, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 24-17. - Duty to cut or kill weeds and noxious vegetation. 
    It shall be the duty of the occupant, person in charge, or owner of any lot in the city to keep the lot free from noxious vegetation and to cut or spray with a generally accepted chemical for weed control such noxious vegetation at such time as may be necessary to prevent its growth. 
(Ord. No. 920, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 24-18. - Notice to cut or kill weeds and noxious vegetation. 
(a)  The city may, at the beginning of or during the growing season, by public notice to each occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot require all weeds and noxious vegetation upon any lot to be cut or sprayed with a generally accepted chemical for weed and noxious vegetation control within five (5) days after the giving of the notice. The notice need not be given personally, but may be given generally by one (1) publication in the official newspaper once in each growing season. 
(b)  The notice given pursuant to subsection (a) shall provide that each occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot shall cut or spray with a generally accepted chemical for weed and noxious vegetation control at all times during the growing season, all weeds and noxious vegetation, and shall further provide that in case of failure to so cut or spray the weeds and noxious vegetation, the city will cause the weeds and noxious vegetation to be cut or sprayed and assess the cost thereof, including the cost of levying a special assessment, against the property benefited. 
(c)  In addition to, or as an alternative to the abatement of any weeds or noxious vegetation, any occupant, person in charge or owner found in violation of section 24-17 may be fined in the amount of thirty dollars ($30.00) for the first offense, sixty dollars ($60.00) for the second offense and $100.00 for each subsequent offense thereafter within any one-year period. 
(d)  No person shall intentionally interfere or attempt to interfere with the cutting, spraying or removal of vegetation that has been deemed noxious per section 24-16. 
(Ord. No. 920, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 24-19. - Compliance with notice. 
    The occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot in the city shall, within five (5) days after the publication of a notice pursuant to this article, and at all times subsequent during the growing season as may be necessary, cut or spray with a generally accepted chemical for weed control all noxious vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 920, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 24-20. - When weeds and other noxious vegetation may be cut or killed by the city.
