    Whenever the city determines that a property owner, occupant or person in charge has failed to cut weeds and other noxious vegetation or spray with a generally accepted chemical for control of all noxious vegetation upon the lot as required, the city shall make a reasonable attempt to give notice to the property owner, occupant or person in charge that weeds or noxious vegetation has been found on their property and that they must cut or chemically treat within five (5) days of the giving of this notice or the city will cause the weeds or noxious vegetation to be cut or chemically treated and all costs incurred shall be reimbursed to the city as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 920, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 24-21. - Special assessment for city weed and other noxious vegetation destruction. 
(a)  The city shall cause an account to be kept against each lot of the cost for the cutting or spraying of weeds and noxious vegetation during the growing season of each year, and the account shall be certified to the finance officer on or before the first day of December of each year. 
(b)  The finance officer shall prepare an estimate of the assessment against each lot for the cutting or spraying of weeds and noxious vegetation for the preceding growing season, including therein the expense of levying the special assessment against each lot. The estimate shall be submitted to the board of commissioners for its approval on or before the first day of January of each year. 
(c)  The finance officer shall cause to be published in the official newspaper a notice of the time and place when the board of commissioners will meet for the purpose of approving the estimate, which notice shall be published once, not less than one (1) week before the hearing. 
(d)  Upon the day for hearing, the board of commissioners shall meet and, if it shall find the estimate correct, it shall approve the estimate by resolution, or if not correct, it shall correct or modify the estimate and approve it as modified or corrected, and file the assessment roll with the finance officer. 
(e)  From the date of the approval and filing of the assessment roll with the finance officer, the same assessment roll shall be and become a special lien against the various pieces of property described in it, and the assessment shall be collected in like manner as special assessments for public improvements are now collected. 
(Ord. No. 920, 1-26-09) 
State Law reference- Financing of public improvements, SDCL 1967, § 9-43-1 et seq. 
Secs. 24-22-24-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 538, adopted Nov. 14, 1983, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-16 as ch. 24, art. III, §§ 24-32-24-47, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 24-32. - Definitions. 
(a)  Street Trees: "Street trees" are herein defined as trees, shrubs and all other woody vegetation on boulevards which would be on land lying between the established curbline and the street right-of-way line within the city. 
(b)  Park Trees: "Park trees" are herein defined as trees, shrubs and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has access as a park. 
(c)  Private Trees: "Private trees" are those trees and all other woody vegetation on private lots and residences within the city. 
(d)  Public Trees: "Public trees" shall include all trees now or hereafter growing on any street or any public areas where otherwise indicated. 
(e)  Small Trees: Trees less than twenty (20) feet tall at maturity. 
(f)  Medium Trees: Trees between twenty (20) and forty (40) feet tall at maturity. 
(g)  Large Trees: Trees larger than forty (40) feet tall at maturity. 
(h)  Pests: An insect or disease that attacks a tree or woody vegetation. 
(i)  Tree Board: The parks and recreation board will be the advisory board that is responsible for assisting in the study of trees. 
(j)  Parks: "Parks" shall include all public parks having individual names. 
(k)  Person: "Person" is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or political subdivision of any kind. 
(l)  Public Places: "Public places" shall include all other grounds, owned by the City of Yankton, lying within the County of Yankton, State of South Dakota, or under its control or supervision whether owned, leased or under contract of the city. 
(m)  Property Owner: "Property owner" shall mean the person owning such property as shown by the records on file at the city offices. 
(n)  Trees and Shrubs: "Trees and shrubs" shall include all woody vegetation now or hereafter growing on any public or private property. 
(o)  Plants: "Plants" shall include all "nonwoody" vegetation now or hereafter growing on any public or private property. 
(p)  City: "City" shall mean the elected and/or designated official, authorized agent or employees of the City of Yankton lying within the County of Yankton, State of South Dakota, assigned to carry out the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 1, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-33. - Tree board. 
    The parks and recreation board will assume the responsibilities as the tree board. The board shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 2, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-34. - Planting. 
    The permit requirements of this article shall not apply to the planting of grass, annual flowers or similar nonwoody vegetation. 
    The city is herein responsible for tree planting in all city parks and established control of street tree planting on boulevards. Private planting of trees is not subject to city control, but the city encourages desirable species and planting practices. 
    No person shall plant or set out any tree or plant on a boulevard or in a public place without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the city. The application required herein shall state the number of trees or plants to be planted or set out, the location and variety of each tree or plant, and such other information as the city shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued hereunder. 
    The city shall issue the permit for the planting of a tree or plant on a boulevard or in a public place when it is found that the proposed planting conforms as to species and location for the street or area involved. 
    The city may designate agents to accept applications and issue permits for the planting of trees and other vegetation covered under this article. No fee shall be charged for any permit issued under this section. 
    The city will issue a desirable species list for tree planting in the city. The list will contain a minimum of ten (10) species in order to provide a diversity of tree types. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 3, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-35. - Spacing. 
    The spacing for all street tree plantings will be done in accordance with the species size classes listed in the desirable species list for tree planting within the city as follows: No street trees may be planted closer together than the following: 
Small trees: Twenty (20) feet; 
Medium trees: Thirty (30) feet; and 
Large trees: Thirty (30) feet; 
except in special plantings designed or approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 4, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-36. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
    No tree shall be planted where the distance between the curb and sidewalk is less than four (4) feet. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 5, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-37. - Distance from street corners and fire plugs. 
    Street trees near street intersections shall be planted in accordance with Ordinance No. 487, section IV.-9B [the zoning ordinance]. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 6, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-38. - Utilities. 
    No street trees, except small trees, may be planted under or within ten (10) feet of overhead utility wires. No trees shall be planted over or within five (5) feet of any underground water, sewer or other service lines. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 7, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-39. - Tree care. 
    The city will be responsible for all tree care aspects of park trees and will accomplish insect and disease control for street trees when determined by the city that a pest is a serious threat to other trees and for which there is an adequate control measure. 
    For any trees or shrubs now situated on or hereafter planted in the public right-of-way, it shall be the duty of the abutting property owner to maintain trees in a safe and healthy condition and in every way in compliance with the provisions of this article. Further, it shall be the duty of each property owner to maintain all trees on his property in a healthy and safe condition. If the property owner fails to so maintain the trees, the city, after thirty (30) days' written notice to maintain the tree, or trees, may perform the required maintenance or removal and charge the costs of the same to the property owner for collection in the same manner as other special assessments. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 8, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-40. - Clearance. 
    Any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall have the branches trimmed so that such branches shall not block or otherwise inhibit street and sidewalk traffic and signs controlling traffic. All large established trees shall be trimmed in such a manner so as to allow ten (10) feet clearance over sidewalks and twelve (12) feet clearance over all streets; however, trees along principal traffic thoroughfares shall be trimmed so as to allow clearance of at least sixteen (16) feet. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property that obstructs the view of any street intersection, street lighting or visibility of any traffic-control device or sign. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 9, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-41. - Tree topping. 
    Tree topping shall be prohibited as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department of any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the city. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 10, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-42. - Tree removal. 
    Dead, hazardous or diseased tree removal will be the responsibility of the city for park and street trees. For removal of street trees, whether they are dead, hazardous or diseased, or not dead, hazardous or diseased, permission must first be obtained from the city. The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased private trees on private property within the city. The landowner will be responsible for removing private trees that constitute a hazard to life and property or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by the owners at their own expense within thirty (30) days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and assess the cost of removal to the property owner in the same manner as other special assessments. Dead trees shall be removed. Trees will also be removed if they cannot be returned to an acceptable condition as determined by the city or any of its authorized agents. Trees harboring contagious pests for which there is no established control shall be removed. 
    Determination of a pest problem will be made by the city or authority acting for them. If the pest cannot be determined at the site with reasonable certainty by the city or other authority, samples will be taken for diagnosis to determine the pest. 
    Wood from dead, substantially dead or infected trees may be used as firewood as long as that wood does not harbor a contagious pest or can be treated to prevent harboring contagious pests. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 11, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-43. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the tops of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. The city shall only be responsible for the removal of those stumps of trees the city cuts down. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 12, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-44. - Abatement. 
    The failure of owners to comply with planting, spacing, minimum distance, utilities, trimming and tree removal provisions of this article shall constitute a nuisance; and the city shall have the authority to abate the nuisance and assess the cost associated with the abatement to the property owner by special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 13, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-45. - Interference with city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city while engaging in the inspection or removal of any street trees, park trees, or private trees, as authorized in this article. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 14, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-46. - Review by tree board. 
    Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city, as defined in section 24-32, to the tree board, who may hear the matter. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 15, 11-14-83) 
Sec. 24-47. - Review by city commission. 
    The city commission shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the city commission, who may hear the matter and make final decision. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 16, 11-14-83) 
Chapter 26 - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing, Ch. 18; utilities, Ch. 231/2. 
State Law reference- Municipal water supply systems, SDCL 1967, § 9-48-1 et seq.; municipal sewer systems, SDCL 1967, § 9-48-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-1. - Separate trenches required for water and sewer mains. 
(a)  Water supply mains must not be laid in the same trench with sewer mains, but an entirely separate trench must be provided therefor, which water and sewer trenches shall not be less than ten (10) feet apart, unless written permission is granted by the administrative authority. 
(b)  In cases where sewer trunk mains or sewer service mains and water trunk mains or water service mains cross, the sewer mains shall be of cast iron for a distance of at least five (5) feet on each side of the water mains, with joints being made according to plans and specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 10.0104, 12.0315; Ord. No. 590, § 1, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 26-2. - Rates and charges for city water and sewerage services generally. 
    The rates and charges to be imposed by the city for water and sewerage services furnished by it shall be as established from time to time by the board of city commissioners by resolution, and shall be on file in the office of the finance officer. 
(1)  There shall be established a monthly special water debt service surcharge. 
(2)  The water debt service surcharge rates shall be based on water service meter sizes and shall be set from time to time by the board of city commissioners by resolution, and shall be on file in the office of the finance officer. 
(3)  The allocation of the revenues derived from the said surcharge shall be segregated from other income of the water system and shall only be used to defray the annual debt service for drinking water SRF loans numbers one through four (1-4) and the proposed drinking water loan number five (5) for the proposed new collector well. 
(4)  If the surcharge rates do not raise sufficient funds to pay the SRF loans one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), and five (5), then the surcharge rates may be increased by resolution of the board of city commissioners but, in no instance, shall general fund proceeds be used to repay the SRF loans. 
(5)  At such time as the SRF loans are defeased or paid in full, subsections 26-2(1)-(5) shall be automatically repealed without any further action of the city. 
(Ord. No. 958, 7-22-13) 
Sec. 26-3. - Department of utilities: Established; functions; composition. 
    There is hereby established the department of utilities of the city, which department shall operate and maintain the city water and sewerage systems. The department of utilities shall consist of the director of municipal utilities and such number of employees as the board of commissioners may prescribe. 
Sec. 26-4. - Director of municipal utilities. 
(a)  There is hereby established the office of director of municipal utilities, who shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(b)  The duties of the director of municipal utilities shall be to superintend the extension of the water and sewerage systems, the making of all connections therewith, and making of all necessary repairs thereto. The director of municipal utilities shall, under the direction of the city manager, have charge of the city water and sewerage systems and shall cause to be read the meters of water consumers of the city and report the amount of water consumed by each consumer as frequently as may be required of him by the city manager. The director of municipal utilities shall perform such other and further duties as shall be prescribed by this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 1.0211) 
Sec. 26-5. - General authority of members of the department of utilities. 
(a)  The director of municipal utilities or other officer or employee of the department of utilities, shall have the power to enter the premises or building of any consumer at any reasonable hour for the purpose of reading, removing, installing, testing, or repairing water meters or for examining piping. 
(b)  The director of municipal utilities or other officer or employee of the department of utilities shall have the power to shut the water off from any premises for nonpayment of water bills or to enforce the repair of the service line between the water main and the water meter, or to prevent the waste of water. 
(c)  The director of municipal utilities or other officer or employee of the department of utilities shall have the right to shut off the water from any water main for the purpose of repairs or improvements. 
(Rev. Ords. 1949, § 12.0308) 
Sec. 26-6. - Criteria for providing water and sewer service to locations that do not use metered city water service. 
    This section is created to ensure the adequate, equitable provision of municipal level fire protection and sanitary sewer services to residents of the City of Yankton and locations outside the City of Yankton that are important to the overall development of the community. The specific application of these provisions will be at locations where the City of Yankton does not serve metered water but is willing to provide fire protection and sanitary sewer service to promote the safe, healthy development of the community. 
    Therefore, water for fire protection and/or sanitary sewer service may be provided to locations based on the following criteria: 
(1)  Requirements of the city's subdivision regulations shall be accounted for. 
(2)  Permits for access to the city service are required. 
(3)  Domestic water shall be metered with remote read capabilities compatible with the city's system. Or, the applicant for service shall purchase the remote read equipment from the city and provide for the installation and inspection thereof. 
(4)  The monthly rate for access to water for fire protection shall be set using the city's established base rate for the size of meter used. 
(5)  The monthly sanitary sewer rate shall be based on the water used at the location as documented by the reading of the installed meter. 
(6)  City hydrant meters are not allowed without written consent from the provider serving the location. 
    Rates for the described services may change by resolution of the board of city commissioners. 
    The board of city commissioners may also apply the provisions of this section to locations outside of the corporate limits by separate action. 
(Ord. No. 942, 6-13-11) 
DIVISION 2. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Sec. 26-7. - Authority. 
    Pursuant to SDCL 9-47-1, the city commission shall have authority to regulate the distribution and use of water supplied by the city. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-8. - Purposes. 
    The city finds that the greater the water capacity usage the more need there is for water conservation. As a result, this division 2 was enacted for the purposes of conserving water, protecting the limited capacity of available water, and assisting the economical production of water. 
    The ordinances herein apply only when the outside watering source is taken from the city's water system or a system supplied from the city water system. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-9. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions apply to words used in this division: 
    Hand watering is any form of application of water on vegetation such as lawns, shrubbery, trees, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, and flowers, other than through an underground irrigation or sprinkler system. 
    Newly established lawn or landscaping is either the first introduction of grass and/or landscaping or replacing an existing grass yard or landscaping. 
    Water capacity refers to the total gallons of daily, potable water available to the city. 
    Water waste occurs when a person allows excess water to run into a gutter, ditch, or drain, or failing to repair a controllable water leak. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-10. - Water conservation measures established. 
    The city hereby establishes the following the water conservation measures: 
(1)  Stage 1 water conservation - Seventy-five (75) percent of capacity. When the city has reached seventy-five (75) percent of its water capacity the following water conservation measure shall automatically arise: 
a.  Lawn watering for all residential, commercial, industrial, and city facilities with an irrigation system or sprinkler will use the following schedule: 
1.  Consumers having even-numbered addresses may water on even-numbered calendar dates and consumers having odd-numbered addresses may water on odd-numbered calendar dates. 
2.  Consumers are prohibited from lawn watering between the hours of 12:00 noon and 5:00 p.m. These are year-round restrictions. 
b.  Permits, as set forth in section 26-13 herein, for newly established lawns or landscaping may be granted. 
c.  Water waste is prohibited at all times. 
d.  Hand watering is permitted any time of day. 
e.  Washing vehicles at a residence is permitted any time. Use of an automatic shut off nozzle or bucket of five (5) gallons or less is recommended to prevent water waste. 
f.  The use of commercial vehicle wash facilities is permitted any day. 
(2)  Stage 2 water conservation - Eighty-five (85) percent of capacity. When the city has reached eighty-five (85) percent of its water capacity the following water conservation measure shall automatically arise: 
a.  Lawn watering for all residential, commercial, industrial, and city facilities with an irrigation system or sprinkler will use the following schedule: 
1.  Consumers may water only one (1) day during each week following this schedule based on the last number of the address. 
Monday - 0 
Tuesday - 1 
Wednesday - 2 and 3 
Thursday - 4 
Friday - 5 
Saturday - 6 and 7 
Sunday - 8 and 9 
2.  Lawn watering is prohibited during the hours of noon to 5:00 p.m. daily. 
b.  Permits, as set forth in section 26-13 herein, for a newly planted lawn or landscape may be granted. 
c.  Water waste is prohibited at all times. 
d.  Hand watering is permitted any time of day. 
e.  Washing vehicles or other equipment at a residence is permitted any time. Use of an automatic shut off nozzle or bucket of five (5) gallons or less is recommended to prevent water waste. 
f.  The use of commercial vehicle wash facilities is permitted any day. 
g.  Washing outdoor surfaces such as parking lots, driveways, streets, or sidewalks is prohibited unless necessary for the public's health, safety, and welfare. 
(3)  Stage 3 water conservation - Ninety (90) percent of capacity. When the city has reached ninety (90) percent of its water capacity the following water conservation measure shall automatically arise: 
a.  All landscape watering is prohibited. 
b.  No permits for newly established lawn or landscape shall be granted. 
c.  Water waste is prohibited at all times. 
d.  Hand watering is permitted any time of day if the water is applied by a bucket no larger than five (5) gallons or by a hose that does not leak and is equipped with a hand-held nozzle that automatically shuts off when released. All watering authorized herein should be the minimum amount of water necessary and where no puddling or runoff of water will occur. 
e.  Washing vehicles or other equipment at a residence is prohibited. 
f.  The use of commercial vehicle wash facilities is permitted any day. 
g.  Washing outdoor surfaces such as parking lots, driveways, streets, or sidewalks is prohibited unless necessary for the public's health, safety, and welfare. 
h.  The use of water to wash down buildings or structures other than preparation for painting or immediate fire protection is prohibited. 
i.  Use of ornamental fountains, waterfalls, ponds or other aesthetic water features-outdoors or indoors-is prohibited unless the fountain is necessary to support aquatic life or where the fountain or pond is equipped with a recirculation system. 
j.  Water runoff onto streets is prohibited. 
(4)  Stage 4 water conservation - Ninety-five (95) percent of capacity. When the city has reached ninety-five (95) percent of its water capacity the following water conservations measure shall automatically arise: 
a.  All outdoor water use is prohibited. 
b.  No permits for newly established lawns or landscapes shall be granted. 
c.  Water waste is prohibited at all times. 
d.  Hand watering is prohibited. 
e.  Consumers shall attempt to reduce water consumption by any means available. 
f.  Washing vehicles or other equipment at a residence or commercial facilities is prohibited unless necessary for the public's health, safety, and welfare. 
g.  Washing outdoor surfaces such as parking lots, driveways, streets, or sidewalks is prohibited unless necessary for the public's health, safety, and welfare. 
h.  The use of water to wash down buildings or structures other than immediate fire protection is prohibited. 
i.  Use of ornamental fountains, waterfalls, ponds or other aesthetic water features-outdoors or indoors-is prohibited unless the fountain is necessary to support aquatic life. 
j.  Refilling of private, commercial, and public swimming pools is prohibited. 
k.  Water for dust control and the washing of streets is prohibited unless deemed necessary for the public's health, safety, and welfare. 
l.  All residential water users are requested to limit their use of water to fifty (50) gallons per person per day. 
m.  The city may ban other uses of water determined to be nonessential at any time. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-11. - Notification to public. 
    If the city initiates a water conservation measure or changes from one stage to another stage, then it shall publish a notice of its new determination in the legal newspaper and shall make appropriate news releases to inform the public. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-12. - Excess water permits and application. 
    Upon written application by the water user, the environmental services director may grant an excess water permit for use of water otherwise prohibited hereby, if it is found that the restrictions in this division: 
(1)  Are not warranted by weather conditions; or 
(2)  Would cause an unnecessary and undue economic or other hardship to the applicant or to the public; or 
(3)  Would cause an emergency condition affecting the health, sanitation, fire protection or safety of the applicant or the public. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-13. - Excess water permits; grant or denial. 
    Within ten (10) working days after receipt of an application for an excess water permit, the environmental services director shall inform the applicant in writing of his or her decision, including any reasons for refusing the permit. The city may revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance involving water use or a violation of the permit conditions, if any. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 26-14. - Enforcement and violations. 
(a)  The city manager or their designee shall, in connection with his or her duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this division. 
(b)  If a person fails to meet the applicable provision of law due to a violation of this division, then the city may terminate water service as set forth in section 26-38 and section 26-39. 
(c)  The maximum punishment for violating any provision found within this division is a two-hundred-dollar ($200.00) fine. 
(Ord. No. 955, 4-22-13) 
Secs. 26-15, 26-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 427, adopted July 26, 1976, repealed former Art. II, the substantive provisions of which were found in §§ 26-17-26-36, 26-43-26-46 and 26-54-26-59, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Art. II, §§ 26-17-26-38, 26-43-26-50 and 26-53-26-60. The article was formerly derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 12.0103, 12.0104(a), 12.0105(a), (b), 12.0301-12.0314, and Ord. No. 276, §§ 1-3, adopted Sept. 14, 1964. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-17. - Purpose of article; water furnished subject to provisions of article. 
(a)  The rules and regulations prescribed in this article are established for governing the waterworks of the city and the control of all persons doing any plumbing in and upon any of the mains, connections or appliances appertaining to the city waterworks. 
(b)  Any person applying for and receiving water from the waterworks system belonging to the city receives such water on the express condition that such water is taken subject to all rules and regulations prescribed by this article and penalties provided for any infraction of such rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-18. - Connection permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lay any water service pipe or introduce into or about any building or any grounds any water pipes, or do any plumbing work in any building or on any grounds for the purpose of connecting such pipes or plumbing, either directly or indirectly, to the city water mains, or make any additions to or alterations of any water pipes, water closet, stopcock or any other fixture of apparatus for the supply of any premises with water from the city water mains without obtaining a permit to do such work. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-19. - Persons who may work on city water system facilities. 
(a)  No person, except a regularly licensed plumbing contractor of the city or sewer and water installation contractor, his employees, or a regular employee of the department of utilities, shall be permitted to do any work, including tapping, in or upon any of the water mains or services or connecting pipes pertaining to the waterworks system of the city; and no plumbing contractor shall directly or indirectly allow any person to do any such work under his license except his qualified employees. 
(b)  All persons authorized by this section to work on the city water system shall be governed by all the rules and regulations of this article and any other rules or regulations that are now or may hereafter be adopted by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-20. - Separate service required for each consumer, exceptions. 
(a)  Not more than one (1) consumer shall be supplied from each water service line without special permission from the board of commissioners and upon the recommendation of the director of municipal utilities. 
(b)  Water pipes shall not be extended from one premises to another without special permission from the board of commissioners and upon the recommendation of the director of municipal utilities. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-21. - Installation of service lines. 
    The owner of the premises to be served shall have a licensed plumbing contractor or a licensed sewer and water installation contractor install all service pipes from the water mains to the lot lines in streets, alleys and avenues in the city, which pipes shall meet the standards prescribed by the plumbing code of the city. 
    The minimum size tap shall be one (1) inch, and the minimum size service line shall be one (1) inch from the tap through the curb box. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-22. - Manner of making excavations. 
    All excavations made upon the streets, alleys or public grounds of the city for the purpose of connecting with water mains or service pipes shall be made in accordance with sections 21-56 through 21-90, both inclusive. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Editor's note- Sections 21-86-21-90, relating to excavation contractors, were repealed by Ord. No. 470, adopted Jan. 9, 1978. 
Sec. 26-23. - Cross-connection prohibited. 
    No plumber or any other person shall make any cross-connection to the water system of the city with any other water system or a supply from a well, cistern or any other source whatever. No plumber or any other person shall make any cross-connection to the water system of the city and any drain pipes, sewer pipe or septic tank. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-24. - Testing pipes. 
    No water pipes laid under the ground shall be covered until after the water has been turned into the pipes and the pipes tested and found to be watertight. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-25. - Protection of service pipes from freezing. 
(a)  Outside of buildings and basements, all service pipes shall be laid at a depth of at least six (6) feet below grade. 
(b)  All service pipes, where entering any building or basement, shall be thoroughly protected from frost by proper insulating material. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76; Ord. No. 590, § 2, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 26-26. - Curb stop boxes required. 
    A curb stop box of a type and design approved by the director of municipal utilities shall be placed on the water service pipe and be maintained accessible at all times, and no person not a direct employee of the department of municipal utilities shall open or close or otherwise interfere with such curb stop unless he has written permission from the department. All curb stop boxes on services up to and including two (2) inches shall be a ball valve type. All curb stops over two (2) inches shall be gate valves. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-27. - Location of stop boxes. 
    All stop boxes and cutoffs for controlling the supply of water to consumers shall be placed between the curb and as close as possible to the property line, as designated by the director of municipal utilities, with the top of the stop box even with the grade of the sidewalk or the parking. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-28. - Maintenance of pipes and fixtures. 
(a)  The city shall not be responsible for pipes and fixtures. All premises owners must, at their own expense, keep their service pipe from the point of connection with the city mains to their premises and all other apparatus in good working order and properly protected from frost and other danger. In the event of improvements such as concrete or asphalt surfacing, it shall be the owner's responsibility to place the curb stop to the proper grade. 
(b)  Any leaky service pipe leading to a water meter shall be properly repaired on notice given by the city, or water shall be shut off. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-29. - Special requirements for connecting water-cooled refrigeration compressors to the city water system. 
(a)  Permit Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to install any water-cooled refrigeration compressor connected with the water system of the city unless he shall have first obtained a permit therefor from the city building inspector. 
(b)  Water Conservation Devices. All water-cooled compressors shall be equipped with water conservation devices so that water from the city mains shall be used for "make-up" and "flushing" purposes only, and the water conservation devices must be of a type that the refrigeration compressor will not use in excess of five-tenths (0.5) gallon per minute per ton and shall be equipped with a device capable of controlling the water flow into the compressor. 
(c)  Inspections; Discontinuance of service. The city shall have the right of inspection of any premises operating water-cooled refrigeration compressors at reasonable hours, and the city shall have the right to discontinue water service to any property not in compliance with the terms and provisions of this section, and service discontinued for such reason will not be renewed until the property is in full compliance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-30. - Expense of excavation and repair of curb stops, corporation cocks and service line. 
(a)  It shall be the owner's responsibility to dig up and repair any corporation cock, curb stop or service line in the event they are damaged or deteriorated. If, in the opinion of the director of municipal utilities, the corporation cock, curb stop or service line cannot be properly repaired, it shall be replaced in accordance with the same requirements as a new service. 
(b)  If it becomes necessary for the city to dig up or repair a corporation cock or to dig up a curb stop to shut off water, the cost of the labor and materials required may be added to the water bill for the premises and considered a part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-31. - Inspection of fixtures. 
    All water meters, and all water fixtures, appliances and appurtenances on private premises connected with the city water system shall be open to inspection by the proper employees of the city at all reasonable and proper hours. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-32. - Duty of plumbers to turn water off or on. 
(a)  In the Case of New Service. In no case shall any plumber, after the completion and test of any service line for a new consumer, leave the water turned on to the premises. 
(b)  In the Case of Repairs. In the case of leaks or other accidents to pipes or apparatus connected with the city water mains, the plumber may shut off the water to make the necessary repairs. 
(c)  In All Cases. In all cases a plumber shall leave the water shut off or turned on as he found it to be when he commenced work on the service or premises, except that the corporation cock on approved new or repair service shall be left open. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-33. - Restoration of service terminated for nonpayment of charges. 
    No person shall turn on the supply of water to a service pipe from which the supply has been turned off by the city on account of the nonpayment of water charges, or other violation. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-34. - Charge for turning water on. 
    There shall be a charge established by the board of commissioners by resolution for turning on water which has been turned off, which charge shall be paid before the water is turned on. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-35. - Liability of city for failure of water supply. 
    No claim shall be made against the city by reason of the breaking of service pipes or for the breaking of any apparatus, meters, water coils in furnaces or stoves or other apparatus connected with service pipes or for an accidental failure in the supply of water; or damage resulting from shutting off of water to make repairs or any other purpose; or by reason of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-36. - Liability of plumber for failure to comply with this article or for defective workmanship. 
    Any plumber shall be liable upon his bond as a plumber for any and all damages which may be sustained by reason of defective workmanship or the failure to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-37. - Water mains. 
    It is hereby established by the city that the minimum size water main to be installed in any city distribution system shall be six (6) inches in diameter. 
    All water mains constructed outside the city limits which are to receive direct service from the city water supply system shall be subject to the same requirements and specifications set forth for mains constructed within the city limits, except that all construction costs shall be paid by the person requesting the water with no obligation of any degree or amount upon the city. 
    Each usage served outside the city shall pay such costs and rates as may be established by the city for services and uses outside the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-38. - Termination of service authorized. 
    The city shall have the right to disconnect or refuse to connect or reconnect any utility service for the following reasons: 
(a)  Failure to meet the applicable provisions of law. 
(b)  Violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to utility service. 
(c)  Nonpayment of bills. 
(d)  Willful or negligent waste of service due to improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures, appliances or otherwise. 
(e)  Molesting any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating the supply of utility service. 
(f)  Theft or diversion and/or use of service without payment therefor. 
(g)  Vacancy of premises. 
(h)  Refusal to permit the inspection, testing, repair or replacement of water service meters. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76; Ord. No. 975, 3-23-15) 
Sec. 26-39. - Procedures for disconnection of water service. 
(a)  The board of city commissioners hereby adopts a formal procedure for the disconnection and reconnection of water service based upon the reasons contained in section 26-38 of this Code. 
(b)  The director of utilities is hereby authorized to discontinue water service on an emergency basis for violation of items (a), (b), (d), (e), (f), (g), or (h) under section 26-38 of this Code. The finance officer of the city shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of the discontinuance of service or by the next business day, give notice by either telephone, visit, or certificate of mailing to the person or firm which has applies for and received water service at this location, and if applicable, separate notice to the owner of the business. Such notice shall state the reason for the emergency discontinuance of the service, the steps to be taken so service can be reestablished and shall notify customer and/or the landlord of the appeal procedure contained in this section. 
(c)  The water service for any customer may be terminated upon notice and opportunity for a hearing as provided for later in this section for nonpayment of bills as provided in subsection 26-38(c) of this Code. The notice shall be given by either telephone, visit or certificate of mailing on the proposed termination of service and shall include the notice of right to appeal and hearing as contained in this section. 
(d)  There is hereby established an appeal procedure for customers or property owners whose water service is terminated for any of the reasons outlined in section 26-38 of this Code. 
(1)  Appeal procedure for termination of service under section 26-38, subsection (a), (b), (d), (e), (f), (g) or (h). The city may terminate service on an emergency basis for reasons cited under any of these subsections. The city shall immediately, by either telephone, visit or certificate of mailing, give notice to both the customer and if appropriate, the property owner. The notice shall include an indication that the property owner or the customer has the right to appeal the termination of service. The appeal shall be made within seven (7) days of the receipt of the notice by either the customer or if appropriate, the property owner. The appeal shall be made to the city manager of the city. The city manager shall establish a date within five (5) days of the receipt of the request for an appeal at which time the finance officer of the city and the appellant shall appear before the city manager and present their information related to the termination of service. The city manager shall within five (5) days of the close of the hearing rule as to the propriety of the termination of service. If the city manager rules that the service should not have been terminated, the service shall be restored without charge to the customer. 
(2)  Appeals for termination of service under subsection 26-38(c), nonpayment of bills. The finance officer shall provide notice by either telephone, visit or certificate of mailing to customers and, if appropriate, property owners of intent to terminate service for nonpayment of bills. The customer or property owner shall be given a date not less than five (5) days after the receipt of the notice on which service shall be terminated unless an appeal is filed. A customer or property owner may file an appeal of the notice of intent to terminate with the city manager. The city manager within five (5) days of the date of the receipt of notice of appeal shall establish a hearing at which time the finance officer and appellant may appear before the city manager and present information and evidence as to reasons why water service should either be terminated or not terminated. The city manager shall render a decision within five (5) days of the date of the hearing. The decision shall be rendered in writing and delivered to all parties. The water service shall not be terminated during the appeal process and until the decision is made by the city manager. 
(e)  Any party to the hearing under either of the previous paragraphs may appeal the decision of the city manager to circuit court as provided by law. 
(f)  It is the express policy of the board of city commissioners that once a water service is terminated for nonpayment of bills, the service shall not be restored until all unpaid bills are paid and become current. The purpose of establishing the appeal procedure contained in this section is to allow proper notice to both the customer and if appropriate, the property owner to allow for due process prior to the termination of utility service. It is the policy of the board of city commissioners that should a customer not pay a bill for a property not owned by the customer and the water service is terminated after following the procedures contained in this section for nonpayment of the bill, the service shall not be restored until the past due bill is paid by either the customer or the property owner. The city manager and finance officer are authorized and directed to implement this policy on behalf of the city. 
(g)  Alternative resolution procedure for unpaid bills. The finance officer of the city is hereby authorized to enter into payment agreements with customers who are delinquent in their bills. The payment agreement shall be on a form developed and approved by the finance officer of the city and shall be executed by the customer or property owner, and by the finance officer or designee on behalf of the city. The failure of a customer or property owner to comply with the terms of the payment agreement shall be grounds for termination of service without further notice. 
(Ord. No. 695.1, §§ 1-7, 9-12-94; Ord. No. 771, § 1, 3-23-98; Ord. No. 975, 3-23-15) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 695.1, adopted Sept. 12, 1994, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ 1-7 of said ordinance as § 26-39 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 26-40-26-42. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 26-43. - Application and contract for water service prerequisites to connections. 
(a)  An application for water service must be made by a consumer to the finance officer, stating the street and number where water service is desired. 
(b)  The applicant for water service shall sign a contract therefor, agreeing to abide with the rules and regulations of the department of utilities, which contract shall be filed in the office of the finance officer. In addition thereto, a minimum deposit established by the board of commissioners by resolution shall be required. Refund of the deposit shall be made upon termination of the service only after payment of all indebtedness to the city. Application of deposit may be made in partial or total settlement of accounts when supply is cut off for nonpayment of bill or for any infraction or violation of any ordinance, rule or regulation of the city relative to water services offered by the city. 
(c)  No water shall be turned on to any user until a water meter has been installed, a turn-on fee has been paid and a contract for water service has been signed. The contract shall provide that all water used through the meter from the time the water was turned on until the time a written request from the user to turn the water off shall be paid by the consumer named in the contract. The water shall not be turned on again until another contract has been signed and the turn-on fee has been paid. 
(d)  No new taps to the city water system shall be made until a connection permit has been issued pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-44. - Connection permit required. 
    Each person authorized by this article to work on the water system of the city shall, before connecting with or tapping any water main, obtain a written connection permit therefor from the director of municipal services, which permit shall specify the time and place at which the tap or connection may be performed. The applicant shall give the department of utilities at least twenty-four (24) hours' advance notice in order to schedule the tapping operation. 
    The permit fee shall include the water main assessment or hookup charge, basic water system charge for the proper use category, the excavation permit fee, the cost of tapping the water main and the cost of furnishing and installation of the water service meter. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-45. - Persons who may make taps. 
(a)  The city shall make all taps up to one (1) inch. 
(b)  All taps over one (1) inch shall be made by a licensed plumbing contractor or by a licensed sewer and water installation contractor, with equipment and methods approved by the director of municipal utilities. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-46. - Maximum tap size. 
    The following sizes of taps in water mains shall not be exceeded: 
    4" Pipe-Tap size-1" diameter; 
    6" or larger Pipe-Tap size-2" diameter 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76; Ord. No. 695, § 1, 4-11-94) 
Sec. 26-47. - Location of taps when more than one required. 
    Where more than one (1) tap is required, such taps shall be placed at least eighteen (18) inches apart on the main; and in no case shall a tap be made closer than twenty-four (24) inches from the face of the bell. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-48. - Maximum size of corporation stops. 
    No corporation stops shall be inserted (threaded) in the city mains larger than one and one-quarter (11/4) inches in diameter. All services over two (2) inches shall be by a cut-in tee installed in the main. Brass saddles may be used for taps up to two (2) inches in diameter. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76; Ord. No. 695, § 2, 4-11-94) 
Sec. 26-49. - Connection fees. 
    The fees for making a connection to the city water system shall be as prescribed from time to time by the board of commissioners by resolution, and shall be on file in the office of the finance officer. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-50. - Fire hydrants usage. 
    Only authorized personnel of the city shall operate fire hydrants throughout the city on the routine basis of operation, maintenance or testing. The city may authorize certain other authorized personnel to operate hydrants for special purposes. 
    The members of the fire department shall operate the fire hydrants during fire or other emergency situations. 
    A person, corporation, agency or others desiring permission to receive water from a fire hydrant shall make a written application to the city which outlines the purpose. The city after review and approval shall issue a permit to divert water through a fire hydrant, designate the hydrant for use, and install the connection with gate valve and meter for control. The city shall charge a connection charge for an approved temporary connection to a fire hydrant. In addition, other water charges shall be made in accordance with the water rate schedule established for other bulk water users. 
    All water used through fire hydrants for purposes other than emergencies shall be accounted for and measured. The opening and closing of fire hydrants shall be kept at a minimum. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 26-51. - Pressure reducing valves. 
    All property owners of buildings served by the municipal water system that have water service lines with a static pressure greater than one hundred (100) psi shall install and maintain pressure reducing valves on their water service line. Such valves shall be of an appropriate make, location and size approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 720, § 1, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 26-52. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WATER METERS 

Sec. 26-53. - One meter to each service; auxiliary meters. 
    The supply of water through each separate service must be recorded by one (1) meter only, for which only one (1) bill will be rendered by the city. If additional or auxiliary meters are desired for recording the subdivision of each supply, they must be furnished and set by the owner or consumer at his own expense; and he must assume all responsibility of maintaining and reading the same. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-54. - Determination of size. 
    The correct size of a water meter to be used on any service shall be determined by the director of municipal services. The minimum size meter shall be three-fourths (3/4) inch on all new or replaced services. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-55. - Installation of meters. 
(a)  Required. 
(1)  All customer water service meters installed shall be furnished and installed by the city as soon as possible after the tap has been made and the service line completed. The customer shall provide all connections ready to receive the meter. 
(2)  The owner shall provide a nonrestricting flow building valve located inside the building near the point where the water service enters and a nonrestricting flow meter valve on the discharge side of the meter. A dual check backflow preventer shall be installed on the building side of every water meter where the water service enters the building. 
A permanent meter bypass shall be installed on all water meters of one and one-quarter (11/4) inches and larger. The permanent bypass shall be connected on the discharge side of the dual check backflow preventer and the inlet side of the meter valve. The bypass shall be provided with nonrestricting flow valves at both points of connection with the building water distribution piping. 
(3)  All water meters for residential use shall be installed with remote reading devices mounted on the exterior of the structure. It shall be the owner's responsibility to provide and install the wiring from the meter register to the outside reader. 
(4)  No water shall be turned on to the customer until the meter has been installed. All meters owned by individual or business customers upon the effective date of this article shall have the option of assigning their meter to the city and transfer of ownership for perpetual care and maintenance without charge. Meters retained in individual or business ownership shall be assessed the actual cost of any service calls for the repair, cleaning or calibration work required for the meter. 
(b)  Exchange of Inoperative Meter. The city shall have the right to exchange any inoperative water meter under its jurisdiction at any location in the municipal water system with an operative meter and continue the replacement meter in service without returning the original meter. The city shall repair and test the replaced meter and utilize it as a replacement meter at another location in the system or may dispose of the meter if beyond repair. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76; Ord. No. 590, § 3, 1-26-87) 
Sec. 26-56. - Method of setting. 
    All water meters shall be set firm and level upon some substantial support not directly on the floor, and all connecting pipes shall be thoroughly cleansed before they are connected with the water meter, and all connections must be made without the use of red lead or other packing. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-57. - Meter to be accessible. 
(a)  The owner and occupant of any building or premises where a water meter is located shall see that the water meter is kept and remains free from obstruction on or around it, and that it is conveniently accessible at all times for the purpose of reading, inspecting and repairing. 
(b)  The water shall be turned off from any water meter that shall not be kept in a manner prescribed by subsection (a) and shall not be turned on again until subsection (a) is complied with and the costs of turning off and on are paid. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-58. - Remote reading device. 
    The department of municipal utilities will install a remote meter reading device on all existing residential customers meters whereby the meter can be read without entering the building. These devices will be installed when it becomes necessary to replace the existing meter. The cost of installing such device shall be the actual costs incurred for the materials and installation and will be billed to the property owner. The department will retain ownership, and the device will be under the control of the department at all times and shall be considered as part of the meter serving the property and shall not be removed or altered except by the department. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-59. - Protection from freezing. 
    Water meters, if in unheated rooms or basements, shall be covered with an insulated frostproof box or other frostproof materials. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 26-60. - Consumer responsibility for meter. 
(a)  Any water meter installed as provided in this division which shall be damaged by freezing or otherwise, by and through the fault or negligence of the party for whom the water meter shall have been installed, or any tenant of the person, or any member of his family, or in his employ or under his control, shall be repaired or replaced, as the case may require, at the cost and expense of the person for whom the water meter was installed. 
(b)  In the case of neglect or refusal to pay the charges imposed pursuant to subsection (a) on demand, the water supply may be turned off or the water meter removed, or both, and shall not be turned on again until the charges are paid, together with the costs of turning off and on the water supply. 
(Ord. No. 427, 7-26-76) 
Secs. 26-61-26-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 443, adopted June 13, 1979, repealed former Art. III, the substantive provisions of which were found in §§ 26-71-26-77, 26-84-26-92, and enacted in lieu thereof a new article, §§ 26-71-26-81. Formerly, the article was derived from Rev. Ords. 1949, §§ 5.0301(c), 10.0101-10.0103, 10.0106, 10.0201-10.0207, 10.0317. 
Cross reference- Sewers in subdivisions, § 17-55. 

Sec. 26-71. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Act shall mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972, P.L. 92-500. 
(2)  ASCE shall mean the American Society of Civil Engineers. 
(3)  ASTM shall mean the American Society for Testing and Materials. 
(4)  Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) of sewage, sewage effluent, polluted waters or industrial wastes shall mean the quantity of dissolved oxygen in milligrams per liter required during stabilization of the decomposable organic matter by aerobic biochemical action under standard laboratory procedures for five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius. The laboratory determinations shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in Standard Methods. 
(5)  Building (or house) drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
(6)  Building (or house) sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
(7)  Chemical oxygen demand (COD) of sewage, sewage effluent, polluted waters or industrial wastes is a measure of the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidant. The laboratory determination shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in Standard Methods. 
(8)  City shall mean the City of Yankton, South Dakota, or any duly authorized officials acting in its behalf. 
(9)  Classification of users: 
(a)  Domestic class user shall mean a user discharging normal domestic sewage, as hereinafter defined, into the system from single-family residences used for residential purposes. Specifically included in this classification are contractual customers serving a preponderance of single-family residences used for residential purposes. In the event such contractual customers serve any industrial users, a separate contract shall be required. 
(b)  Commercial class user shall mean any user not subject to other classifications herein defined, including but not limited to automotive service businesses such as filling stations and car washes; food-handling businesses such as restaurants and grocery stores; hair dressing shops and barbershops; office buildings; apartment complexes; retail dry goods stores; and motels. 
(c)  Industrial class user shall mean any user falling within division A, B, D, E or I as described in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget as amended and supplemented. A user in the divisions listed may be reclassified as commercial class if it is determined that it will introduce primarily segregated domestic waste or waste from sanitary conveniences. 
(d)  Contractual class user shall mean any user required to contract for services. 
(10)  Director shall mean the director of municipal services of the city, or his authorized deputy, agent or representatives. 
(11)  Effluent shall mean the water, together with any wastes that may be present, flowing out of a drain, sewer, receptacle or outlet. 
(12)  Emergency shall mean a combination of unforeseen circumstances which require an immediate remedy. Said emergency shall be declared by the city commissioners and shall be limited to a specific time period. 
(13)  Garbage shall mean any solid wastes from the preparation, cooking or dispensing of food and from the handling, storage or sale of produce. 
(14)  Ground garbage shall mean garbage that is shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely in suspension under the conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle being greater than one-half inch (1.3 centimeters) in dimension. 
(15)  Hearing board shall mean the board of commissioners. 
(16)  Industrial wastes shall mean any solid, liquid or gaseous substance or form of energy discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from an industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource carried on by any person as defined in subsection (23). 
(17)  Influent shall mean the water, together with any wastes that may be present, flowing into a drain, sewer, receptacle or outlet. 
(18)  Major contributing industry shall mean an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: 
(a)  Has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average work day; 
(b)  Has a flow greater than five (5) per cent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; 
(c)  Has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of the Act; or 
(d)  Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singularly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
(19)  NCPI shall mean the National Clay Pipe Institute. 
(20)  Normal domestic sewage, as defined for the purpose of determining eligibility for payment of surcharge, shall mean sewage having an average daily suspended solids concentration of not more than two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter, an average daily BOD of not more than two hundred twenty (220) milligrams per liter. 
(21)  NPDES permit shall mean a National Pollution Discharge Elimination System permit as issued by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for discharge of waste waters to navigable waters of the United States pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
(22)  Outlet shall mean any conveyance, natural or constructed, which is the point of final discharge of sewage or of treatment plant effluent into any watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
(23)  Person shall mean any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, association, trust, estate, public or private institution, group, agency, political subdivision or agency thereof or any legal successor, representative, agent or agency of the foregoing. 
(24)  pH shall mean the logarithm (to the base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution expressed in gram-atoms per liter of solution. 
(25)  Pollutants: 
(a)  Compatible pollutants shall mean waste with any pollutant that is an incompatible pollutant. 
(b)  Incompatible pollutants shall mean waste which contains any of the following described materials: 
(i)  Wastes which create a fire or explosion hazard in the publicly owned treatment works. 
(ii)  Wastes which will cause corrosive structural damage to treatment works, but in no case wastes with a pH lower than 5.0, unless the works is designed to accommodate such wastes. 
(iii)  Solid or viscous substances in amounts which would cause obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the publicly owned treatment works. 
(iv)  Waste waters at a flow rate and/or pollutant discharge rate which is excessive over relatively short time periods so that there is a treatment process upset and subsequent loss of treatment efficiency. 
(v)  Wastes which contain heat in such quantities that the influent waters to the publicly owned treatment works exceed one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (65°C). 
(vi)  Wastes, by themselves or in combination with other wastes, which contain substances or materials in concentrations which exceed the publicly owned treatment system's tolerance levels. 
(26)  Receiving stream shall mean the watercourse, stream or body of water receiving the waters finally discharged from the sewage treatment plant. 
(27)  Residential property unit shall mean a building under one (1) roof designed, arranged and used primarily for dwelling purposes by a single family. 
(28)  Sanitary sewage shall mean sewage discharged from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings, factories or institutions and free from storm water, surface water and industrial wastes. 
(29)  Sewage shall mean the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, singular or in any combination, together with such groundwaters, surface waters and storm waters as may be present. 
(30)  Sewage treatment plant or waste water treatment plant shall mean the arrangement of devices, structures and equipment used for treating and disposing of sewage and sludge. 
(31)  Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage or other waste liquids. 
(a)  Combined sewer shall mean a sewer which carries both storm water, surface water and groundwater runoff and sewage. 
(b)  Public sewer shall mean a sewer which is owned by the city. 
(c)  Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters, groundwaters and unpolluted industrial waste waters are not intentionally admitted. 
(d)  Storm sewer shall mean a sewer which carries storm water, surface water and groundwater drainage but excludes sanitary sewage. 
(32)  Sewerage system shall mean the network of sewers and appurtenances used for collecting, transporting and pumping sewage to the sewage treatment plant. 
(33)  Shall is mandatory; may is permissible. 
(34)  Slug shall mean any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
(35)  Standard methods shall mean the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published jointly by the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
(36)  Superintendent shall mean the chief operator of the waste water treatment plant at the city. 
(37)  Suspended solids shall mean solids which either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquid and which are removable by laboratory filtration. Their concentration shall be expressed in milligrams per liter. Quantitative determinations shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in standard methods. 
(38)  Watercourse shall mean a channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently. 
(39)  WPCF shall mean the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
(Ord. No. 443, 6-13-77) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 26-72. - Use of public sewers required. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with applicable statutes, rules and regulations of the state and the United States. 
(3)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage inside the city limits. 
(4)  The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within two hundred fifty (250) feet (76.3 meters) of the property line. 
(Ord. No. 443, 6-13-77) 
Sec. 26-73. - Private sewage disposal. 
(1)  Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 26-72, subsection (4), the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the director. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the director and approved by the board of commissioners. A permit and inspection fee shall be prescribed from time to time by the board of commissioners by resolution. 
(3)  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the director. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction; and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the director when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within seventy-two (72) hours of the receipt of notice by the director. 
(4)  The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all current recommendations of the state department of environmental protection. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the minimum separation requirements of the state department of environmental protection are not met. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any surface or subsurface watercourse. 
(5)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in subsection (4), a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article; and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material approved by the director. 
(6)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(7)  No statement contained in this article shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the state health officer. 
(8)  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to said sewer within sixty (60) days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank-run gravel or dirt. 
(Ord. No. 443, 6-13-77) 
Sec. 26-74. - Building sewers and connections. 
(1)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the director. 
(2)  No owner or occupant of any real property shall tap or drain either directly or indirectly into any public sewer until a sewer tap permit has been obtained and until he has satisfied his obligation to pay all assessments, reimbursements or pro rata shares of sewer extension costs laid against that property for public sewers installed to serve it. A tap permit given in error shall not operate to nullify any such obligation that has been duly recorded. 
(3)  Tap permits shall be obtained from the city's municipal services office and shall be issued only to licensed sewer tap contractors. After making each sewer tap and building sewer installation, the tap contractor shall notify the director so that the tap and the building sewer can be inspected and approved before the excavation is backfilled. Any tap or building sewer installation not made in accordance with the foregoing provisions shall be deemed an illegal installation and, upon discovery, shall be promptly disconnected at the expense of the property owner and shall remain disconnected until the provisions of this section have been complied with. 
(4)  The board of commissioners shall have the authority to require an owner of real property to disconnect from a building sewer which drains into a sanitary sewer any downspouts, yard drains or other drains which carry the runoff of natural precipitation. Property owners shall have thirty (30) days after notice to comply with any such requirements. 
(5)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the contractor. The contractor shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(6)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer. 
(7)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the director, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(8)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing and testing shall comply with the city's plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city and the state. The materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9, Sewer Design and Construction, shall apply except that additional code provisions may be required by the director as outlined herein. 
(9)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(10)  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, area way drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(11)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city and the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made in accordance with the standards of the ASCE and ASTM.
